xi
Preface
Nanotechnology has been booming in many areas, including materials science, mechanics, electronics, optics, medicine, plastics, energy, electronics, and aerospace. Nowadays, it is playing an extraordinary role in the functional finishing of textiles and polymers. It has sought to improve existing material performances and develop fibers, composites, and novel finishing methods. Application of nanoparticles has imparted novel characteristics to textiles such as flame retardation, UV-blocking, water repellence, self-cleaning, and antimicrobial properties. This book on “Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles” presents diverse aspects of nanomaterial application in the textile industry, approaches used for synthesis and application, as well as strategies to remove toxic effluents from wastewaters employing state-of-the-art nanoadsorbents. We have no doubt that the readers will benefit from this book which covers latest developmental work pertaining to functionalization of textiles using diverse nanomaterials. We would also like to thank all the authors who contributed the chapters and provided their valuable ideas and knowledge in this book. We are also very thankful to the editorial board, and in particular to Martin Scrivener for the generous cooperation at every stage of the book production.
Shahid-ul-Islam B.S. Butola
Indian Institute of Technology Delhi (IITD), Hauz Khas, New Delhi, India
December 15, 2017
1 Shahid-ul-Islam and B.S. Butola (eds.) Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles, (1–70) © 2018 Scrivener Publishing LLC
1 Functional Finishing of Textiles
via Nanomaterials Azadeh Bashari*, Mina Shakeri, Anahita Rouhani Shirvan
and Seyyed Abbas Noorian Najafabadi
Textile Engineering Department, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
Abstract The unique properties of nanomaterials have real commercial potential for the textile industry. In recent years, fine materials that are produced using nanotechnology have been used in the textile production process. Production of functional textiles is the main purpose of using nanomaterials or nanocomponents on natural fibers such as cotton, wool, silk and synthetic fibers such as polyester, nylon, and acrylic, as they possess various properties such as light resistance, antimicrobial, self-cleaning, fire retardant, etc.
Different kinds of nanostructures are used in textiles. For example, carbon and copper nanoparticles or polymeric nanostructures such as polypyrrol and polyaniline as electro conductive agents; aluminum, zinc oxides, and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) for increasing durability of fibers; antimicrobial agents such as silver, zinc oxide, and titanium dioxide (TiO2); moisture absorbent agents such as TiO2; selfcleaning nanostructures such as CNT, TiO2, and fluoroacrylates; UV protection agents as TiO2 and ZnO; nano porous structures such as silicon dioxide or carbon black in order to improve dye ability of fibers; and many advanced properties such as heat conducting or insulating or electromagnetic shielding via introducing CNT or vanadium dioxide and indium tin oxide to fibers, respectively.
In this chapter, the development of using nanostructures to improve the properties of textiles is discussed. For this reason, nanostructures used in finishing processes are presented, separately.
Keywords: Nanotechnology, functional finishing, antibacterial, anti-odor, deodorant, UV-protective, water repellent, self-cleaning, flame-retardant, wrinkle-resistance
*Corresponding author: bashari@aut.ac.ir

sections.heading: 2 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
1.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Textiles play a major role in the development and industrialization of countries. The increasing demand for modern functional textiles has led to the usage of new materials and technology. Therefore, high-tech materials and well thought-out fabric constructions can improve the wearing comfort and provide unique properties. Antimicrobial effects, UV-protection, flame retardancy, stain and water repellency features, and others are the most important requirements of textiles. Since textiles are now widely used in different application sectors such as clothing, pharmaceutical, medical, engineering, agricultural, and food industries, imparting these characteristics into textiles can increase their potential for different applications.
Nowadays, there is a new revolution in the textile industry with the apparition of new technologies, which could add special functions and prominent features to the fabrics. For example, there has been notable improvement in technologies for natural and synthetic textile finishing, smart fabrics, and high performance functional textiles. In this sense, nanomaterials play a vital role in technological evolution since they show interesting surface properties that allow increasing their effect in comparison with bulky traditional additives and materials. For instance, using conventional nanomaterials such as metal oxide agents, carbon-based materials, host-guest compounds, and so on are examples of nanostructured materials used in antimicrobial, deodorant, UV-protection, self-cleaning, and other common finishing methods. In addition, in view of the rising environmental awareness, using environment-friendly methods and materials is necessary in the finishing process. Therefore, using alternative materials with high environmental safety is preferred.
This chapter reviews the most relevant contributions of the use of nanoparticles for functionalize textile materials. In fact, in this section, the use of nanomaterials for providing new properties such as antibacterial activity, anti-odor properties, UV-protection, self-cleaning, crease resistance, and others is explained.

sections.heading: 1.2 Antibacterial Textiles
sections.text:
With increasing population in recent years, the bacterial infection problems are becoming more and more serious in comparison to the past. Many microorganisms live in human’s environment. The presence of these microorganisms on textiles can lead to unwanted consequences such as paling, staining, decrease in mechanical properties, and decaying of the textile. In
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 3
addition, some environmental factors such as temperature and humidity and chemical materials that are used in textile finishing can provide an appropriate media for the microorganisms to grow and multiply [1].
Some species of bacteria have a covering capsule, which surround them and keep them from drying out and other external factors. Each bacterium is enclosed by a rigid cell wall composed of peptidoglycan, a protein-sugar (polysaccharide) molecule. The wall gives the cell its shape and surrounds the cytoplasmic membrane, protecting it from the environment. The most important role of antibacterial agents is to penetrate in the cell wall and inhibit the bacteria’s living.
The best way to prevent growth and multiplication of bacteria is to destroy their appropriate conditions for living. Several factors provide an acceptable media for bacteria to live such as nutritional requirements, water, oxygen, and heat. These factors are easy to find in textiles due to their contact with the human body. That is why the human body can be a good place for the microorganisms to live and multiply [2].
Antibacterial modification of textiles prevents the growth of bacteria, fungi, alga, and other microorganisms on them. One or more chemical agents that can destroy the microorganism’s structure are used in this process [3].
Antibacterial materials are divided into two main groups called bacteriostatic and bactericide.
Bacteriostatic can link to the amino acids of the DNA in the bacterial structures and prevent the multiplication of the bacteria. On the other hand, bactericides can disrupt the routine metabolism of the bacteria and completely destroy them [4].
A practical antibacterial agent must be easy to use in textile finishing methods, stable and durable in different treatments, compatible with other finishing materials, and non-toxic for end users and environment [3].
The antibacterial finishing of textiles has recently become a very active research field and has a great significance among the other methods of modification of textiles. Several metal nanoparticles have been suggested for antibacterial finishing of textiles such as silver, zinc, and titanium. There are also some biopolymers like chitosan, alginate, and starch that are used extensively in the textile industry.
Metal nanoparticles are more effective in comparison to biopolymers due to their multi-targeted mechanism of action, high surface area-to-volume ratio, and unique properties of these nanoparticles. A large surface area of

sections.heading: 4 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
the nanoparticles increases the contact of the antibacterial agent with bacteria and fungi, which is an important advantage of nanoparticles. Among all the materials with antibacterial properties such as copper, zinc, silver, titanium, gold, chitosan, and alginate, silver have proved to be the most effective against bacteria in antibacterial textile finishing [5].
Metal nanoparticles can be induced into textile by sol–gel technique, magnetron sputter coating, plasma sputtering, layer-by-layer coating, and other methods. One of the widely used techniques for coating textile substrates is the combination of the sol–gel synthetic procedure with the “paddry-cure” method [1, 6].
Some of the nanostructures that can be used in antibacterial finishing of textiles are mentioned as follows.

sections.heading: 1.2.1 Antibacterial Organic and Non-Organic Nanostructures
sections.text:
These nanostructures can be applied directly on the fabric or can be loaded on the textile via a chemical carrier. There are following two groups in this category.
Non-organic and metal nanostructures and nano composites: As mentioned before, some nanoparticles such as metal oxides, copper nano crystals, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and nano clay can be used for antibacterial finishing of textiles. Nanostructure-loaded carriers: In this method, several chemical materials such as nano spheres, nano/microcapsules, dendrimers, liposomes, and nano tubes can be used for loading of the antibacterial agent and delivering it to the surface of the fabric.
Some of the mentioned nanostructures are explained briefly as follows.

sections.heading: 1.2.1.1 TiO2 Nanoparticles
sections.text:
When the titanium dioxide (TiO2) catalyst is irradiated with light of energy greater than or equal to its band gap energy, electron–hole pairs are generated that can induce redox reactions at the surface of TiO2 [7]. The general scheme for the photocatalytic damage of microorganism cells by TiO2 photocatalytic properties involves several steps:
1. The photo-excited TiO2 catalyst produces electron–hole pairs that migrate to the TiO2 surface.
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 5
2. Photo-generated holes in TiO2 can react with adsorbed H2O or OH- at the catalyst/water interface to produce highly reactive hydroxyl radicals and the electrons can react with oxygen vacancies to form superoxide ions. 3. Finally, the various highly active oxygen species generated can oxidize organic compounds/cells adsorbed on the TiO2 surface, resulting in the death of the microorganisms [8].
By the combination of electron and electron hole with oxygen, carbon dioxide and water will form in an oxidation-reduction reaction (Figure 1.1).
Through this reaction, TiO2 nanoparticles can destroy the cell wall of the bacteria and provide an effective protection against them [9, 10].

sections.heading: 1.2.1.2 Silver Nanoparticles
sections.text: Silver is a nontoxic inorganic metal, which is not harmful for the human body. Several studies have shown that silver has a broad antibacterial activity toward bacteria and fungi. It is believed that the antibacterial effect of silver nanoparticles comes from their strong affinity toward phosphorus or sulfur. Since the cell wall of the bacteria contains amounts of sulfurcontaining proteins, silver nanoparticles can react with these groups and affect the bacteria performance [11, 12]. It was also reported that the released silver ions (particularly Ag+) from silver nanoparticles can interact with phosphorus moieties in DNA, leading to inactivation of DNA replication, or react with sulfur-containing proteins, resulting in the inhibition of enzyme functions [13].

sections.heading: 6 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
Silver nanoparticles have attracted many researchers due to their effective performance against bacteria and fungi. These nanostructures can be very reactive with proteins and will inhibit the growth of the bacteria completely (Figure 1.2) [9].
Scientists suggest the following three main mechanisms for antibacterial effect of silver nanoparticles:
Decomposing of the bacterial cell wall Reacting with the S–H group in the enzymes and inhibiting the metabolism of the microorganism Creating the active oxygen groups [14].
In recent years, researchers have been studying on the usage of silver nanoparticles in nano composites with polypropylene fibers and other metal oxides [15].

sections.heading: 1.2.1.3 ZnO Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Zinc oxide nanostructures are also photocatalyst materials, which has the same mechanism as TiO2 nanoparticles. ZnO nanoparticles are widely
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 7
used now in antibacterial textiles due to their effective photocatalytic properties [9].
Recent studies indicate that the ZnO nanostructure show better antibacterial properties when doped with CuO molecules. It can be due to the narrower band gap of Zn structures when doped with copper and better photocatalysis activity in this condition [16].
In another study, antibacterial behavior of suspensions of zinc oxide nanoparticles has been investigated against E. coli. It was deducted that the effects of particle size, concentration, and the use of dispersants are large on the antibacterial behavior. The results show that the ZnO nano fluids have bacteriostatic activity against E. coli. It was also deducted that the antibacterial activity increases with increasing nanoparticle concentration and with decreasing particle size, while it turned out that particle concentration is more important than particle size. SEM analyses of the bacteria before and after treatment with ZnO nano fluids show that the presence of ZnO nanoparticles damages the membrane wall of the bacteria. Electrochemical measurements also show some direct interaction between ZnO nanoparticles and the bacterial membrane at high ZnO concentrations [17].

sections.heading: 1.2.1.4 Chitosan
sections.text:
Chitosan is one of the natural biopolymers that has attracted researchers’ attention due to the environmental and toxicological concerns about the use of heavy metals for the production of nanoparticles (Figure 1.3). It is assumed that the antibacterial effect of chitosan is because of the presence of amino groups, which gives chitosan a significant characteristic in decomposing the bacteria and fungi [5].
Chitosan’s molecular weight is an important object in researches, which has a significant effect on the antibacterial activity of the textiles. Recent studies on the antibacterial activity of chitosan and chitosan oligomers have revealed that chitosan is more effective in inhibiting the growth of bacteria than chitosan oligomers. Furthermore, the antibacterial effect of

sections.heading: 8 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
chitosan and chitosan oligomers is reported to be dependent on its molecular weight [18].
In a study, the molecular weight of chitosan and chitosan oligomers has been investigated. It was shown that chitosan has a better antibacterial activity in comparison to chitosan oligomers [19].

sections.heading: 1.3 Anti-Odor Textiles
sections.text:
Anti-odor textiles are one of the main sectors of the textile industry, which have increased considerably over the last few years due to rising consumer health awareness. Especially in the main parts of the textile industry such as sportswear, underwear, socks, and shoes, using anti-odor textiles have received much attention and nanotechnology plays a vital role in this issue.
There are various types of unpleasant odors in our daily life, such as body odor caused by metabolism and aging, and odors of garbage and cigarettes. In terms of chemical structures, unpleasant odors are divided into the following three main groups:
Fatty acids such as body odor, sweat odor, etc. Nitrogen compounds such as urine, the smell of fish, etc. Sulfur-containing compounds, such as excreta, etc.
Therefore, deodorant technology has attracted worldwide attention in different fields of applications. Among the various approaches, physical methods (absorption of odors by activated carbon), chemical methods (turning the odor into a common smell), and using aromatic compounds have been proposed to eliminate unpleasant odors [20]. Therefore, with the increasing number of people being sensitive to odors, using anti-odor technology is an obligation for textile producers.

sections.heading: 1.3.1 Odor-Control Methods
sections.text:
In general, there are two different mechanisms for controlling the odors in textiles:
Absorption: simple capture of the offending molecules. No change is made to the process of decomposition. Prevention: bacteria are prevented from multiplication; the offending molecules are not generated [21, 22].
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 9

sections.heading: 1.3.1.1 Absorption Mechanism
sections.text:
According to the absorption mechanism, several types of nanostructured materials are used for deodorizing textiles, which is shown in Figure 1.4.
1.3.1.1.1 Cyclodextrins Cyclodextrins (CDs) are a family of cyclic oligosaccharides with 6–8 glucopyranoside units which are known as α, β, and γ-CD [23]. Among different types of CDs, β-CD has a wide range of applications in the textile industry due to its low cost, ease of production, and ease of attachment to surfaces. Also, the size of pores makes it suitable for trapping a range of odor molecules [24]. One of the natural properties of CD is stacking the molecules on top of each other that increases the probability of absorption of odorous compounds. On the other hand, when the scent molecules are absorbed by CDs, the conical structure provides the effective possibility of maintaining the odor molecules. However, CDs as anti-odor agents have some problems. Since different odor compounds have various sizes and shapes, small molecules pass easily through the pores but large molecules cannot enter the inner structure of CDs. Therefore, CDs just maintain specific odor molecules with certain size [25]. CDs have been extensively used for the absorption of various odors in different applications such as controlling the odors caused by chronic wounds. For example, CDs can be incorporated

sections.heading: 10 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
into various materials used for wound healing such as hydrogels. They are used in applications outside of wound care for the control of foul odors. However, there are some limitations in the absorption process by CDs like slow diffusion rate and water deficiency. It seems that these problems can be solved by using the combination of CDs and conventional hydrocolloids, such as sodium carboxymethyl cellulose for effective elimination of wound malodor. This technology has been already introduced as “Exuderm Odorshield” brand (Medline Industries Inc, Mundelein, IL, USA) [26].
In a research, Narayanan et al. introduced an efficient wound odor removal by β-cyclodextrin-functionalized poly (ε-caprolactone) nanofibers. According to the results, the PCL/β-CD nanocomposites, by virtue of having their β-CD cavities free and unthreaded by PCL, could potentially be an ideal substrate for removing wound odors through the formation of inclusion compounds with odorants [27]. In the same study, Lipman et al. developed a new series of hydrocolloid adhesives based on CDs to provide an alternative technology for the adsorption of chronic wound odors. Their results showed that CD materials provide a new method of controlling the malodor associated with various types of wounds [28].
1.3.1.1.2 Activated Carbon Nanoparticles Activated carbon is one of the most widely investigated absorbents in various fields such as water treatment, food industry, medicine, and the environment. It is considered as the most effective method for deodorizing in textiles. The mechanism of odor absorption by activated carbon is physical entrapment and it is capable to trap small molecules of body odors due to the high porous structure. Then, in order to eliminate the trapped scent molecules from a textile, a scouring treatment is required. In addition, activated carbon has an incredibly large surface area per unit volume and good potential to absorb a large quantity of odor molecules.
Another  amazing  property of activated carbon nanoparticles is their ability to absorb a wide range of odor compounds with various sizes. According to the research by Dr. Don Thompson from North Carolina State University, there are different types of odor compounds in the shoes due to the foot sweat. So, the diversity of odor compounds produced by body sweat creates a serious requirement to use materials such as carbon nanoparticles [29]. In a patent, Quincy et al. invented a dual-element odor control in personal care products. Their products comprised two portions with a formulation of activated carbon and silver nanoparticles. The obtained layer is disposed in a personal care product selected from the group consisting of diapers, training pants, absorbent underpants, adult incontinence products, and feminine hygiene products [30].
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 11
1.3.1.1.3 Bamboo Charcoal Nanoparticles Bamboo is an Asian plant that is found in diverse climates from cold mountains to tropical or subtropical regions. Bamboo is one of the most notable natural resources because it is a fast-growing plant and used for various applications such as preparation of cellulose nanofibers and enhancing properties of synthetic fibers such as polyester.
Bamboo charcoal is prepared by five years of pyrolysis process of bamboo at high temperatures of about 800–1200 °C (Figure 1.5) and obtained from two different resources:
Stems, leaves, and roots of the bamboo plant Bamboo wastes.
Therefore, the bamboo charcoal nanoparticles act like a sponge, catching any odor inside its fine pores. These nanoparticles are considered as a good candidate for odor absorption of textiles and the environment [31, 32]. Organic bamboo charcoal is 100% safe to use in fabrics, which are directly in touch to our skin. Therefore, bamboo charcoal nanoparticles have already been widely used with great success in different applications such as beauty products, water filters, foods, and medicines.
Bamboo charcoal powder’s ultra-fine structure contains millions of tiny gaps, which allows 1 gram of bamboo charcoal powder to cover a surface area of 600 square meters. This super porous structure of bamboo charcoal powder absorbs bacteria, unwanted odor, and wicks away sweat up to 50% quicker than cotton. 
According to the literatures, bamboo charcoal can absorb formaldehyde, benzene, toluene, ammonia, and chloroform at a rate of 16–19.39%, 8.69– 10.08%, 5.65–8.42%, 22.73–30.65%, and 40.68%, respectively. Also, bamboo charcoal fiber effectively decomposes the microorganisms attached to its surface and in the air around it. Recently, Ettitude Company has introduced its new product, “Bacteria and Odor Control Bamboo Charcoal Bedding”. In this product, bamboo charcoal’s ultra-fine structure powder is added in the bamboo lyocell fabrication process to create the antimicrobial and anti-odor bedding fabric [33]. In addition, Greenyarn Company

sections.heading: 12 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
has exposed their fabrics that contain bamboo charcoal nanoparticles for use in products such as socks and underwear. These bamboo charcoal nanoparticles have antibacterial and deodorizing properties [34].
1.3.1.1.4 Dandelion-like polymers A novel method of producing an odor-controlling textile is using a polymer with odor-trapping ability (Figure 1.6). Milliken Company first developed this technology in 1865 as a housekeeping and cleanliness technology to control the unpleasant odor of carpets and furniture. This method was inspired by a dandelion structure as a polymer mass containing very small branches. When, a person wears such a textile with an odor-trapping technology, the small scent molecules released from the body are trapped by the dandelion structure. Following the odor-capturing process, the conventional scouring method is utilized to remove the odor compounds from the polymer. So, these kinds of textiles have reusability, which is the most important characteristic of dandelion-like polymers. However, short lifetime and absorption of a low range of odor compounds are the main drawbacks of these polymers [35].
1.3.1.1.5 Activated alumina nanoparticles Activated alumina is prepared by de-hydroxylation of aluminum hydroxide. It is a highly porous material with a large surface area-to-volume ratio due to the many “tunnel like” pores. Activated alumina is used as an effective odor absorbent in a wide range of applications such as wastewater, antiodor textile, and others via trapping the odor molecules in their pores [36]. In some researches, activated alumina nanoparticles with their tunnel-like pores have been used as an effective absorbent for different applications.
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 13
For example, Jenkins et al. produced an absorbent composition with improved odor control suitable for use as an animal litter, comprising an absorbent material, activated alumina, and optional additives [37]. Furio et al. proposed an absorbent structure with odor-control material consisting of activated alumina, carbon, silica gel, zeolite, siliceous molecular sieve, and their mixtures for an adult incontinence garment, absorbent pad, or diaper [38].
1.3.1.1.6 Nano Silica Gel Silica gel is a hard, granular, and porous substance made by precipitation from sodium silicate solutions treated with an acid. The main properties of nano silica gel such as porous structure and large specific surface area play a vital role in the odor absorption process [39]. However, nano silica gel is not commonly used as an odor absorbent in comparison with other odor absorption agents in different applications.

sections.heading: 1.3.1.2 Prevention Mechanism
sections.text: This approach is based on preventing proliferation of the odor-causing bacteria by different types of antimicrobial agents such as silver, titanium, zinc oxide nanoparticles, and so on, which are described in section 1.3.

sections.heading: 1.4 Deodorant Textiles
sections.text:
Smelling a delightful aroma can be a very pleasurable experience and have physiological and emotional effects. Fragrance finishing of textiles has been greatly expanded in recent years and enhanced the benefit of the products.
The most natural aromatic substances are essential oils that are extracted from different parts especially aerial parts of plants such as leaves and flowers. These compounds are produced due to complex metabolic reactions in plant in order to protect the plant against various pathogens and insects and also reduce the tendency of some herbivorous animals [40]. Some of the biological activities of natural aromas such as antimicrobial, antiviral, anti-inflammatory, anti-mutation, anti-cancer, and antioxidant effects have been proven [41].

sections.heading: 1.4.1 Aromatic Textiles with Nanocarriers
sections.text: Although the aromatic textiles concept is not new, recently great progress has been made on the textile-finishing process in order to produce effective

sections.heading: 14 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
and long-lasting aromatic textiles. In the past, the aromatic extracts usually have been used via direct spraying on the surface of textiles. Today, encapsulation has been known as an effective method to increase the lifetime of odors on textiles. Micro/nano encapsulated fragrances are coated on textiles and released due to pressure or abrasion of textiles or garments [42].
For many years, researchers are seeking a new formulation for gradual release of drugs in the body. Today, drug delivery systems (DDS) such as lipid- or polymer-based nanostructures are characterized having great benefits in comparison with conventional methods of drug delivery [43]. In order to control the release rating, improve the efficiency, reduce the toxicity, and lower the side effects of aromatic compounds, the same DDS are used for essential oils [44].
Nanocarriers such as lipid carriers, nano emulsions, and biocompatible polymer nanostructures are able to protect aromatic compounds against oxidation or evaporation. Some types of nanocarriers are shown in Figure 1.7.
In the 1970s, researchers used nanoparticles for delivering and releasing vaccines and anticancer drugs for the first time. Recently, in addition to pharmaceutical compositions, the nanoparticles have been utilized to carry the aromatic compounds and protect them from optical and thermal decompositions and increase the lifetime and efficiency of these active materials.

sections.heading: 1.4.1.1 Polymeric Nanocarriers
sections.text:
Polymeric nanocarriers include nanocapsules and nano sphere systems. Nanocapsules are nanoscale core/shell systems made from a polymer in which aroma is confined into the core surrounded by a polymer membrane, while nano spheres are matrix systems in which the aroma is physically dispersed.
Biocompatible natural or synthetic polymers are suggested for producing polymeric nanocarriers. The most common natural and man-made polymers in preparation of polymeric nanocarriers are chitosan, gelatin,
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 15
alginate, polylactides (PLA), poly (lactide co-glycolides) (PLGA), and poly acrylamide [45].
1.4.1.1.1 Methods of Producing Nanocapsules This group of nanostructures can be prepared with different physical, chemical, physicochemical, and mechanical techniques, which are effective on size, particle-size distribution, thickness of shell, morphology, and other characteristics of the nanocapsules [46]. Different types of such methods are summarized in Figure 1.8.
Many methods have been developed for preparing polymeric nanocarriers containing aromatic compounds. The usage of a non-solvent compound to fabricate nanostructured deposition and solvent exchange are the most widely used methods. In this technique, polymer and aroma are dissolved in a suitable organic solvent or a mixture of several solvents, and then this organic solution, in the presence or absence of a surfactant, is introduced to water with applied shearing stress. The organic solvents are separated from the polymer via evaporation and a polymeric film or powder is made [47].
Corzani prepared a fragrance delivery system consiting of a mixture of 50% poly(tetramethylene glycol) having an a number average molecular weight (Mn) of approximately 2000 Da with 25 wt% of a rosin ester plasticizer and 25 wt% benzyl acetate with a selcted perfume.

sections.heading: 16 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
Yang prepared a fragrance delivery system consiting of 20% limonene and 3% γ-terpinene compounded with an ionic stabilizer, dihydropropyltrimonium chloride, fatty esters, and a silicob fluid.
A fragrance delivery system consisting of a nanostructure microcapsule shell of urea-formaldehyde or melamine-formaldehyde and containing an olfactive component was prepeared by Lie and had at least a 6-month shelf life when stored at 37 °C [48].
Encapsulating rose fragrance in nanoparticles in order to reduce the evaporation of volatile compounds and prepare the long-term fragrancereleasing textile has been proposed by Hu et al. Chitosan nanocapsules loaded with fragrance were prepared via the ionic gelification in acetic acid, Tween 80 as a surfactant, and sodium tripolyphosphate as a gelation compound under ultrasonication. Aroma-loaded nanocapsules were incorporated into the cotton fibers via immersion in nanoemulsion under vacuum [49]. The SEM micrographs of untreated cotton and treated cotton fibers with aroma-filled nanocapsules are shown in Figure 1.9.
Applications of encapsulated fragrances, perfumes, and essential oils are in woven and nonwoven textiles ranging from perfumed curtains, bed linen, shirts, socks, and hosiery to antimicrobial towels, shoe insols, and textiles for seats in public transportaion [50].

sections.heading: 1.4.1.2 Lipid Nanostructures
sections.text:
Liposomes, niosomes, solid lipid nanoparticles (SLN), and nanostructured lipid carriers (NLC) are four major types of lipid nanostructures.
Liposomes and niosomes as potential carriers for hydrophilic and hydrophobic compounds are bilayer structures that consist of phospholipid and non-ionic surfactant vesicles, respectively.
SLNs and NLCs are lipid core particles that are solid at body and ambient temperature. So lipid carriers are suitable for trapping and carrying lyophilic compounds such as essential oils.
Lipid nanostructures are summarized in Table 1.1.
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 17
Increasing the stability of the drug delivery system and dissolving oilbased aromas in aqueous phase are the main factors for using lipid carriers in aroma finishing of textiles. Liposomes are the most reported nanocarriers for essential oils.
Dahms et al. invented a SLN dispersion for the controlled release of fragrances and/or aromas. In this formulation, SLNs with varying melting points are dispersed in an aqueous medium with emulsifiers that formed not only monolayers around lipid particles but also lyotropic liquid-crystalline membranes within the aqueous phase. The fragrance may be included both in the nanoparticles and/or in the emulsifier monolayers or the liquid-crystalline membrane layers. Oil-soluble and/or amphiphilic fragrance oils or aromas are preferably stored in the lipid particles while hydrophilic, waterslouble fragrances are incorporated into the aqueous phase [52].

sections.heading: 18 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: On the other hand, nanostructured lipid carriers (NLCs) can be used in fragrance products to prolong the release of the fragrance. Fragrance evaporates fast from ethanolic solutions, delayed from the more viscous liquid lipid (oil) of o/w emulsions, and more delayed from the solid lipid of NLC due to reduced diffusion. Other delayed release products are insect repellents [53].

sections.heading: 1.4.1.3 Cyclodextrins
sections.text:
Considering the volatile nature of fragrance compounds and essential oils, the fragrance molecules have to be formed as inclusion compounds with CD molecules in order to retain fragrances for a long time. To prepare aromatherapeutic textiles, β-cyclodextrin is the first choice as the host molecule, because β-cyclodextrin molecules are capable of forming inclusion compounds with organic compounds that fit into their own cone-shaped hydrophobic cavities. As a result of the inclusion, the physicochemical properties of the compounds are changed; for example, the vapor pressure of the volatile substance is reduced and the stabilities against light and air are enhanced. The functional textile with the “guest–host” effect may be achieved by anchoring the inclusion compound. The sedative effects for emotion and the pharmaceutical effects of essential oils were shown by Wang et al.
In this research, β-cyclodextrins were resolute in a mixture of alcohol and distilled water (1:3). The solution was emulsified in a high-speed mixer at a speed of about 10,000 rpm for 5 min. The lavender–alcohol solution was added to the emulsified solution within 30 min, with the aid of stirring, while the temperature was maintained at 40 °C for 2 h. The inclusion compound was fixed onto cotton with a low temperature binder by a conventional pad-thermofixing method. As a result, the rate of fragrance release of inclusion compounds decreases with time [54].
If CD is used as a carrier for aromatic compounds, this carrier should be bound to fibers in order to enhance the washing fastness of fragrance textiles. Since CD is not able to bind directly to the textile substrate, the usage of CD derivates or a cross-linking agent is recommended [55]. β-cyclodextrin modified with monochlorotriazine was synthesized by Sricharussin et al. and applied on cotton fabric. The pad–dry–cure method at high temperature (150 °C) was the best fixation way for this CD derivate on cotton fabrics. Sandalwood oil was sprayed onto the modified fabric to prepare aroma inclusion in CD [56].
In another research, Bndyopadyay et al. employed maleic anhydride as the modifying agent for finishing cotton fabric with β-cyclodextrin in the presence of ammonium peroxodisulphate, as a free radical polymerization catalyst and tetra sodium pyrophosphate as an esterification catalyst. The
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 19
modified fabric had been treated with Thyme essential oil and the retention of fragrance and sustained release of essential oil had been assessed after repeated post-wash procedures. The results showed that fragrances held by CD can withstand the action of detergent wash for a significant number of wash cyles [57].

sections.heading: 1.4.1.4 Dendrimers
sections.text: Dendrimers are repetitively branched molecules that have attracted considerable attention in the textile industry (Figure 1.10). A dendritic structure has potential to act as a host molecule via abundant functional groups and hollow interior branches. They are able to include non-polar or charged guest molecules into their pockets by hydrophobic/hydrogen-bond interactions, or on the branches by electrostatic interactions and forming different types of inclusions or ion-pairs in aqueous solutions. In this regard, Akbari et al. used the second generation of PPI dendrimer to produce long-lasting fragrant semi-worsted fabric. They investigated the release behavior of ginseng and rosewater as fragrance candidates using an E-nose and reported excellent sustained-release property of treated fabrics for a long time [58].

sections.heading: 1.4.2 Application of Aroma Textiles
sections.text: Cosmetic textiles: micro/nanocapsules containing moisturizing agents, essential oils, skin-cooling agents, vitamins, and pro-vitamins have been used as finishing agents for textiles.

sections.heading: 20 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: Aromatherapy via textiles: modified textiles such as bed linen, curtains, carpets and bedspreads with lavender, cinnamon, and citrus oils are very appropriate for a better sleep and lowering fatigue. On the other hand, the patients suffering from high blood pressure feel more comfortable after using relaxing aromatic herbal pillow with lavender, basil, or lemon oils. Sportswear: antibacterial effects and preserving the freshness and energy can be obtained in sports apparel via using essential oils such as lemon or orange.

sections.heading: 1.5 Protective Textile Against Electromagnetic Radiation
sections.text: The development of the electronics industry and the increasing usage of electronic products in communications, computing, automation, biomedical, aerospace, and others can lead to electromagnetic (EM) interference. In other words, radiation-induced waves can cause problems for electronic devices and health issues. Hence, the demand for strict protection of people and electronic devices against the unpleasant effects of EM signals and free charge problems has increased. This section discusses different types and properties of EM waves, followed by the introduction of methods and materials that improve protective finishing textiles against EM radiation. These methods include protective finishing textiles by using nanostructures and high performance fibers.

sections.heading: 1.5.1 EM Waves
sections.text: EM waves are named because they have both an electric and a magnetic component. They create when charged particles vibrate due to the various forces acting on them. The vibration of charged particles results in an emission of energy known as EM radiation. EM waves include infrared, ultraviolet, radio waves, microwaves, X-rays, and gamma rays.

sections.heading: 1.5.2 The Effect of EM Radiation on the Body
sections.text:
Although that light therapy or photo therapy has been growing rapidly recently and the use of coherent waves (single-phase wave like laser light) or non-coherent waves (non-single-phase wave such as sunlight) in the infrared can accelerate wound healing, reduce pain and inflammation, and
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 21
prevent tissues’ death [59], the exposure of EM radiation on the body may lead to physical damage, stimulating nerves and muscles, and changes in the nerve cell performances [60]. Due to the vibration and heat generation by EM radiation in the human’s body, DNA and RNA in cells may halt production, which will lead to abnormal chemical activity of cells and cell cancer [61].
The simplest and most effective way to prevent EM radiation hazards is to stay away from the radiation source. One of the primary methods used in protection from EM radiation is “shielding”. Shielding can be described as reducing the EM field in a space by blocking the field with barriers made of conductive or magnetic materials. EM shielding materials are usually used to reduce the intensity of EM fields [62].

sections.heading: 1.5.3 Shielding Materials Against the EM Waves
sections.text:
When an EM field is passed through an object, there are three phenomena that determine how the field strength is lost as it interacts with the object: absorption attenuation, attenuation due to reflection, and attenuation due to successive internal reflections. Thus, EM shields function based on the above-mentioned two major EM mechanisms: reflection from a conducting surface and absorption in a conductive volume. An EM wave striking a metallic surface encounters both types of losses. Part of the wave is reflected, while the remainder is transmitted and attenuated as it passes through the media. The combined effect of these losses (reflection and absorption) determines the effectiveness of the shield [63].
Absorption in an EM shield transforms EM energy into thermal energy. In general, the materials used for absorbing EM waves can be classified into two groups:
1. materials with high dielectric constant, such as BaTiO3 and carbon particles, 2. materials with high permeability, such as Fe3O4 and ferrite materials [64].
Materials with a high dielectric constant absorb the electric energy and convert it into thermal energy, while materials with high permeability convert the magnetic energy into thermal energy [65].
In the past, the traditional approach for EMI shielding relied on the use of metallic materials, which supply excellent shielding effectiveness. In recent years, in addition to the metal layers, conductive polymers are used to protect the body against EM waves. Conventional textile fibers have

sections.heading: 22 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
sufficient isolation properties with resistance at around 1015 Ω/cm2, which is more than the resistance required for applications of protection against EM waves (109–1013 Ω/cm2). Therefore, conductive textiles are produced for improving protection against EM waves [61]. The basic mechanism of protection against EM radiation is improving charge transfer (electron or hole). In other words, the protective materials must contain electrical/ magnetic dipoles, to have the ability to interact with the EM field.
Electric dipoles such as carbon particles and BaTiO3 on textiles have high dielectric constants, whereas magnetic dipole on ferromagnetic substrates such as ferrite material and Fe3O4 cause high magnetic permeability. In other words, materials with a high dielectric constant attract electric power and convert it into thermal energy, while high magnetic permeable materials convert absorbed magnetic energy into heat energy [66].
Metals are the best protective materials against the EM waves, due to their conductivity and stability. However, these materials are often expensive and heavy and some problems such as expansion and oxidation or corrosion may occur during their use. In contrast, most of the fabrics made of synthetic fibers are electrically insulated and transfer EM field [66].
In recent years, flexibility and lightweight of conductive fabrics have attracted the attention of many researchers in order to produce protective textiles against EM waves. Conductive fabrics are prepared by conductive fibers or special finishing methods using a slight amount of conductive materials such as carbon. The following methods can be used to achieve the conductive textiles:
1. Lamination of conducting layers onto the fabric surface, conductive coating, zinc arc spraying, ionic plating, vacuum metallization, and sputtering 2. Adding conductive fillers, such as conductive carbon black, carbon fiber, CNTs, metal powder, and flake (Al, Cu, Ag, Ni) to the spinning dope of synthetic fibers 3. Incorporation of conductive fibers or yarns into the fabric [67].

sections.heading: 1.5.3.1 Conductive Polymer
sections.text:
Conducting polymers are a new class of materials with an extensive delocalization of p-electron conjugated network. Among conducting polymers, polyaniline and polypyrrole have received widespread attention because of their environmental stability and moderate conductivity. Conducting polymers are unprocessible due to the extensive delocalization of p-electrons.
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 23
In order to solve this problem, different groups have prepared conducting composites by blending conducting polymers with insulating polymers so that the conducting composites retain the mechanical properties of the conventional polymers and electrical conductivity of the conducting polymers [68].
The polymerization of aniline and pyrrole on insulating fabrics such as polyester cloth, glass fabrics, and high silica cloth was carried out by in situ chemical oxidative polymerization. The chemical polymerization of pyrrole in the presence of textile substrates results in the formation of electrically conducting, polypyrrole-coated fabrics [69].
Engin et al. developed conductive fabrics by polymerizing aniline onto the polyamide (PA)-knitted fabrics. Hydrochloric acid as an acidic medium and ammonium persulfate as an oxidant were employed during the polymerization process. The results showed that the fabric treated with 0.5 M aniline concentration had the highest shielding effectiveness [70].

sections.heading: 1.5.3.2 Metal Nanocoating
sections.text:
Despite the problems associated with the use of metals and conductive polymers for improving the protective properties of textiles, the use of nanoparticles as a very thin layer on textiles is much more favorable. Applying hydroxyl apatite and nanoparticles (TiO2, ZnO, and Fe2O3) with other organic/inorganic materials on the textile surface can increase the protection effect against ultraviolet, infrared, and EM radiations, as well as improving abrasion stability, water repellency, and anti-microbial properties. Clinoptilolite nanoparticles, a silicate mineral microporous crystalline structure with tetrahydral configuration, have been applied on cotton fabric. This treated fabric was used as protective clothing against radioactive radiation [66].
Among the metal particles, applications of magnetic nanoparticle are the best option for improving the protection property against EM waves on textile fabrics. For this purpose, various methods for the synthesis and use of magnetic nanoparticles are used such as lumen loading (direct wetend addition), nano-coated fibers, or in situ nanoparticle synthesis on the textile fabrics [71].
In situ synthesis of nanoparticles on textiles is the easy-to-do method and attracted researchers’ attention for the production of multifunctional textiles. Polyester fabric with multiple protection properties against magnetic fields, antimicrobial, and catalytic activity was prepared by in situ synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles of iron (magnetite and hematite) using iron chloride, iron sulfate, and sodium hydroxide. The process was

sections.heading: 24 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
in two steps at different temperatures, 100 °C and 130 °C, and by usage of α-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 nanoparticles, respectively. The treated fabric with magnetite and hematite has great potential in the protection against EM waves with high stability, excellent antimicrobial activity, and noticeable catalytic activity. Although this method improves textile protection properties, the color of magnetic nanoparticles restricted their application on light-colored textiles [72].
Classical methods of metallic layer deposition such as vacuum evaporation, electron beam evaporation, or chemical deposition of metalorganic compounds are not suitable for some fabrics made of polymeric fibers, such as polypropylene (PP) or polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), because of the properties of their surfaces. The deposited layer has very poor adhesion and is subject to wear. The only possibility is plasma activation of the surface followed by the deposition of a metal layer by vacuum evaporation. It is, however, a two-stage process. Ziaja et al. found that the metallization of PP fabric by pulse magnetron sputtering gives the possibility to obtain metallic layers with very good adhesion, which is impossible to get by other methods. The layer formed is very fine, which is measured in nanometers [73].

sections.heading: 1.5.3.3 Carbon Nanostructures
sections.text:
In recent years, CNT/graphene-based polymer composites are commonly used as EM shielding materials, as they are lightweight, have ease of processing, and good electrical conductivity [74].
Bonaldi et al. produced flexible, lightweight, and porous conductive fabrics as EM shielding by knife-over-roll coating and using combinations of CNT, conductive polymer, and metal nanoparticles. The coating thickness was 100–200 μm, and the EM range tested was 200–1000 MHz. EM shielding fabrics of 95–99.99% (15–40 dB) were obtained, and CNT was found to be the most effective material [75].
Kowsari et al. created a magnetic functional graphene oxide (MFGO)/ epoxy resin composite. The test results showed that a high thickness resulted in excellent microwave absorption [76].
Lin et al. utilized the yarn coating process to ensure that multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) can be arranged along the axial direction via a drawing force. In this method, PET yarns were used as the core and fed into the yarn coating machine. Then, PP/MWCNT composite pellets were coated over the PET yarns via melt extrusion. The conductive yarns were then made into conductive knitted fabrics and woven fabrics. Changing the structure of conductive fabrics and the number of lamination layers also significantly improved the EM shielding effect [77].
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 25

sections.heading: 1.6 UV-Protective Textiles
sections.text:
Sunlight spectrum ranges from ultraviolet to infrared EM radiation. UV wavelength is divided to three parts as UV-A from 320 to 400 nm, UV-B from 280 to 320 nm, and UV-C from 200 to 280 nm, in which the energy per part is significantly increased respectively. While, the UV-C region is completely absorbed by the ozone layer, the UV-A and UV-B regions of wavelength can reach the earth’s surface (Table 1.2) [78].
Too much exposure to short-wavelength EM radiation can lead to damage substance surface. In that case, exposure to UV radiation cause damaging and decaying of nonwoven car supplies, fading of colored clothes, and skin burning for lightweight summer garment wearer. This could result in a series of damaging health effects such as acceleration of skin aging, sunburn, erythema (skin reddening), promotion of photo-dermatitis, and even severe skin cancer (Figure 1.11) [80].

sections.heading: 26 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
1.6.1 The Necessity of Using UV-Protective Textiles
sections.text:
Nowadays, transformation of UV sun light has increased due to the destruction of ozone layer, and as a result, it has led to more skin contact with UV radiation. Therefore, modification of fabric properties as a layer to protect the skin from harmful radiation has been investigated more by researchers. Surface modification of textiles to protect against the UV radiation in children’s, athletes, outdoor workwears, and leisure wear is more important [78].
UV protection properties often make use of a transparent layer of UV-absorbent materials on the surface of the fabric. In other words, chemical agents or nano inorganic materials such as UV absorber and UV blocker can be applied on textile fabrics to improve UV protection factor (UPF) and sun protection factor (SPF). UPF and SPF are described as the UV protection properties of a modified substance. Some factors such as additive agents, material and weaving method of the fabric, and shade of colored fabrics are able to play an important role in the protection of skin against UV radiation. It can consequently reduce the possibility of skin burning and cancers by increasing SPF of the fabrics. The UV protection property of fabrics and garments holds a great significance to end users all over the world and researchers are still studying on each of the effective factors that can influence the SPF of fabrics [45].

sections.heading: 1.6.2 UV Protection Effect of Textile
sections.text:
The UV protection property of a textile fabric depends on fiber types, weaving structures, finishing modification, and color of fabric [81]. Azeem et al. critically discusses and modeled the effect of fabric structure parameters such as ends/inch, picks/inch, warp count, and weft count on the UV protection properties of textiles [80].
The mechanism of UV protective activities on the textile and polymer materials is related to the UV scattering, absorption, and reflection of surface [82]. In general, the surface of textile and polymer materials can reflect and scatter or absorb some parts of the photons and the remaining photons can be transferred through the fabric samples. Although the raw textile fabrics are naturally able to absorb, scatter, and reflect some UV radiation, it is not enough for necessary UV protection property. Additionally, some pretreatments may reduce the UV protection property of textile fabrics. For example, it has been proved that the UV protection property of cotton fibers will decrease after desizing. It can be due to the removal of natural pigments and lignin of cotton fabric after desizing [83].
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 27

sections.heading: 1.6.2.1 UV-Protective Textiles with Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Modification of textile and polymer surfaces by chemical agents and inorganic nanoparticles is significantly investigated. Inorganic nanoparticles such as TiO2, ZnO, SiO2, Cu2O, CuO, Al2O3, and reduced graphene oxide are more abundantly utilized owing to the thermal and chemical stability at high temperatures, permanent stability under UV rays, and non-toxicity compared to the organic ones [84–86].
Among the nano inorganic materials, nano TiO2 and ZnO have some important advantages such as low cost [87], white appearance, photo catalytic oxidation capability [88], self-cleaning and UV-blocking properties [89, 90], and absorption of a larger fraction of the solar spectrum [87, 91]. Modification of textile and polymer substances by metal oxide as UV protection agents can improve the absorbency percentage in the UV region. However, by modifying textile and polymers via increasing the total reflectance and absorbance, the amount of transferred UV light can be reduced. Therefore, the UV protection of modified textile and polymers will increase.
The mechanism of the UV absorption characteristic is certified to the electronic structure of nano metal oxide. Indeed, modification of textile and polymers by the metal oxide nanostructures can absorb UV radiation with the energy of hν that is equal to or surpasses their band gap energy (Eg). The Eg of nanostructures lies in the UV region of the solar range, and therefore has excessive potential to absorb UV rays due to a great specific surface area [81, 92]. In other words, by increasing the surface-areato-volume ratio of materials in nano scale, more absorption of UV rays can be enhanced [91]. For example, TiO2 in nano scale shows superior UV-protection properties than that of the pigment TiO2 in micro scale possessing its stronger UV absorption properties. Also, enormous weak scattering intensity visible for nano TiO2 showed slight effect on the matrix color. Moreover, nano TiO2 has higher UV-A and UV-B absorption capacity than most of the other metal oxides and it has the highest refractive index among metal oxides. Because of great specific surface area and high surface energy and activity, the TiO2 nanoparticles have good affinity to textiles and polymers. Alternatively, when nano-TiO2 is used as a UV protecting agent, the negative effect of blue shift on the absorption edge will decrease the absorption of UV-A close to visible light [92]. However, using TiO2, nanoparticles have proved superior UV protection property for textiles and polymers. Some researchers used bi-component metal oxide to improve UV protection of textile and polymers. Ibrahim et al. used Ag/ TiO2 nanoparticles on linen/cotton (50/50%) fabrics for antibacterial activity, UV-protection property, self-cleaning ability, and durability to washing

sections.heading: 28 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
process. They claimed that these nanoparticles increase the UV-blocking and or scattering capability of UV-rays by changing the fabric color from white to brownish [93]. In another research, Cu2O/ZnO nanoparticles were in situ synthesized to the cotton fabric surface in order to improve the UV protection property. The results revealed that the improving UV protection property is much more in the case of using Cu2O/ZnO nanoparticles than using ZnO and Cu2O nanoparticles alone on cotton fabric. They explained that ZnO nanoparticles have greater UV absorption and reflectance than Cu2O nanoparticles, which guards next-to-treated cotton fabric and both are capable to shield fibers together by in situ formation of a thin layer of particles on the surface of the fabric. Consequently, when ZnO and Cu2O nanoparticles were positioned on the cotton fabric together, more UV rays can be absorbed due to the narrower band gap of this bi-component and synergistic photo absorption activity can be obtained. By studying the effect of in situ parameters such as curing time on the UV protection property, the obtained results showed that by increasing the curing time, the UV protection property improved [94–97].
They revealed that the formation of Cu2O/ZnO caused by the conversion of the residual of metal hydroxides to metal oxides could be increased under long exposure to heat of the curing process. Consequently, in situ synthesis of Cu2O/ZnO nanoparticles on the cotton fabric showed a synergistic effect on the UV protection property [83]. Prasad et al. in situ synthesized ZnO nanoparticles by the spraying and dipping process in order to modify antibacterial and UV protection properties on treated cotton fabrics. They claimed that producing durable antibacterial and UV protection properties on cotton fabric is a result of negative charge of cellulosic chains under alkaline condition that provide abundant sites for the nucleation and formation of ZnO nanoparticles [98, 99].
UV or even visible light radiation causes some negative effects on textiles and polymers such as photo shading of dyed fabric, reduction of mechanical properties, and flaking and photo yellowing in wool fabrics. Therefore, using inorganic nanostructures can postpone these effects on textile fabric. For example, wool textiles have the lowest photo stability compared to other types of fibers, such as cotton or synthetic fibers. Therefore, light irradiation can cause photo yellowing on wool fabrics [100, 101]. Inorganic metal oxide nanoparticles such as TiO2, ZnO, and Al2O3 delay of photo yellowing in wool textiles [102, 103]. It has been demonstrated that UV protection and flame retardancy properties on textile fabrics result in applying Mg–Al nano layered double hydroxide. In other words, Barik et al. claimed that good UV protection can be achieved together with both higher mechanical
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 29
strength and flame retardant property at higher stiffness due to release of bound water and metal oxide residue through igniting [104].
A novel approach for making UV-protective textile is the use of nanofibers as a protective mat on fabric. Embedding of UV protective nanoparticles in the nanofibers can have a major synergistic effect on UV protection properties of a fibrous structure. Several studies have been carried on for the protection against UVR by nanofibers containing nanoparticles.
Lee has reported that an electrospun PU/ZnO thin layer significantly increases the UV blocking and this property enhances with increasing zinc oxide concentrations of the nanocomposite fiber web [105].
Dadvar et al. showed that the TiO2 nanofilm coated on the PAN nanofibrous mats has a considerable effect on its UV protection. They also showed that the UV protection factor (UPF) of the mats increases with decreasing nanofiber diameter [106].
In a recent research, Merati et al. produced ZnO and MWCNT nanoparticle-embedded electrospun polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofibrous mats. The results showed that the UV protection properties of the PAN/ MWCNT composite nanofiber mats of 3 g/m2 were better than that of PAN/ZnO at nanoparticle concentrations of 2.5% and higher, while the PAN/ZnO mats of ≥5% ZnO nanoparticles provided enough UV protection properties. Consequently, the composite nanofiber mats with 5% and higher ZnO nanoparticles had enough UV protection properties to cover the requirements of the Australian/New Zealand standard [107].
In addition to metal nanoparticles, carbon nanostructures can also be used to create protection against ultraviolet radiation. For example, graphene as one of the carbon materials possesses high electrical/thermal conductivity, UV blocking, and hydrophobicity [108]. However, the use of graphene in textile application because of few polar groups and weak bonding force with fibers has been limited, but graphene oxide (GO), as a functionalized derivative of graphene with a large number of polar groups that can easily bind with fibers and disperse in water, is a good candidate as a textile finishing agent [109].
Cai et al. prepared UV protective cotton fabric via the functionalization of cotton by in situ thermal reduction of GO absorbed on cotton. Conventional dip and dry approach was utilized. Both transmittance values in UVA and UVB regions decreased visibly after the cotton fabrics were coated with GO nanosheets. Compared with untreated cotton (UPF: 14.9) and GO/cotton (UPF: 20.4), reduced-GO/cotton fabrics (UPF: 35.8) possessed higher UV blocking ability [110].

sections.heading: 30 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
1.7 Water-Repellent Textiles
sections.text: Surface wettability of substrate is influenced by chemical composition and geometry of the surface. Although wettability is satisfactory in many textiles, in some applications such as clothing, furniture, protective textiles, sportswear, and automotive textiles, water repellency or in other words low wettability of the surface is desired. In this section, various physical and chemical nano finishing methods for producing water and stain-repellent textiles have been reviewed.

sections.heading: 1.7.1 Are Water-Repellent and Waterproof Finishing the Same?
sections.text:
A waterproof textile is one in which the pores, the open spaces between the yarns and fibers, are filled with substances that make integrated surface and very low air permeability. In simpler terms, water cannot pass through the waterproof fabrics; however, the surface of this type of fabric may get wet during raining.
A water-repellent textile is one in which the surface tension of the fabric has been decreased via a hydrophobic compound. The pores are not filled in this finishing process, so this type of textile is permeable to air and water vapor. Water tends to form droplets on a water-repellent fabric. The tendency of textiles to resist wetting is revealed by measuring the contact angle between water and substrate.
The size of angle reveals the repellency of the textile. When the contact angle is less than 90 degrees, the fabric is wettable. When the angle is above 90 degrees, the fabric is repellent or non-wettable (Figure 1.12) [111]. Various hydrophobic compounds such as waxes, petroleum-like molecules, soaps of polyvalent metals containing long-chain hydrocarbons, and compounds with low surface tension like fluorocarbons are used in order to produce water-repellent fabrics. Surface tensions and contact angles of polymers, which are used in textile finishing, are mentioned in Table 1.3.
In addition to the chemical finishing, water repellency is created on the fabric due to the surface roughness. An uneven surface compared to a flat
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 31
surface with the same chemical structure usually shows a higher contact angle. The presence of roughness in micro/nano scale can lead to the super hydrophobic textiles with contact angle about 160 degrees.
Both surface-free energy and surface roughness are critical factors for wettability. As a natural sample with superhydrophobic performance, lotus leaves and insect wings are made up of micro/nano-scale structure. In many researches, nanoparticles were added to the surface of a substrate to change the surface tension or surface roughness by chemical and physical methods such as in situ synthesis, anodic oxidation, electrodeposition, chemical etching, plasma etching, laser treatment, electrospinning, chemical vapor deposition, sol–gel processing, spray-coating, etc. [113, 114].

sections.heading: 1.7.2 Plasma Treatment
sections.text:
Plasma is ionized gas consisting of a mixture of free electrons, ions, and neutral atoms (depending on the degree of ionization) and is formed when sufficient energy is put into a gas. Under laboratory conditions, ionized gas is generated by using high electric fields, known as cold plasma or electric discharge. Ionized molecules with high energy can be bombarded on the surface of a given substrate. Most of the chemistry occurs on the surfaces within the reactor due to the high-energy ion bombardment. High-energy ions cause relatively unselective fragmentation of the surface-adsorbed species and a deposition or etching process results, depending on the power and molecules involved [115].
Low pressure plasma processes have been widely utilized for the modification of surface properties of natural and synthetic textiles. The surface

sections.heading: 32 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
properties, which depend on the feeding gas, input power, pressure, electrode geometry, and other operating conditions, allow to obtain etching, grafting, cros–s-linking and deposition with the same experimental apparatus [116]. Several research groups investigated the hydrophobicity of polymers and textiles using plasmas containing fluorocompounds such as tetrafluromethane [117], hexafluoroethane [118], hexaflouropropane [119], etc. Small molecules such as CF4 or CF6 as plasma additives can form short polymer chains hanging on the treated fabric surface. So despite their good initial hydrophobicity (contact angle > 120 degrees), they do not have acceptable washing or dry-cleaning fastness [120].
In order to improve water repellency and anti-stain characteristic of PET textiles, De Vietro et al. used plasma enhanced-chemical vapor deposition (PE-CVD) with a large fluorinated molecule for depositing a 100 nm thick layer with F/C ratio higher than 1.4 on textile and obtained a water contact angle around 150 degrees and oil contact angle around 120 degrees. The obtained fabrics were wear resistant, particularly if they were modified at high value of input power [121].
In another research by the surface of polypropylene fabric, samples were treated with hexamethyle disiloxane (HMDSO) to produce inorganic protective layers to reduce wettability. All HMDSO plasma-treated fabrics showed a significant decrease in demand wettability (water uptake) and a significant increase in contact angle values [122].
Hegemann used plasma treatment as a method to produce strain-repellent polyester fabric. The plasma activation in a low-pressure RF discharge with Ar/O2 was found to support a subsequent wet chemical fluorocarbon impregnation of a densely woven PET fabric and a PET knit showing a multi-layer, open structure. The plasma process that first leads to a more wettable surface, thus enabled enhanced oil repellency at a reduced film thickness in the sub-micron range leaving the touch and the optic of textile fabrics unaffected [123].
Acrylic fabrics were processed with an RF atmospheric pressure plasma generator and afterward a fluorocarbon finish was applied through a traditional pad-dry-cure method. Two gas mixtures were tested (helium and helium/oxygen) with different plasma treatment times. The aging of the finishing was simulated through repeated accelerated laundry cycles. The water and oil repellencies were measured through standard test methods. While the initial water and oil repellency did not change, the plasma treatment improved the durability of the finish after artificial aging. The results presented in this research confirmed the benefit of applying an atmospheric plasma treatment as a preparation step for standard water and oil repellency finishing of acrylic fabrics. Although the repellency
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 33
grade was not affected immediately after the chemical application, the improvement in durability has been shown at long-term usage. After artificially aging, plasma pre-treated fabrics decreased their performance more slowly than the untreated and this gap has been quantitatively demonstrated [124].
The atomic layer deposition (ALD) technique, similar to chemical vapor deposition (CVD), is a chemical process to deposit a thin layer or film by sequential use of a gas. Al2O3 and SiO2 coatings deposited on cellulosebased materials have been reported to function as gas and vapor barriers [125]. Cotton fibers were modified with ZnO to make them conductive [126]. In the ALD process, a metal organic precursor (e.g., bis (diethylamido) silane, trimethylaluminium, and diethyl zinc) and a reactant (e.g., water) are sequentially exposed to a surface desired to be modified, resulting in a complementary sequence of self-limiting reactions. ALD allows preparation of dense and pin-hole free inorganic films. ALD is expected to be a promising method to produce super-hydrophobic surfaces with topography control [127].

sections.heading: 1.7.3 Electrospinning
sections.text:
Electrospinning, as an effective technique to produce nanofibers, provides a mat of nano fibers with effective nanostructured roughness. Electrospinning of nanofibers with N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as a solvent for the polyacrylonitrile (PAN) polymer, was performed in order to compare it with a well-known commercial protective multi-layered fabric, Gortex™. It could be concluded that using the nanofiber membranes, instead of coating material (such as PTFE), presented acceptable waterrepellent properties and water vapor permeability behavior [128].
In order to simulate the “lotus effect” in nature, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), polyvinylidene fluoride/polyethylene glycol (PVDF/PEG), and polyvinylidene fluoride/polyethylene glycol/silicon dioxide (PVDF/PEG/ SiO2) nanofiber fabrics are fabricated through electrospinning and weaving technology. Hydrolyzing PEG and doping with SiO2 nanoparticles on a hierarchical nanofiber structure in the PVDF/PEG and PVDF/PEG/SiO2 nanofiber were performed. The results showed that the fiber structure of the PVDF/PEG composite nanofiber doped with SiO2 nanoparticles after water scrubbing was composed of balls, which are formed by embedding the SiO2 nanoparticles in the polymer, similar to the “small thorn” on the “lotus hill” because of the embossment of SiO2 nanoparticles on the “ball” surface. The PVDF/PEG/SiO2 nanofiber fabric exhibits super hydrophobicity with a water contact angle of 173.2 degrees [129].

sections.heading: 34 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: Cakir et al. used electrospinning for coating of cotton fabric surface with the polyurethane/silica hybrid solutions. In this study, PU/silica hybrid solutions were prepared by the sol–gel method. Coating of the solution onto the fabric surface as a thin layer was carried out using an electrospinning process combined with a UV curing step. This thin layer cannot be obtained by dip-coating or other textile finishing methods. The innovative method of this study is to choose the electrospinning process to obtain a very thin coating layer instead of nanofibers onto just one surface of the fabric with the combination of UV-curing. Thus, the other surface of the fabric remains uncoated without any clothing comfort loss. Furthermore, during the electrospinning process, with the help of a continuous UV radiation, a well and deeply crosslinked coating layer can be obtained on the fabric surface. The effect of fluorinated silane-terminated urethane on the water-repellency was investigated by contact angle measurements. Water-repellency was evaluated by contact angle measurements. A sample that contained 50% inorganic part showed a contact angle of 154.5 degrees. After the domestic laundering step, this contact angle value decreased to 137 degrees because of the surfactant residue of the detergent [130].

sections.heading: 1.7.4 Pulsed Laser Deposition
sections.text:
Pulsed laser deposition (PLD) is a highly versatile tool to prepare a functional thin film on textile surfaces. PLD is a dry process, very versatile, and has several advantages in the formation of thin films of functional materials. A laser is utilized as an energy source to evaporate a target material that is placed on a carousel. The laser plume deposits onto the surface of the substrate that is placed on the sample stage (Figure 1.13). Through PLD, it is possible to control the film thickness digitally at the angstrom scale. It is also possible to deposit a hetero-structure or multi-layer film whose structure differs from layer to layer by changing the ablation target appropriately. Among available organic materials, polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) has been the main target in PLD because it exhibits poor solubility in all solvents and has low surface adhesion. Note that conventional wet processes such as spin-coating methods are not applicable for the formation of thin PTFE films [127].
Deposition of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) thin films on a cotton fabric was performed via PLD at room temperature. The PTFE-coated fabric showed super hydrophobic effect by a water contact angle of 151 degrees. The presence of uniformly grown PTFE grains with a grain size of about 50–70 nm was confirmed by scanning electron microscopy micrographs [131].
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 35

sections.heading: 1.7.5 Sol–Gel Technique
sections.text:
The sol–gel technique is an effective and easy method for depositing coating onto the textile substrate in order to prepare water-repellent property. Large deposition area, uniform deposition on substrates with different shapes, and time saving are the main advantages of this finishing method. Yin and Wang prepared a water-repellent cotton fabric via coating hybrid SiO2/hexadecyltrimethoxysilane (HTEOS)/γ-chloropropyltriethoxysilane (CPTS) sol. Despite the hydrophilic effect of cotton fabric because of massive hydroxyl groups on the surface of fibers, the contact angle of the treated fabric increased to 139.8 degrees. During this finishing process, the Si-O-Si chains via dehydrating and condensation reactions were deposited on the cotton surface and most of the OH groups on cellulose fabric were blocked by the hybrid coating. Silica nanoparticles caused a rough microsurface (mean roughness was about 16.4 nm and the root mean square was 21.1 nm) with a low surface energy and good hydrophobic water repellency [133].
Onar et al. obtained water- and oil-repellency properties for cotton fabrics by using the sol–gel process. To achieve this aim, they treated cotton fabrics by using the sol-gel process, with tetra ethylorthosilicate (TEOS), tridecafluorooctyl triethoxysilane (TDFOES), hexadecyltrimethoxysilane (HDMS), vinyltrimethoxysilane (VTEO), phenyltriethoxysilane (FES), 3-aminopropyl trimethoxysilane (AMMO), glycidyloxypropyltriethoxysilane (GLYEO), zirconium (IV) acetylacetonate (zrA), and titanium (IV) isopropoxide (TIPT) as precursors. It was found by using a spray test that fabric samples treated by nanosols have excellent water-repellency properties (90–100), while untreated fabric has hydrophilic properties. The fabric samples treated with nanosols containing TDFOES, HDMS, VTEO, ZrA,

sections.heading: 36 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
and TIPT as precursors have good water-repellency properties (90–100). However, the fabric samples treated with nanosols containing FES, AMMO, and GLYEO as precursors have relatively low water-repellency properties (70–80). The highest contact angle values were obtained for samples containing TDFOES and HDMS as precursors after washing [134].
In another research, surfaces of cotton, polyester (PES), and polyamide (PA) fabrics have been modified by the sol–gel process in order to achieve silica-based hybrid coatings onto the fibers for enhancing their water repellency, thermal stability, and mechanical properties. In order to achieve such a hybrid coating onto textile fabrics, a chloropropyltriethoxysilane (CPTS) precursor was utilized and hydrolyzed in the presence of hydrochloric acid (HCl) as a catalyst to form reactive silanol groups by replacing some ethoxy groups (-OC2H5) of CPTS by hydroxyl (–OH) groups. In the subsequent reaction of condensation, hydroxyl groups reacted between each other or with the textile fibers leading respectively to siloxane bonds (Si–O–Si) or covalent bonds (Si–O–C) in the case of cotton and hydrogen bond in cases of PES and PA. Regardless of the type of textile, the sol– gel-treated samples exhibit a hydrophobic surface in addition to efficient water-repellent properties. The best results were achieved with the sol containing the highest CPTS concentration whatever the impregnation time of the textiles [135].
