sections.heading: 1.7.6 Dendrimer
sections.text:
Dendrimers are repetitively branched macromolecules with a threedimensional structure and their repellency effect depends on build-up crystal structures in a nanostructure (Figure 1.14). Good water repellency can be obtained via using dendrimers and combination of dendrimers with fluorocarbon polymers in order to force them into a more ordered structure leading to self-organization of the fluoro polymers on the outer layer of the textile [136, 137].
The repellency effect of dendrimers is based on their forming nano-sized crystalline structures that impart wash resistance through water repellency and high abrasion resistance. Sancaktaroğlu investigated changes in water and oil repellency values after treating cotton and cotton/polyester fabrics with products containing a dendrimer, a fluorocarbon, and a dendrimer– fluorocarbon combination. The dendrimer–fluorocarbon treatment gave the best oil and water repellency effect [138].
Namlıgöz et al. applied polymeric dendrimer-containing fluorocarbon, nano-sized fluorocarbon (FC) polymer, nano-silica acid, and conventional agents (e.g., a paraffin emulsion containing zirconium salt and a
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 37
conventional fluorocarbon compound) to cotton fabrics. Water repellency results revealed new chemicals such as the polymeric dendrimer containing FC and the FC nanomolecule had better results than conventional ones in terms of performance and washing resistance. Stain release results for dirty motor oil and olive oil soiling clearly showed that especially the polymeric dendrimer containing FC, the FC nanomolecule, and the conventional FC compound had better results than other samples. When comparing the stain repellency performances of all the chemicals for tea soiling, they had similar and good results for coffee soiling without paraffin emulsion containing zirconium salt and nano-silica. The performances of all the chemicals were dependent on the concentration [140].
Atav et al. applied dendrimer, fluorocarbon, and dendrimer–fluorocarbon to undyed woven cotton fabrics using the pad-dry-cure method. The water repellency of the treated cotton fabrics tested in this study gave the following results: dendrimer-fluorocarbon treated > fluorocarbon treated > dendrimer treated. The optimal application conditions of the fluorocarbon and dendrimer–fluorocarbon-treated fabrics were 60 g/L of the treatment agent at 160 °C for 2 min and 60 g/L of treatment agent at 140 °C for 3 min, respectively. These treated fabrics gave water repellency values of 100 that could be maintained even after 10 successive wash cycles. The dendrimer-treated fabric gave a water repellency value of 50 after

sections.heading: 38 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: 10 washings, after 60 g/L of the treatment agent was applied. For the dendrimer–fluorocarbon-treated fabric, less treatment agent (40 g/L instead of 60 g/L) was sufficient for obtaining high water repellency values resistant to 10 wash cycles if ironing was applied between each successive wash cycle [138].

sections.heading: 1.7.7 Carbon Nanotube
sections.text: Another possibility to prepare water-repellent textile is employing CNTs with a long structure shape. However, it is difficult to grow CNT arrays on common textiles due to van der waals forces of CNTs bundles. The assembly of CNTs on the fabric surface can lead to create a lotus-like leaf surface at the nanoscale. Liu et al. showed that cotton fabric with perfect water absorbability, after surface grafting with CNTs-poly-butylacrylate composite via dip-dry-cure finishing method, showed super hydrophobic effect with water contact angle larger than 150 degrees (Figure 1.15) [139].

sections.heading: 1.8 Self-Cleaning Textiles
sections.text:
One of the new intelligent textile products, which attract many researchers, is self-cleaning textiles. The development of self-cleaning textiles can extend the applications of the routine textiles, which have been used for a long time. One of the benefits of these products is their ability to do the self-cleaning process without any need to common laundering methods. In addition, the self-cleaning properties of textiles can increase the durability of the fabric [141].
In recent years, several scientists studied the modification of innovative textiles with new properties. Some of these properties such as the selfcleaning characteristic of textiles are inspired from nature.
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 39
There are two approaches for self-cleaning finishing of textiles.
In the first approach, a super hydrophobic surface is provided for the textile, which has the self-cleaning properties. In the second approach, some nanoparticles such as titanium oxide are used to cover the textile fabric in nano scale. These nanoparticles can decompose the stains and dirt on the textile fabric in the presence of water, oxygen, and sunlight [142].

sections.heading: 1.8.1 Self-Cleaning and Superhydrophobic Surfaces
sections.text:
For the preparation of superhydrophobic surfaces or films, the combination of surface roughness and low surface energy is required. From a viewpoint of surface roughness, hydrophobicity is competitive with its transparency because surface roughness becomes a scattering source of light. Thus, the precise control of roughness is required to satisfy both hydrophobicity and transparency. We have recently succeeded in developing a new process to prepare transparent superhydrophobic boehmite (A1OOH) or silica (SiO2) films by using aluminum acetylacetonate (Al (C5H7O2)3, sublimation temperature 193 °C) as a sublimation material. Either the boehmite or the silica film is roughened by the sublimation of aluminum acetylacetonate after calcination. Then, transparent superhydrophobic films are obtained by subsequent coating of (fluoroalkyl)silane [143].
The self-cleaning properties of the textiles can be obtained via chemical and geometric modification of the surface. As a result, adhesion of dirt particles can be dramatically reduced and a real self-cleaning effect can be achieved. The effective surface contact area for dirt particles is extremely minimized by the surface structure and thus the adhesion will be very low.
In a rough surface, the adhesion energy of the particle to the solid surface is very low which is because of the roughness of the surface and small contact area. Consequently, dirt particles from a superhydrophobic surface are completely removed, in contrast to a smooth hydrophobic surface where the energy is higher allowing only for the relocation of particles. For a smooth surface, the adhesion energy between the particle and the solid surface is relatively higher than between the particle and the water drop.

sections.heading: 1.8.1.1 Natural Superhydrophobic Surfaces
sections.text: There are almost 200 types of different natural super hydrophobic surfaces, which have self-cleaning properties due to either having specific chemicals on their surface or a special morphology [144].

sections.heading: 40 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
As mentioned earlier, scientists are trying to make use of the natural phenomenon to overcome the limitations of textiles. As an example, the use of textiles is limited due to their soiling and wetting behavior in many applications. That is why textiles are improved with a variety of treatments to meet the needs of the end users. Recently, several products have been invented that make use of the Lotus Effect and implement self-cleaning properties to a textile surface. This achievement can lead to a significant reduction in the cleaning requirement of such surfaces.
Using an efficient method, nature can achieve the self-cleaning properties, which has been perfectly realized on the leaves of the lotus plant. Besides this species, self-cleaning properties can be found on a variety of other biological surfaces, such as cabbage, reed, and nasturtium. The main function of nanostructured superhydrophobic surfaces in nature is probably the protection against pathogenic organic contamination such as bacteria or spores [145].
Scientists have fabricated superhydrophobic textiles by creating surface roughness by using low surface energy materials inspired by the self-cleaning properties of lotus leaves. These materials include organic silanes, fluorinated silanes, alkyl amines, and silicates [146]. Popular surface modification methods include wet chemical reactions, self-assembly and sol–gel, layer-by-layer deposition, polymerization reactions, colloidal template techniques, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), plasma treatment, and electrospinning [147].
The wetting behavior of the surfaces is determined by the measurement of the static contact angle of the water droplet with the surface. The water contact angle with the surface can show the hydrophobicity or hydrophilicity of the surface, which plays an important role in achieving the selfcleaning properties of the surface [148].
Although some chemicals such as fluorocarbons can help scientists to achieve the contact angle of 120 degrees, these surfaces do not fit in the self-cleaning category of textiles [149].

sections.heading: 1.8.2 Superhydrophobic Finishing of the Textiles
sections.text:
Hydrophobicity of the textiles had been an important issue since more than 50 years ago. However, with the improvement in science and technology especially nanotechnology, scientists could achieve super hydrophobic textiles with self-cleaning properties.
Super hydrophobicity of the textiles can be obtained via using hydrogels, nano composites, and other nano structures. These treatments can be applied via different methods onto textiles. These methods can include
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 41
simple ways such as padding, spraying, and surface coating to the more complex methods such as using nano structures, nano particles, nano wires, CNTs, and oxides of Zn and Ag [150].
The surface of textiles is different from other materials such as glass or metal plates in terms of flexibility and roughness. The roughness of the surface of the textiles makes it possible to have a super hydrophobic fabric via creating nano scale roughness.
Scientist suggests two methods for obtaining super hydrophobic textiles:
Making roughness on the surface of the fabric using low surface energy materials Modification of a rough surface using low surface energy materials [151].
The important issue in the self-cleaning finishing of textiles is not only the creation of a super hydrophobic surface, but also maintaining the induced properties for a long time [152].
In order to fabricate the cotton fabric with super hydrophobicity, scientists suggest using chemicals such as metals, silanes, and some methods such as coating with gas and layer-by-layer finishing. Using some chemicals such as silver and zinc oxides can provide some other properties such as being antibacterial and conductive as well as super hydrophobicity.
Some methods for the production of self-cleaning textiles are represented in Table 1.4.

sections.heading: 1.8.3 Modification of Textiles Using Photoactive Coatings
sections.text:
Recent researches have shown that via optical decomposition of organic substance using semi-conductive metals, self-cleaning surfaces can be obtained [153].
TiO2 is one of the best candidates for a photocatalytic application. Nanosized TiO2 particles show high photocatalytic activity because they have a relatively large surface area per unit mass and volume, which facilitates the diffusion of the surface-generated charge carriers under light irradiation. Coating of textiles with TiO2 has drawn attention of researchers due to its advantages such as cost saving, chemically stable, non-toxicity, and biocompatibility.
Titanium dioxide is used in self-cleaning of textiles with two approaches:
Photocatalysis oxidation Super hydrophilicity properties.

sections.heading: 42 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
When the surface coated with TiO2 is exposed to solar radiation, stimulated radicals on the surface of the textile can decompose organic substances such as dirt, stains, bacteria, and other materials to carbon dioxide and water [153].
Another approach is using TiO2 with SiO2, which shows great hydrophilicity when exposed to sunlight. In this situation, some of the oxygen molecules leave the surface and water molecules fill the empty positions. As a result, the surface is coated with a water coating, which can clean it continuously. This effect can remain on the surface of the textile until a couple of days after the sun exposure [142]. The synergic effect of using TiO2 via photocatalysis effect and super hydrophilicity makes it an appropriate material for using it in self-cleaning products.
In one of the studies, TiO2 nano particles and their derivatives were used to produce a transparent superhydrophobic surface. The results demonstrate that microstructure and surface roughness of the films were changed with increasing TiO2 concentration, which attributed the size difference of the starting materials. Also the contact angles of the different films are also increased and the contact angle of the film containing 2 wt % TiO2 was higher than 140 degrees [154].
In spite of numerous studies in the field of self-cleaning and super hydrophobic textiles, there are still some challenges relating to their short lifetime and fragile structures. Another problem is the tendency of these surfaces absorbing some types of dirt such as oily substances. Using some metal oxides such as titanium in comparison to superhydrophobic surfaces can provide a more durable and stable finishing on the textile fabric. Some
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 43
other properties such as antibacterial, UV protective, and anti-odor surfaces can be obtained via using TiO2.
In several studies, fibers are usually changes to a rough surface with nanostructures, such as nanoparticles, which face the issues to strengthen the interfacial interaction between the nanostructures and the substrate for application-oriented superhydrophobic surfaces. Alternatively, surface roughness could also be created directly from the bulk materials at the surface, resulting in hierarchical structures monolithic with the bulk substrate. The main advantage of this method is that these roughening structures possess strong adherence and mechanical stability [155, 156].
In one of the studies, PET fibers were roughened through chemical etching at the surface and durable superhydrophobic textiles could be prepared by following diffusion of fluoroalkylsilane into the fibers. However, diffusion of hydrophobic alkylsilanes into fibers shows dependence on specific equipment and conditions. It has also been suggested that some fluorochemicals have potential risks to human health and the environment [157].
In another study, the combination of a photoactive agent such as TiO2 and a superhydrophobic agent such as SiO2 was used to obtain the photocatalytic self-cleaning property on fluorine-free superhydrophobic cotton fabrics. The cotton fabrics coated with TiO2–SiO2 composite particles exhibit superhydrophobicity with a water contact angle of 160.5 degrees [158].

sections.heading: 1.9 Flame-Retardant Textiles
sections.text:
Along with the rising trend of stringent fire safety regulations, demands for reduction in the fire hazards caused by highly combustible materials such as textiles and polymers have become a matter of significant importance. Therefore, numerous attempts have been made to improve the flameretardant properties of textiles for a variety of applications. 
Natural fibers especially cellulosic structures can ignite fast and may cause a fire. In order to improve self-extinguishing of these fibers, researchers developed flame-retardant agents for finishing of fabric. Indeed, flameretardant finishing improved the resistance of the fabric against igniting. Furthermore, the flame spread rate decreased as a result of using flameretardant finishing.
Another method was developing synthetic fibers to produce fire resistance types of regular fibers besides developing inherently flame- and ignition-resistant fibers created by aromatic structured polymeric chains such as aramids and the poly(meta-aramid) fiber Nomex (Du Pont). This was followed by the production of poly (para-aramid) fiber.

sections.heading: 44 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
Kevlar (Du Pont), which has great modulus and tenacity, in addition to its great heat and fire resistance [159]. Lastly, some modacrylic and flame-retardant viscose fibers were developed for inherently fire-retardant fabrics. These fibers were usually used for firefighting clothes and antiflash arc work wears. Based on the type of flame-retardant agent, there are different flame-retardant mechanisms which contain:
Suppression of thermal decomposition by endothermic reaction (hydrated metal compounds), Dilution of decomposition products by releasing inert gas (nitrogen-based compounds) Trapping of free radicals in oxidation field (halogen-based compounds) Formation of surface layer to block heat and suppress diffusion of decomposition products (phosphorus-based compounds) [160].

sections.heading: 1.9.1 Flame-Retardant Finishing Agents
sections.text:
Although active halogen compounds were almost used before to obtain fabric flame retardancy, halogenated flame retardants have been found having significant disadvantages for their toxic and corrosive properties [161]. In fact, halogen-based compounds are prone to cause incomplete combustion due to the mechanism of trapping free radicals and thus to generate a large amount of smoke [160]. Furthermore, some combustion products such as furans and dioxins cause some serious health effects and environmental risks. Therefore, researchers have developed halogen-free flame-retardant agents for fabric finishing. Flame-retardant agents, containing phosphorus, boron, nitrogen, silicon, and other nanostructures, have been investigated to develop the flame resistance of fabrics and polymers [161]. Among different halogen-free flame retardants, phosphorus-based agents show high flame-retardant properties. However, these compounds usually have low water resistance to cause significant reductions in insulation properties and appearance in high temperatures and high humidity [160]. Therefore, using non-halogen and non-phosphorous based flame retardant agents in different applications is preferred.
There are various nanostructured materials with fire-retardant features. In fact, nanostructures have been recently used to improve flame-retardant property of fibers by melt spinning polymer/nanoparticles or a combination of phosphorous material/nanoparticles through finishing treatments.
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 45
In this section, some flame-retardant nanomaterials used in textile finishing are described.
1.9.1.1 Flame-Retardant Nanostructures 1.9.1.1.1 Nano Clay Clay exists naturally in the form of nanoscale platelets, stacked up to form particles about few microns. Most of the beneficial properties of clay as a filler material are only realized when the particles are dispersed and exfoliated to separate the individual nanoscale layers. So, exfoliated nano clays can exhibit excellent flame-retardant properties [162]. The most commonly used layered silicate in polymer nanocomposites is MMT, which has encouraged much improvement in the mechanical, thermal, flammability, and barrier properties of polymers owing to its high aspect ratio, large surface area, extraordinary modulus, and nano-scale dispersion [163].
Nano clay particles play a vital role in flame-retardant textile coating. However, the exact mechanism of the combustion inhibition caused by nanoclays is not yet known but it seems that when the polymer matrix is burned and gasified during combustion, the incorporated nanoclays accumulate at the surface and act as a barrier to oxygen diffusion. So, the burning process is slowed down. Also, the nano clays act as a barrier to flame propagation and promote the formation of chars but they have no effect on the after-flaming properties [164].
As mentioned earlier, nano clays containing polar functional groups such as OH, -NH- or NH2 will lead to nano dispersion in polar and hydrogen-bonded polymers, for example, polyamides 6 and 6.6 and polyvinyl and polyacrylic and can be used for flame retardancy of fiber and fabric back coating finishing. Although cotton fibers have desirable characteristics such as comfort, good mechanical properties, biodegradability, and excellent wearing properties, it has some disadvantages such as high flammability and hydrophilicity. These properties are the reason for the limitations of the application of natural textiles in some branches such as workwear garments [165]. So, flame-retardant finishing on cotton fibers in some applications is necessary.
There are many researches about using clay nanoparticles as a flame retardant. For example, in order to fabricate flame-retardant finishing with different add-on values on cotton fabrics, the organosilicon-functionalized cyclotriphosphazene N3P3 [NH (CH2)3Si (OC2H5)3]6) was synthesized and applied to the cotton fabrics through a pad-dry-cure process. The LOI value increased from 20.5 to 24.5 and excellent flame retardancy was found durable after 30 cycles of the washing process [166]. Uddin et al. used the

sections.heading: 46 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
two types of local clay samples to impart the flame-retardant effects on bleached cotton fabric. It was found that the two types of clays used can enhance the flame retardancy of finished fabric and significant amount of char was obtainable with increasing clay concentration [167]. Keshin et al. used nanoclay on 100% greige and bleached pure conventional cotton fabrics by finishing process. They showed that by utilizing nanoclay with a proper application process, it is possible to impart flame-retardant characteristics to conventional cotton fabric samples [168]. A cotton/MMT nanocomposite was prepared by Delhom et al. by the addition of pretreated nano clay and cotton to 4-methylmorpholine-N-oxide as a cotton solvent. The nanocomposites composed of higher than 7 wt% nano clay showed char yield about 30 wt% [163].
The improvement of flame-retardant properties in polyamide/nano clay textile nanocomposites was also reported in the literature. Wu et al. proposed flame-retardant polyamide 6/nano clay/intumescent nanocomposite fibers through the electrospinning method. Based on the transmission electron microscopy results, there was good dispersion and exfoliation of nano clay platelets within individual nanofibers. The degradation temperature of nanocomposite samples was lower than pristine nylon 6 samples. Moreover, the difference in residual char weight after decomposition was significant [169].
1.9.1.1.2 Layered Double Hydroxide Layered double hydroxide (LDH) known as brucite-like compound is anextensive class of anionic clays with divalent and trivalent metallic cations andanions. Since the range of metals and anions which can be usedin the  LDH structure is quite extensive, the LDH properties are controllable [163].
In Pan et al.’s research, a layer-by-layer flame-retardant coating, assembled from MgAl-layered double hydroxides (MgAl-LDH) and alginate, was fabricated onto the surface of cotton fabric for reducing its flammability. The high flame-retardant ability of coated cotton fabrics is attributed to the fact that the MgAl-LDH-filled coating can form an inorganic protective layer, which can act as a barrier to heat and oxygen [170]. Also, Barik et al. applied the nano-MgAl-layered double hydroxide on the cotton fabric for enhancing flame retardancy, mechanical, and UV protection properties. It was found that the limiting oxygen index increased from 16.5 to 20.8 [104].
1.9.1.1.3 Nano Silica (SiO2) Silica nanoparticles are considered as a potential flame-retardant agent to improve flame-retardant properties of textile fabrics. Nano silica is an
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 47
environment-friendly material compared to other nanomaterials. Also, they are cheap and their chemical behavior could be easily controlled by surface modification [171]. These materials are commonly used as a fire retardant agent in different researches.
Gashti et al. prepared the cellulose fibers using a polycarboxylic acid/ hydrophobic silica nanocomposite coating with water-repellent and flame-retardant properties. The results indicated that the embedded silica nanoparticles modify the surface of fibers, increasing the thermal stability of substrate. This enhancement of thermal properties is attributed to the presence of the silica nanoparticles, which have high heat resistance, heat insulation effect, and mass transport barrier toward cotton molecular chains [172]. Also, Carosio et al. introduced a novel method to improve flame-retardant properties of textile fabric using multilayered thin films. In this work, PET fabrics were coated with silica nanoparticles using the layer-by-layer assembly method. Five bilayers of positively and negatively charged colloidal silica nanoparticles increased time to ignition and decreased heat release rate peak of PET fabric by 45% and 20%, respectively. This study demonstrates the ability to impart flame-retardant behavior using a water-based, environment-friendly protective coating [173].
1.9.1.1.4 Carbon Nanotubes Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have also been investigated as a potential flameretardant filler material. They can reduce heat release in burning materials very effectively. Despite the relative high cost of manufacture for CNTs, the high performance of CNT-based flame retardants and the low concentration required could make them useful for various applications.
It is reported that combining a low concentration of multi-wall CNTs with the nanoclay filler produces a synergistic effect that is much more effective than either component alone.
In a recent study, CNT was stabilized on a cotton fabric using a vinyl phosphonic acid monomer as a crosslinking agent and benzophenone as a catalyst through UV irradiation. The results showed that the polyvinylphosphonic/CNT nanocomposite improved the thermal stability and decreased the flammability of the substrate [174]. In a research performed by Yin et al., polyamide 6 (PA6) was melt-blended with an intumescent flame retardant (FR), multi-wall carbon nanotubes (MWNTs), and nano clay particles to produce multi-component FR-PA6 nanocomposites. The formulation combining both MWNT and clay showed the largest quantity of char residue and a synergistic effect in flame-retardant properties [175]. Dittrich et al. investigated the influence of various nano-carbon additives (5 wt%) on the flame-retardant properties of PP. Thermally reduced

sections.heading: 48 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
graphite oxide (TRGO) and multi-layer graphene (MLG250) were compared with spherical, tubular, and platelet-like carbon fillers including carbon black (CB), MWCNT, and expanded graphite (EG). According to their results, TRGO and MLG250 indicated higher flame retardation in the nanocomposites, which can be attributed to the well-exfoliated graphenes compared to the less exfoliated, micro-sized, expanded graphite or conventional spherical and tubular carbon nanoparticles [176].
1.9.1.1.5 Metal-based Nanoparticles Metal-based nanoparticles are used in textile finishing in order to improve their flame retardation. Various mechanisms have been suggested about flame-retardant properties of metallic nanoparticles. Metallic nanoparticles can act as a barrier to heat and mass transfer, restrict the mobility of the polymer chains, absorb active species such as free radicals, and modify the degradation pathway of the polymer. Following, we present some reports of the metal-based nanoparticle application [163].
El-shafei et al. performed the flame-retardant and antibacterial finishing on cellulose fabrics using TiO2 nanoparticles and chitosan phosphate. TiO2 nanoparticles were prepared by the sol–gel method using titanium tetraisopropoxide. The obtained results indicated that cotton fabric gained flame retardancy and antibacterial properties [177]. Also in a same study, Lessan et al. proposed a novel flame-retardant woven cotton fabric using sodium hypophosphite (SHP), maleic acid (MA), triethanol amine (TEA), and nano TiO2 through the pad-dry-cure method [178]. In another research based on using TiO2, Hashemikia and Montazer immobilized TiO2 nanoparticles on the surface of cotton/polyester-knitted fabrics using citric acid as a cross-linking agent and SHP as a catalyst to produce a multi-functional textile with durable flame retardation, anti-pilling, hydrophilicity, selfcleaning, antibacterial, and UV protection properties. The presence of TiO2 nanoparticles and SHP as a phosphor source increased the char residue of the fabrics by 21% [179]. It is reported in Lam et al.’s research that nano titanium dioxide was used as a co-catalyst in the flame-retardant formulation of N-methylol dimethyl-phosphonopropionamide, melamine resin, and phosphoric acid for cotton fabrics to improve the treatment effectiveness and minimize the side effects. It was found that the nano-TiO2 cocatalyst had a significant effect on decreasing the flame-spread rate [180].
In a same study, Lam et al. used zinc oxide (ZnO) nanoparticles as a co-catalyst for flame-retardant finishing on cotton fabrics. Their results showed that the flame ignited on the treated fabrics extinguished right after the removal of ignition source and by using 0.2% and 0.4% of nanoZnO as a co-catalyst, the flame spread rate of samples decreased [181].
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 49
Also, Samanta et al. applied nano-ZnO on bleached jute fabric to impart a fire-retardant finish. Nano zinc oxide was prepared from aqueous Zinc acetate by the co-precipitation method in the presence of NaOH followed by calcination at 600 °C. Then, it was applied on the jute fabric by the paddry method. The coating had reasonably good LOI values for as many as five wash cycles [182].
In another study, the LbL coating has been used to obtain the flameretardant cotton fabric by using Bio-based and phosphorus-free coating. Indeed, the flame-retardant cotton fabric was prepared by negatively charged alginate and positively charged polyethylenimine together with subsequent crosslinking of barium, nickel, and cobalt ions. Metal ions such as Cu2+, Mg2+, Ni2+, Co2+, and Ba2+ were practically used as crosslinking agents for alginate to introduce the flame-retardant properties on fabric and films. The char residues at 700 °C revealed that the added extras of barium, nickel, and cobalt metal ions enhanced thermal degradation of fabric to fabricate firm char residues and reduced the degradation rate of the matrix. Moreover, the char residue showed a superior washing durability of the LbL cotton fabric when treated by the metal ions as crosslinking agents than untreated metal ions of the LbL cotton fabric. In other words, the flame spread rate of the LbL cotton fabric treated by barium ions demonstrated 28% reduction than untreated cotton [183].
The in situ synthesis of silver and diphosphate malonate nanocomposites was used for antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus bacteria and flame-retardancy properties on cotton blend and polyester fabrics. Indeed, silver nitrate was reduced to silver nanoparticles by a reducing agent and in the presence of diphosphate malonate, which acted as a capping agent. The results showed that by increasing diphosphate malonate in the nanocomposite, the size of silver nanoparticles will increase due to the reduction properties of diphosphate malonate. Moreover, comparing the effect of diphosphate malonate and silver nanoparticles on the flame retardancy property of treated textile fabrics, by increasing the diphosphate malonate concentration in the nanocomposite, more relative flame- retardant activity was resulted than increasing the silver nanoparticle concentration in the nanocomposite. The flame-retardancy properties of textile were considerably enhanced and char layer was solid enough by increasing the diphosphate malonate concentration in the nanocomposite. Indeed, the concentration ratio between the organic phosphate and silver nanoparticles showed a vital role in the nanocomposite effect on textile fabrics. The efficient effect of diphosphate malonate on the flame-retardant property leaded to the formation of a solid char layer upon the release of phosphoric acid which catalyzed degradation of cotton fabric, following char [184].

sections.heading: 50 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: In general, the results demonstrated that most of the nanoparticles can improve the thermal stability and flame-retardant properties of the textile fabrics. The main mechanisms involved are the formation of a protective barrier layer, char promotion, and free radical trapping. Nevertheless, the extent of enhancement depends on several factors such as morphology and composition of the nanoparticle, compatibility between nanoparticle and polymer, dispersion of the nanoparticles in the polymer matrix, and migration speed of nanoparticles to the surface.

sections.heading: 1.10 Wrinkle-Resistant Fabrics
sections.text:
Cellulose fibers are the most commonly used natural fibers in the textile industry. However, one of the major disadvantages of using cellulose fiber is low dimensional stability and wrinkle resistance. Cellulose fibers such as cotton have a high water absorbency and potential to make hydrogen bonds to water molecules. Therefore, water molecules penetrate into amorphous regions of cellulose and cause local swelling of the fibers. Subsequently, the cellulose chains displace from their original positions and hydrogen bonds re-form at new locations. As a result, fabrics become wrinkled in appearance [185]. In fact, there are two theories for the mechanism of antiwrinkle finishing of cotton fabrics.
In the deposition theory, small particles of finishing agents are dispersed in the amorphous region of the fibers and form hydrogen bonds with the fiber molecules. This may restrict the movement of the molecular chains and decrease deformation of the fabrics. In the cross-linking theory, the finishing agents form covalent bonds with fiber molecules, and join the adjacent molecular chains within the fibers. This gives the recoverability improvement of the deformed fibers and increases the crease resistance [186].
According to the researches, wool and silk fabrics have good ability to resist the formation of wrinkles. However, some studies have been recorded about wrinkle-free finishing on silk fabrics. Generally, there are two different physical and chemical methods in order to apply anti-wrinkle finishing on fabrics that are shown in Figure 1.16. Physical wrinkle-reduction techniques, such as heat and pressure, are effective ways of flattening fabrics. However, their effect is not permanent and wrinkles reappear due
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 51
to a range of shear, torsion, and compressive deformation forces applied in wear. Therefore, physical methods just reduce the wrinkle formation and do not have enough potential to improve crease resistance. However, the body’s heat and humidity can relax the fabric and enhance the wrinkling of these deformational forces [187, 188].
Formaldehyde-based resins such as phenol formaldehyde, urea formaldehyde, melamine formaldehyde, and cross-linking agents such as glutaraldehyde and poly-carboxylic acid cause a significant increase in the crease-resistance properties of the textile. However, formaldehyde-based resins come with potentially dangerous side-effects and it is the main obstacle for efficient application of these types of materials [189]. Recently, using various nano materials in order to enhance the wrinkle resistance textiles has increased. In this section, different nano materials as antiwrinkle agents have been studied.

sections.heading: 1.10.1 Nanostructured Materials as Anti-Wrinkle Agents
sections.text:
In the conventional methods, in order to impart wrinkle-resistant properties to fabrics, resin was used previously. The most important drawbacks of conventional resin applications include decreasing of the strength of fiber, abrasion resistance, water absorbency, dye-ability, and breathability. To overcome the limitations of using resins, some researchers have employed nano structured materials with wrinkle-resistant features [190].
Nano materials play a vital role as a co-catalyst in anti-wrinkle finishing to promote the cross-linking between the fabric structure and the crosslinking agent. In fact, the presence of nano materials can enhance creaseresistant properties [186]. Different types of nano materials employed in the anti-wrinkle finishing process are represented in Figure 1.17.

sections.heading: 52 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
1.10.1.1 Titanium Dioxide Nanoparticles (TiO2)
sections.text:
Sodium hypophosphite (SHP) is considered as a catalyst in anti-wrinkle finishing of cotton via cross-linking compounds such as poly-carboxylic acid. However, high cost, producing shade changes, and serious environmental problems are the main drawbacks of using SHP. Recently using various co-catalysts such as titanium dioxide nanoparticles (TiO2) have been investigated in order to enhance the crease recovery finishing process. In fact, nano-TiO2 as a co-catalyst improves the finishing performance and decreases the side effects. In addition, nano-TiO2 is very stable toward high temperature and pressure. Due to its large surface area, nano-TiO2 provides sufficient number of active sites for the achievement of acceptable reaction rates [191]. On the other hand, nano TiO2 can fill the amorphous region of the cellulose, and hence, the presence of nano TiO2 inside the fiber would probably restrict the molecular movement of cellulose [192].
Recent studies have discussed the application of nano-sized TiO2 in textile finishing such as wrinkle-freeness applications. For example, Lam et al. evaluated the wrinkle-resistant property of cotton specimens treated by butane tetra-carboxylic acid (BTCA) and catalyzed by SHP in the presence of nano-TiO2. It was found that the addition of nano-TiO2 could further enhance the wrinkle resistance of BTCA/SHP-treated cotton fabrics [191]. In a same study, Yuen et al. used nano-TiO2 as a co-catalyst for improving wrinkle-resistance of cotton fabric in the presence of BTCA and SHP and the obtained results were successful in crease resistance [193]. Hezavehi et al. evaluated the wrinkle-resistant properties of cotton fabrics dyed by
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 53
Direct Blue 2B in the presence and absence of TiO2 nanoparticles. Also, the addition of BTCA can significantly enhance the crease resistance of fabrics, especially in the presence of SHP and nano-TiO2 as a co-catalyst. In fact, TiO2 nanoparticles restrict the molecular movement of cellulose chains, and leading to the enhancement of crease resistance of the samples. However, it seems that adding TiO2 in the absence of BTCA causes better wrinkle-resistant property, but is not considerable [186]. Also, Karthik et al. performed the non-formaldehyde wrinkle-resistant finishing of cotton fabrics using citric acid as a cross-linking agent and SHP as a catalyst together with nano-TiO2 as a co-catalyst compound. Based on the results, it was concluded that 10% CA, 10% SHP, and 0.1% nano-TiO2 were the optimum concentrations required to enhance wrinkle-resistant properties without any negative effect on the other physical features of the treated cotton fabrics [194]. Nazari et al. optimized the resistance of bleached cotton fabric against creasing by using nano-TiO2, sodium hypophosphite, and two different poly-carboxylic acids. Figure 1.18 represents the formation of linkages between BCTA/cellulose chains and BCTA/nano-TiO2. The presence of nano-TiO2 enhances the cross-linking between cellulose chain and cross linker. It has a positive effect on improving crease recovery angle, as well [195].
In another research, Bombyx mori silk was also treated with TiO2 nanoparticles in chitosan by cross-linking reactions of citric acid and maleic anhydride. Based on the results, dry and wet crease recovery angles

sections.heading: 54 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: of the treated silk were 267 degrees and 250 degrees compared to the untreated fabric of 235 degrees and 178 degrees, respectively [185].

sections.heading: 1.10.1.2 Silver Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Silver nanoparticles (Ag) have received a considerable attention due to their chemical and physical properties. Silver nanoparticles can enter inside the polymer molecules and act as filler because of their small size. This formed chemical cross-linking causes an improvement in the crease recovery angle [196].
In situ synthesis of Ag nanoparticles on the cotton fabric using silver nitrate (AgNO3) with a reducing agent and stabilizer citric acid/sodium hypophosphite has been reported in different researches in order to improve wrinkle resistance properties. Also, Hebeish et al. synthesized silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) via a green method and treated the cotton fabric by AgNPs, 1,2,3,4-butane tetracarboxylic acid (BTCA) and sodium hypophosphite (SHP) as a catalyst. The obtained results show that the treated fabric has a significant crease recovery angle [197]. Montazer et al. applied the colloidal nano silver on the surface of cotton fabric and stabilized using BTCA. Their results showed that the winkle recovery angle of finished samples increased [198].

sections.heading: 1.10.1.3 Silica Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Silica nanoparticles (SiO2) penetrate easily into the interior of the cotton fiber and adhere more tightly to the fiber structure. Therefore, a covalent bond is formed between the hydroxyl group of cellulose and –Si–OH in silica nanoparticles. In fact, the thermodynamic affinity of fibers to the formation the non-covalent interactions such as dipolar–dipolar and hydrogen bond is the key factor for the adhesion of silica nanoparticles. The Si–O–cellulose covalent bonds in the treated fabrics make less contribution toward the adhesion of particles. Also, the cellulose in cotton fabric plays a decisive role in the intensity of the covalent bond between the hydroxyl group of cellulose and –Si–OH in silica nanoparticles. The bond formation can promote the wrinkle resistance property of the cotton fabrics. Also, it was observed that the increase of concentration of silica nanoparticles contributes more to the increase of the crease recovery angle of the fabric due to restriction of the molecular movement in the fiber structure [192].
Nallathambi et al. reported an efficient anti-wrinkle finishing method using silica nanoparticles, BTCA and SHP. Increasing the concentration of SiO2 nanoparticles causes improved wrinkle recovery angle and strength
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 55
in fabric [192]. In another research, SiO2 nanoparticles and maleic anhydrate as a catalyst have been applied to silk fabric in order to improve wrinkle resistance [185]. Also, in a patent, Doneva et al. prepared a dispersion consisting of suitable inorganic nanoparticles like silica, titania, alumina, zinc oxide, and the mixed oxides class such as ITO (indium-tin oxide) in order to synthesis a silicone-based resin as an anti-wrinkle agent. The average particle size of dispersion was in the range of 10 to 50 nm and the amount of dispersion deposited on the fabric was between 0.25 and 0.5 wt%. As well as the enhancement of anti-wrinkling features, the nanoparticle depending on their structure can provide additional benefits such as anti-odor, water absorbency, and so on [188]. Patel et al. synthesized the silica nanoparticles and applied to cotton fabrics by the exhaust technique. There was an improvement in the crease recovery angle, which proves that the silica nanoparticles penetrated in between the polymer chain molecules. In addition, the results showed that the crease recovery properties of fabric improve with the increase in the concentration of silica nanoparticle and were found better in the exhaust method compared to the pad-dry-cure method. From the results, it seems that the incorporation of silica nanoparticles enhances the crease recovery angle without any negative effect on the fabric hand [199].

sections.heading: 1.10.1.4 Zinc Oxide Nanoparticles
sections.text: Based on the researches, ZnO nanoparticles, SHP as the catalyst, and BTCA or succinic acid as the cross linker have a positive effect on wrinkle resistance of the cotton fabric. Also, changing the parameters such as nanoparticle concentration, catalyzer concentration, and curing temperature can influence on the enhancement of the wrinkle recovery angle. For example, Ashraf et al. used ZnO nanoparticles in the curing process with the aim to replace the conventional catalyst and to enhance the crease recovery properties on the cotton fabric [200]. Shady et al. characterized the effects of zinc oxide nanoparticles on the performance characteristics of cotton, polyester, and their blends. Generally, the improvement greatly depends on the size and concentration of ZnO nanoparticles. As the size of ZnO nanoparticles increases, the crease recovery angles of the samples improve and this confirms the positive effect of ZnO nanoparticles on the antiwrinkle properties [201]. Also, in a research performed by Farouk et al., ZnO nanoparticles-chitosan composite was prepared for the finishing of textiles. The crease-resistant angle enhancement of the composite-finished fabric suggests that ZnO nanoparticles/chitosan composite form a network hybrid matrix on the fabric [202].

sections.heading: 56 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
1.10.1.5 Carbon Nanotubes
sections.text: Intermolecular cross-link between long-chain CNT and cellulose molecular chains via a crosslinking agent impart crease resistance properties to cotton fabric. In fact, cross-linkage between CNTs and the fabric creates a network and reduces the flexibility of molecular chains. Therefore, the crease recovery angle of fabrics is increased. For example, Amini et al. used multiwall CNTs in order to increase wrinkle-free properties of cotton fabric via succinic acid as the cross-linker and SHP. The obtained results confirm the notable effect of CNTs in reducing fiber flexibility [203]. In a patent, Alimohammadi et al. used CNTs for textile production. The CNTembedded textiles are more antibacterial, conductive, crease resistant, flame retardant, thermally stable, and EM energy absorbent than raw textiles. They prepared seven cotton samples treated with a solution including the crosslinking agent, catalyst SHP, and CNT with different concentrations of 100, 250, 500, 1000, and 1500 ppm. According to their results, above a CNT concentration of 250 ppm, the crease-resistant properties of CNT-embedded cotton are better than raw cotton [204].

sections.heading: 1.10.1.6 Chitosan Nanoparticles
sections.text:
Binding cellulose and chitosan nanoparticles as a polycation via intermolecular inclusion interaction decreases the possibility of molecular chains movement, hydrogen bonds breaking, and creasing the fibers. Also, the presence of a cross-linking agent is considered as a necessary factor to obtain desirable results. Although, chitosan nanoparticles have a positive effect on crease resistance, chitosan micro particles completely cover the surface and prevent the crosslinkage between the fabric and the cross-linking agent [205]. Lu et al. prepared hydroxypropyl chitosan (HCS) nanoparticles through ion-gel technology and applied it onto Antheraea pernyi (A. perny) silk fabric in the presence of 1,2,3,4-butane tetracarboxylic acid and sodium hypophosphite by a conventional pad-dry-cure process. According to their results, treatment of A. pernyi silk fabric with HCS nanoparticles strengthened the wrinkle-resistant property [206]. In another study, Cheng et al. synthesized chitosan nanoparticles with a size distribution of 15–45 nm and a good dispersity and stability. Then, they characterized the influences of nano-chitosan on antibacterial and wrinkle-resistant performances of Mulberry silk fabrics. The results indicated that Mulberry silk fabrics treated with appropriate mass fraction of nano-chitosan have an enhanced wrinkle-resistant performance [207]. Also, Zulfiqar et al. synthesized chitosan nanoparticles (CsNPs) by using ionic gelation method and then applied it on the cotton fabric utilizing the pad-dry-cure approach.
Functional Finishing of Textiles via Nanomaterials 57
Based on the results, the higher crease resistance angle was due to the polycation nanoparticles which easily moved into the inter fiber region and bound the fibers to provide better crease recovery [208].

sections.heading: 1.11 Future Trends and Challenges of Nano-Based Textiles
sections.text:
The present status of the global textile market is based on innovations in high-tech textile products, and nanotechnology is one of the prominent driving forces, which helps the technical textiles stay ahead of the competition. The textile industry is affected by two main factors, that is, market volatility and world-wide competition. Therefore, the industry needs to enhance its capability to produce and market high quality and added value products. Recently, with dramatic growth in nanotechnology, increased volumes of engineered nanoparticles have been produced which represent the potential functional benefits in a wide range of applications by integrating into textiles. Among different types of nano materials, polymeric nanostructures, metal oxides, CNTs, clay nanoparticles, carbon black, graphite nanofibers (GNF), and others provide an unprecedented level of textile performance such as being hydrophilic and hydrophobic, antimicrobial, anti-odor, stain-resistant, anti-static, wrinkle resistant, anti-UV, and so on. These materials are transparent due to their high surface area and nanoscale dimension, and do not blur the color and brightness of the textile substrates. They improve the properties of textiles by their own unique characteristic, as well. In fact, finishing with different nano materials can convert fabrics into versatile multifunctional materials.
Regardless of positive aspects of nano materials in textile finishing, there are still a lot of items to be taken into consideration. The first issue is cost, which in some cases limit the development of nano material coating on textiles and mass production. Development of products via nano structured materials remains an expensive affair and demands R&D spending in the textile industry. On the other hand, the durability of nano-finished textiles is notable. The challenge is to ensure the fastness of nano-structured finishing agents on fabric during usage and against different factors such as washing, rubbing, light, temperature, humidity, etc. However, regardless of its prosperous future, the main challenges that still need to be resolved in today’s nano-finished textiles are as follows:
Increase the durability and maintainability of nano-based properties on textiles after repeated using cycles.

sections.heading: 58 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
Due to the very small size of nanomaterials, they can potentially expose into the human body. Also, aggregation of nanoparticles and their uncontrollable release are other serious issues which threat the environment and human health.
It is expected that the future of nano-finished textiles be surely related to bio–nano textiles. New generation of the finishing agents integrate the nanoscale structure with eco-friendly properties, which produce dramatic characteristics without harmful effects on environment and the human health.

sections.text:
