Shahid-ul-Islam and B.S. Butola (eds.) Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles, (71–112) © 2018 Scrivener Publishing LLC
2 Antimicrobial Textiles Based on Metal
and Metal Oxide Nano-particles Mangala Joshi* and Anasuya Roy
Department of Textile Technology, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, India
Abstract With the increasing surge in recent times toward better health and hygiene around the globe, considerable research attention has been focused on developing textile materials possessing antimicrobial functionality. In such times, when microbial resistance to synthetic organic compounds like drugs and antibiotics are rampantly increasing, metal and metal oxide-based inorganic nano-particles (NP) have taken a pivotal role in preparing such antimicrobial fibers and textile materials. Incorporation of antimicrobial NP, for example, NP of Ag, Cu, ZnO, Au, and titania, in fibers and fabrics via nano-coating or nano-finishing presented promising results and excellent bioactivity. These active nano-reinforced textile structures are potential candidates for application in various areas such as sportswear, upholstery, hospital curtains, surgery gowns, medical textiles, wound dressings, bandages, etc. However, research concerning its nano-toxicological impact to human health and environment is still at its infancy and has considerably been questioned its several applications. This chapter reviews the state-of-the-art NP-based antimicrobial textile fibers and fabrics, both man-made and natural with special emphasis on toxicological properties and its effect on commercial applications.
Keywords: Fibers, textiles, metal NP, antimicrobial, nano-toxicological studies
*Corresponding author: mangala@textile.iitd.ac.in

sections.heading: 72 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
2.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Textile materials provide ample ambient conditions of temperature, humidity, and nutrition for pathogenic micro-organisms to thrive and multiply on their surface and proliferate into the surrounding environment [1–3]. The exponential multiplication of micro-organisms is assisted by internal factors of the human body, such as accumulation of sweat, dead skin cells, oil secreted by sebaceous glands, as well as external parameters like dust, stains caused by spilled food and drinks, nature of finishing chemical, etc. As a consequence, imparting antimicrobial property to textile fabrics and fibers by different methods such as finishing or coating has become one of the utmost significant research field in the modern world [4–6]. The global antimicrobial finishing market is expected to rise by a compound annual growth rate of 20% to 25% as per recent market surveys and is estimated to reach 2.9 billion dollars by 2018 [7]. In addition to providing improvement in human living standards, it controls allergic reactions, lethal infections, cross-infections of microbe-transmitted diseases, and other harmful health effects [8–11]. Antimicrobial finishes on textiles prevent microbial attack in the material which is responsible for maintaining its aesthetic and functional value. Degradation of the fibers and dyes leading to loss of local color or undesirable staining is prevented along with unpleasant odor associated with bacterial colonization. Currently, antimicrobial fabrics and fibers are increasingly being used in various sectors such as protective, medical, technical and decorative, and sportswear textiles with vast application areas from hospital environment to daily household items [12–16].
Microbes are defined as a class of living micro-organisms, both unicellular and multicellular, that include bacteria, fungi, algae, virus, archaea, and protozoa [17–19]. The phyla of fungi includes yeasts (unicellular), rusts, smuts, mildews, molds, and mushrooms (multicellular). A large number of microbes co-exist in the human society with harmony, in the immediate surroundings and inside the bodies of living organisms [20– 23]. Although it is conceived that majority of microbes are pathogenic and exert harmful ill-effects on the health, in reality, majority of them are completely harmless [24–26] and some even help us in bodily functions like digestion (Escherichia coli) and preparation of nutrient-containing food such as bread (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) [27], citric acid (Aspergillus niger) [28], riboflavin (Eremothecium sp.) and even has medicinal uses such as antibiotic isolation [29]. Some bacteria do not cause fatal or highrisk diseases but are associated with unpleasant smell and overall bad hygiene [30]. The human skin itself is a home to a microbiota of diverse species ranging from bacteria and viruses to yeasts, prokaryotes, and fungi
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 73
[31]. The environment humidity (moist or dry) and the composition of the clothing enclosing the skin have a strong effect on the type of residing bacteria [32–34]. An interesting study [35] found significantly different microbiomes on different clothing fabrics. Highest malodor was observed for polyester fabrics with infestations of Micrococci, Enhydrobacter, and Propionibacterium sp. owing to inherent low moisture uptake. Cotton fabrics showed a predominant strain of Staphylococcus hominis while both the fabrics showed growth of Staphylococcus epidermidis. Wool clothing promoted growth of almost all bacteria and nylon fabrics exhibited promoted growth of Propionibacterium sp., Staphylococcus sp., and Enhydrobacter sp. The Propionibacterium sp. are mainly responsible for unpleasant odor associated with nylon socks and thrives well in most areas such as foot [36].
The present decade has witnessed frequent outbreaks of infectious diseases with increase in microbial resistance to antibiotics and drugs based on organic structures [37]. Conventionally, textiles were treated with antimicrobial formulations based on the antimicrobial property of complex organic compounds such as quaternary ammonium salts, N-halamines, halogenated phenols like triclosan, polybiguanides, etc. [38–43]. Alternatively, antimicrobial textile substrates were developed using natural extracts, biopolymers, and bio-based NP [44–49]. Depending upon the mechanism of antimicrobial action of the active agent impregnated within the textile material, the textile may be termed as “bacteriostatic” when the growth of micro-organisms is inhibited or “bacteriocidal” when the active agents impart antimicrobial action by killing the bacteria corresponding to bound and leeching types of antimicrobial agents, respectively [38].
With the advent of nano-technology, considerable research studies have focused on a new class of antimicrobials which are inorganic in nature like metal and metal oxide NP based on Ag, Cu, CuO, ZnO, and titania NP [50–54] unlike the conventionally used organic antimicrobials. These biologically active nano-materials are highly potent even at very low concentrations while having zero microbial resistance with other advantages such as multi-targeted action, unique small size, large surface-to-volume ratio, and unique physiochemical properties. Several studies are oriented toward achieving antimicrobial textile materials with incorporation of these inorganic NP that provide fast and easy functionalization with excellent effectiveness and long durability [55–62]. However, owing to their metallic nature, the NP above the threshold limit can hamper normal cell division and proliferation even in humans due to the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) which can cause inflammation and allergy along with other minor complications [63–64]. This drawback has put a leash on the everexpanding market of nano-scale-based antimicrobials. The toxicological

sections.heading: 74 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
data of these NP are elucidated primarily in water and cell media, which is a far cry from the complex in vivo environment of the human body [65–66]. Although Ag salt-based burn creams and gels are a commercial triumph, Ag NP having significantly higher affectivity face difficulty in penetrating the market due to unavailability of sufficient data confirming its non-toxic nature [67–68].
Various standard test methods, both qualitative and quantitative, are available for testing antimicrobial-finished textile fibers and fabrics. The AATCC Test Method 100: 1999 and AATCC Test Method 147: 1998 are most popular methods to test the efficacy of antimicrobial textile materials although AATCC Test Method 90: 1998 is also frequently employed. The AATCC Test Method 147: 1998, Parallel Steak method, is a fast and qualitative measurement of the antimicrobial activity in which a rectangular cut fabric sample (25 mm ´ 50 mm) is placed on a sterile nutrient agar plate parallel streaked with inoculations of Gram-positive or Gram-negative strain. The amount of bacterial growth on the petridish and on the textile after the incubation period of 18–24 h gives a qualitative method of antibacterial activity. In the AATCC Test Method 100: 1999, Colony Counting method, a swatch of fabric with a certain weight or dimension is inoculated with bacterial solution and incubated at ambient conditions. After the swatches are removed, the number of bacteria in the extract is determined using serial dilution and agar plating technique. This is an accurate quantitative test method and by far the most popular as the results are reproducible. The AATCC Test Method 90: 1998 Disk Diffusion Test is only suitable for antimicrobial fabrics that have leaching chemicals that can detach itself from the fabric and form a zone of inhibition. In this test procedure, the small swatch of fabric is placed on the center of surface-inoculated pertidish. The clear zone surrounding the sample is quantified after 18–24 h incubation period. Other test methods for antimicrobial textiles include ASTM test methods such as the ASTM E 2149 Test Method for determining the antimicrobial activity of antimicrobial agents under dynamic contact conditions, the ASTM E 2180 Test Method for determining the activity of incorporated antimicrobial agents in polymeric or hydrophobic materials, and the ASTM E 2722 Test Method for using Seeded-Agar for the screening assessment of antimicrobial activity in fabric and air filter media.
The antifungal properties of a textile material are generally evaluated using the AATCC Test Method 30: 1999. The standard provides four methods for evaluation of fungal growth on the textile substrate to be classified as “‘no growth”, “microscopic growth”, or “macroscopic growth” accompanied with the determination of tensile strength loss due to fungus-induced
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 75
deterioration in the fabric. The first method tests the extent of growth of fungi in the test sample of dimension 4 15 cm buried and incubated in fungi-inoculated soil for 2 to 16 weeks at 28 °C. The second and third method involves growth of fungi Chaetomiumglobosum and fungi A. niger, respectively, in an inoculated petridish having a circular (4 cm diameter) or rectangular specimen (4 15 cm) placed at the center. The last method involves a 2.5 7.6 cm specimen-introduced sealed jar seeded with three fungi mixtures at a high humidity environment for 14 to 28 days. The extent of fungal growth in the samples is taken as a direct measure of antifungal activity.

sections.heading: 2.2 Antimicrobial NP Used in Functionalization of Textiles
2.2.1 Ag NP: Synthesis and Antimicrobial Activity
sections.text:
Ag has been used as a sign of prosperity since ancient times by royal families with Ag cutleries and crockeries considered epitome of high standard life [55]. The excellent biological activity of Ag was long known and has been used through ages as a medium to fight infectious ailments. Ag compounds and ions have been used for centuries to treat contaminated water to render it potable and life-sustaining [51, 55]. Among the different metallic NP used in antimicrobial finishing of textiles, Ag NP is by far the most prominently used due to highest effectiveness at lowest concentration. Ag NP inhibit almost 650 different types of pathogenic bacteria and five strains of yeast; however, its affectivity toward mildew, mold, and fungus is limited, probably because it falls into the category of non-essential elements of nutrition [69–71]. In the present decade, Ag-based finishes both in NP and bulk form have unprecedented market application in not only textile, but also plastic, chemical, pharmaceuticals, and hygiene industries [72–73]. Ag resin columns and Ag zeolites have been used since long in water filters and pharmaceutical applications [74–75]. Ag salts such as silver sulfadiazine have been extensively used in burn bandages and wound dressings [76–77]. The use of AgNO3 as a finishing chemical to impart antimicrobial activity is often accompanied with a dark brown–black stain on exposure to air, heat, or light caused by uncontrolled reduction of Ag ions to form bigger metallic Ag particles [78–79].
The size, shape, and crystallinity of Ag NP have a profound effect on its antimicrobial behavior with the non-spherical shapes such as polygonal, triangular, and poly-hierarchical morphologies which have a higher

sections.heading: 76 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: inhibitory effect than spherical and disc-shaped NP [80–81]. However, the method of synthesis, that is, reduction route, type of chemicals, and process parameters, also affects the end properties [68]. The synthesis of Ag NP can be broadly categorized into top-down and bottom-up approaches. In the bottom-up approach, which is used predominantly for synthesis purpose, Ag NP are produced by both physical deposition and chemical precipitation methods. Chemical deposition routes often require harsh non-environment-friendly surfactants and reducing agents. The precursor salt is most often AgNO3 as it offers advantages of comparatively low cost and chemical stability although silver acetate is also in use [82]. The reducing agents used are sodium borohydride, sodium citrate, and hydrazine hydrate as mostly used; however, ethanol, DMF, ascorbic acid, aldehydes, and isopropanol are also employed [83–86]. The capping agents used to cease particle growth and prevent agglomerated superstructures are mainly PVP and citrate salts with uses of amines, CTAB, sugars, and PVA also mentioned in the current literature [68, 84–86]. With growing concern about environmental hazards with the release of toxic byproducts and reagents into the immediate surroundings, green synthesis has found significant focus in recent times. Plant extracts, biological agents, and microbe-mediated metabolism byproducts that are capable of donating free electrons are increasingly reported as potential reducing agents to combat and replace hazardous reducing chemicals [87–90]. Physical deposition routes of synthesizing Ag NP include UV-irradiation, calcination at moderately elevated temperatures, and plasma treatment [91–93]. The top approach for synthesis which employs laser ablation techniques and nanolithography to reduce particle down is comparatively less reported due to difficulty in controlling the morphology and thereby leading to imperfectly shaped NP [68].

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Titania NP: Synthesis and Antimicrobial Activity
sections.text:
TiO2 or titania is the natural oxide form of titanium and has been used generously in a variety of applications in cosmetic, paints, paper, plastic, and textile industry for decades [95–96]. Titania is a semi-conducting material with one of the strongest photo-catalytic activities with high oxidizing power, long-term stability, and low cost [97]. The high refractive index and good light-scattering property of the material make it possible to impart considerable whiteness and opacity to its product even at very low concentrations. Titania is considered to be chemically and biologically inert, and hence accepted as a food and pharmaceutical additive for artificial food coloring, dental pastes, tablets, oral capsules, suspensions, and
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 77
dermal ointments and creams [54, 98–99]. With breakthrough research on nano-science and nano-technology and development of nano-materials as an improved version of the parent materials with unique value-added properties, TiO2 NP or nano-titania became increasingly important having unique photocatalytic, optical, UV-shielding, and antimicrobial properties making it suitable for a plethora of applications in various market sectors [95, 99, 100–101]. In the textile industry, nano-titania is popular in “selfcleaning” textiles for obtaining impurity-free surfaces and self-disinfecting nature by self-decomposition of dirt and organic pollutant molecules under accelerated photo-catalytic reaction [50, 102–104].
Crystalline TiO2 exhibits three different polymorphs—anatase, rutile, and brookite—among which anatase exhibited the highest photocatalytic activity. However, the commercial nano-titania powder available for antibacterial studies contains 80:20 mixture of anatase and rutile [105]. Titania NP are generally obtained by the sol–gel precipitation method in which titanium isopropoxide is normally stirred with ammonium hydroxide, and the end-point of the reaction is confirmed when a change of color from purple to white precipitate is obtained [95,98]. When UV light is illuminated, a positive hole is photo-generated in the valence band when excitation causes electrons to jump from valence to conduction band. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as O2*, H2O2, and HO* are generated via redox reactions between electron-hole and adsorbed oxygen and water. ROS are known to induce oxidative stress inside the bacterial cell and contribute toward bactericidal action [98–100]. Studies shown on E. coli bacteria demonstrates that OH radicals were major contributors toward oxidative stress; its high reactivity makes crevices on the outer wall that subsequently leads to drainage of cytoplasmic fluid [100]. Nano-titania with spherical crystallites <30 nm diameter exhibits strong photo-catalytic disinfection action against many strains of bacteria (Streptococcus mutans, Streptococcus epidermis, E. coli, Bacillus sp.), fungi (Aspergillus sp.), algae, and virus [99, 104–105], although their MIC values are pronouncedly less than Ag-based systems [106–107].

sections.heading: 2.2.3 Cu NP: Synthesis and Antimicrobial Activity
sections.text: Due to its inherent antimicrobial nature, Cu along with Ag has been employed by the human society since pre-historic ages with documented uses in coins, utensils, and inexpensive jewelry. Its hygienic and antibacterial properties were well-recognized and gained popularity in common masses, being less expensive as compared to Ag since the advent of human civilization [108–109]. In ancient times, pots or bottles were made of Cu

sections.heading: 78 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
where water was stored for hygienic purposes. In fact, old-age Hindu traditions believed throwing coins in water would fulfill wishes, and it was considered a good practice as Cu coins purified the water, making it potable. Cu, unlike Ag, is an essential trace element that is present in all living tissues and is crucial for growth and development of many micro-organisms including human [110–111]. Cu is a well-established element with antibacterial, antiviral, antifungal, insecticidal, and molluscicidal properties [112– 113]. Cu salts such as CuSO4 have been extensively used as a fungicide in agricultural applications [114]. However, its toxicity at higher doses, especially to marine and aquatic life, has restricted its widespread commercial applications in recent times [115]. With the advent of nano-technology, research on the synthesis of Cu and CuO NP was focused to bring antimicrobial effects at lower concentration and less toxicity [38, 55,116].
The current literature on the synthesis of Cu NP can be classified broadly into three categories by physical, chemical, and biological means. Like synthesis of Ag NP, most researchers focus on the bottom-up approach by wet chemical routes as the scope of controlling the size of NP is higher. In wet chemical routes, the precursor Cu salts such as CuSO4, in aqueous or ethanol media using reducing agents such as sodium borohydride, hydrazine, ascorbic acid, etc., are reported [117–118]. Recently, extracts from plants, that is, extracts from the plant Terminalia arjuna and from the leaves of Lawsonia inermis (henna), are employed as reducing agents and/ or capping agents [119–120]. These methods of reduction are environment friendly and avoid direct usage of harsh reducing agents. The reverse emulsion method containing surfactant-stabilized oil-in-water micro-emulsion acting as nano-reactors for the formation of Cu NP is another well-known procedure where shape and size are easily controllable [121–122]. The physical routes for synthesis include microwave irradiation, thermal treatment, electrochemical synthesis, ultra-sonication technology via acoustic cavitation, etc. [38, 123]. In an attempt to develop non-toxic, reliable, and green process routes, efforts are being put into modern studies to focus on biological synthesis [124–125]. The bacterial strain of Pseudomonas stutzeri isolated from soil was successful in producing cubic-shaped Cu NP of 50- to 150-nm diameter [125]. The synthesis of CuO NP is generally accomplished by hydrolysis of precursor Cu salt followed by dehydration. CuO NP relatively has more physical and chemical stability than pure Cu NP [126]. Cu and CuO NP are found effective against a wide range of both Grampositive and Gram-negative bacteria, for example, Staphylococcus aureus, Bacillus subtilis, E. coli, Micrococcus luteus, and Klebsiella pneumoniae as well as different strains of fungi such as Aspergillus flavus, A. niger, and Candida albicans [55, 127]. The antifungal activities of Cu-based NP were
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 79
higher than Ag NP of a similar diameter as Cu is relevant to the biochemical reactions of organisms and is readily taken up by fungi that consider Cu as a nutrient [128].

sections.heading: 2.2.4 ZnO NP: Synthesis and Antimicrobial Activity
sections.text:
Zn belongs to the class of essential elements required for vital functioning, as it controls and catalyzes many cellular reactions responsible for structural activity [129–130]. It is responsible for growth and differentiation, utilized in redox processes, and they regulate osmotic pressure as well as maintain ionic balance. In lower organisms, as the Zn concentration reaches higher levels, depending on the type of micro-organism, it starts exerting its cytotoxic nature [131–132]. It has been postulated that it hampers the generation time of an organism by prolonging the lag phase of the cycle responsible for growth. Additionally, it alters the semi-permeable nature of the cell membrane preventing calcium uptake by controlling the enzymes responsible for membrane permeability [133–137].
Nano-ZnO represents a significant class of metal oxide NP possessing excellent antimicrobial action with lowest toxicity to human cells [132]. Its virtues make it highly recommendable in the food industry and in biomedical applications where an optimal balance has to be sustained between safety to human health and potent biocidal property [138–139]. Its UV shielding property has been rampantly used as active ingredients in skin lotions, creams, and sunscreens [138–140]. ZnO NP are also used in sensors, electronic devices, energy-harvesting materials, and in optical absorption due to its semi-conducting, photo-catalytic, and piezoelectric nature [140]. Different shapes of ZnO nano-structures, namely nano-rods, nanospheres, nano-wires, nano-needles, and nano-rings, have been reported by controlling physical parameters and chemical parameters such as temperature, pH, solvent type, and precursor concentration [140–141]. Some of the most adopted technologies for synthesis of ZnO nano-structures include thermal evaporation, hydrothermal synthesis, sol–gel technique, simple thermal sublimation, self-combustion, polymerized complex method, vapor–liquid–solid technique, double-jet precipitation, and chemical solution synthesis [138–141]. Spherical shaped ZnO NP synthesized by the wet chemical process using a Zn precursor salt such as Zn acetate dihydrate and strong alkali like sodium hydroxide have currently been explored for antimicrobial activity and have been found to exhibit strong microbial resistance to gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria like E. coli, S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, B. subtilis, S. acidaminiphila, and P. aeruginosa [141–143]. The excellent antifungal behavior of ZnO NP is considerably higher than that

sections.heading: 80 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: of non-essential elements such as Ag and has been shown to be effective against white-rot fungi, mildew, and algae [128].

sections.heading: 2.3 Application of NP onto Textile Substrates
2.3.1 Application of Ag NP on Textiles
sections.text:
Among different metal NP used for antimicrobial functionalization of textile materials, Ag NP are by far the most preferred choice over other NP, because of high potency at low concentration. Additionally, most research attention is focused on antimicrobial functionalization of cotton fabrics, mainly because it is most prone to microbial degradation and is used extensively in non-implantable medical textiles such as wound dressings, bandages, gauze fabrics, uniforms, and caps [4, 38, 57, 144]. Surface modification or finishing has been done using various application techniques such as dip-coating, pad-dry-cure method, layer-by-layer coating, plasma treatment, or in situ reduction [55]. According to the International Standard Organization, an NP is defined as a particle as a whole having a diameter <100 nm in all three dimensions. However, any particle between 100 nm and 1000 nm, which essentially contains clusters of individual NP, is also termed as NP in the textile world [55]. By this definition, some of the Ag salts impregnated into the textile fabric are also NP as they are clusters of Ag crystals in nano-meter range. With vast expanding areas of research conducted on antimicrobial Ag NP-based chemistry, excellent bioactive textile fabrics are readily available. However, although the binding mechanism of Ag NP onto textile substrates is not fully elucidated, effectiveness of antimicrobial activity is greatly reduced with strong chemical binding in the interface. This raises a huge concern for the detrimental drainage of nano-Ag into the immediate environment with successive washing cycles [145–146]. The toxicological shock represents a potential research area where future investigation must be directed to achieve commercial success of NP-based biochemistry onto textile substrates [67]. Unlike thermoplastic polymers, where incorporation of Ag NP can be carried out at various stages, impregnation in fibers and in fabrics can only be done at the final stage in which NP are applied as a finishing technique. Emam et al. [147] argue that functional household cellulosic textiles show a significant pick up of Ag NP and subsequent antibacterial activity through simple immersing in AgNO3 aqueous solution and therefore the researches which articulate incorporation of reducing and stabilizing agents, whether physical or chemical or bio-based, only complicate the methodology without bringing
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 81
out better functional attributes. However, the concentration of the Ag nano-sol has a significant control over its laundered antimicrobial activity. Low concentrations (less than 10 ppm) may not be suitable for longterm antimicrobial activity and high concentrations upto 50 ppm may be required to achieve a desirable effect.
The morphological shape of the Ag NP is a determining factor in deciding the extent of bio-activity. Different morphologies of synthesized Ag NP—spheres, flat nano-plates, nano-prisms, polygonal and hierarchical by chemical reduction route have been applied on different cotton fabrics using ultra-sonication technology at suitable temperature [148]. The fabrics treated with hierarchical Ag NP evaluated against E. coli and S. aureus showed the best activity of >91% after five washing cycles.
Several studies are tuned toward in situ reduction of Ag NP directly on the textile substrate. Perelshtein et al. [149] prepared antibacterial cotton, nylon, and polyester fabrics using the dip-coating method using a solution of AgNO3 salt precursor and ethylene glycol in aqueous media. The fabric was further sono-chemically treated for immobilization of Ag NP effective against E. coli and S. aureus. Liu et al. [150] reported a simple yet effective one-pot synthesis method for fabricating a cotton bandage for biomedical applications with excellent activity toward E. coli and S. aureus. The nano-coating on cotton was carried out by dipping cotton fabric in ethanol-mediated AgNO3 and butylamine solution. Lee et al. [151] developed bioactive cotton and a polyester-woven fabric by simply dipping in Ag nano-sol stabilized in ethanol. Rajavel et al. [152] demonstrated yet another simple method for producing cotton fabrics with durable antimicrobial finishing by dipping the fabric in AgNO3 and subsequently sodium borohydride solution under static conditions. The authors optimized the concentrations of the solution to maximize loading and distribution and reported that low concentrations of both precursor (1 m M Ag NO3) and reductant (0.5 m M borohydride) are beneficial for optimum results. The treated fabrics showed yellowish coloration and bioactivity against B. subtilis and S. sonnei for potential use in wound dressing. Antimicrobial cotton fabrics pre-activated with potassium hydroxide, dipped into AgNO3 and ascorbic acid solution, and further treated with hexadecyltrimethoxysilane to coat with a low surface energy barrier layer were reported by ShateriKhalilabad et al. [153]. The same research group reported pre-activation of cotton fabrics with alkali treatment to maximize loading [154]. The in situ NP-embedded hydrophobic fabric showed good laundering stability and antimicrobial action against E. coli and S. aureus. The carboxylate and the amine groups present in the polymeric chains of polyamide fibers were used as a reducing agent for obtaining Ag NP by Montazer et al. [155]. The

sections.heading: 82 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
antibacterial fabric was obtained by treating it with Ag-ammonia complex at boil with 20–150 nm Ag NP forming in situ on its surface. The fabric exhibited excellent antibacterial activity against S. aureus and E. coli with >98% bacterial colony reduction after 20 washes. A schematic of the paddry-cure method and the corresponding TEM image of the Ag NPs as outlined by Hebeish et al. [86] has been outlined in Figure 2.1.
Apart from in situ reduction, considerable research activities were carried out to fabricate antimicrobial textiles using ex situ precipitated Ag NP. El-Rafie et al. [156] reported antibacterial cotton fabrics finished with Ag NP by dipping in a colloidal solution of Ag NP and an acrylate-based binder. The prepared fabrics were effective against E. coli and S. aureus. Hanh et al. [157] prepared polyester–cotton-blend fabric coated with Ag NP by the pad-dry-cure method. The Ag NP were previously prepared ex situ by γ-radiation of AgNO3 chitosan solution, chitosan acting as a stabilizing as well as binding agent. The fabric showed acceptable performance as a wrapper in patient’s bed in the hospital where chances of cross-infections are high. Alkali-hydrolyzed alginate solution has been used as a reducing and stabilizing agent for the synthesis of Ag NP and further used for finishing of cotton fabrics by the pad-dry-cure method. In another study by Hebeish et al. [158], carboxy methyl cellulose hyrdrogel-based Ag NP has been used as a finishing agent on cotton fabrics through the pad-dry-cure route. Multifunctional wool fabrics functionalized with different morphologies of ex situ prepared Ag NP by the dip coating method were developed by Tang et al. [159]. The prism and disk-shaped NP imparted brilliant and uniform coloration of blue, red, and yellow to wool fabrics due to localized surface plasmon resonance. Montazer et al. [160] reported antimicrobial nylon/Ag NP nano-composite fabric using colloidal Ag nano-sol and 1,2,3,4-butanetetracarboxylic acid (BTCA) as a binder as shown as
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 83
Figure 2.2. The multifunctional fabric showed antimicrobial activity and resistance to creasing without undesirable color formation. In another study by Yuranova et al. [161], polyester and polyamide fabrics were pretreated with both RF-plasma and Vacuum-UV radiation for surface modification to maximize Ag loading and further treated with AgNO3. Zhang et al. [162] developed ex situ nano-colloidal Ag NP using an amino-terminated hyper-branched polymer as a reducing agent and a finishing agent for cotton fabric. Yeo et al. [163] reported a bicomponent PP sheath-core filament with Ag NP incorporated in the sheath part for enhanced bioactivity. Majumder et al. [164] presented a model-based study on the effect of knitting parameters on antimicrobial activity for knitted PET/Ag NP nano-composite fabrics. The authors reported a decrease in the count of yarn, and an increase in machine gauge increases antimicrobial activity and the fabrics showed ~1% of antimicrobial loss after 25 washes. A comparison study between in situ and ex situ approach for deposition of Ag NP on cotton fabric was presented by Perera et al. [165]. The authors concluded that in situ approach functioned better in terms of strength of antimicrobial activity and durability along with easier control of shape, size, and location of Ag NP on the fabric. Further, in situ approach is capable of

sections.heading: 84 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
providing antimicrobial action at low concentrations; thereby, leeching out of chemicals is also minimized.
The LBL nano-coating method for immobilization of Ag NP is generally used for nylon, silk, and cotton using alternate dipping into dilute solutions of poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDADMAC) and Ag NP capped with poly(methacrylic acid) (PMA) [166]. Dubas et al. [167] reported better uniformity in nano-coating for silk fibers than nylon fibers, the antibacterial efficiency being 80% and 50% bacterial colonies reduction for silk and nylon, respectively, against S. aureus. Sataev et al. [168] invented a novel method of nano-coating in which fabrics are first treated with CuSO4 solution by either dipping or spraying and further treated with phosphine to obtain copper phosphide and silver nitrate to obtain a silver phosphide coating of 40–600 nm thickness. The fabrics retained bactericidal efficacy after 10 washes. Ag NP (~20 nm) in another study reported by Budama et al. [169] were synthesized as reverse micelle cores using polystyrene-block-polyacrylic acid (PS-b-PAA) as a copolymer, polymerized in situ by atom transfer radical polymerization. Further, cotton fabrics were padded with the copolymer-Ag solution enabling esterification reaction between hydroxyl groups of cellulose and corona (PAA). The fabrics were effective against E. coli for up to 5 washes and S. aureus for up to 20 washes. Cotton gauze fabrics for wound healing applications finished with Ag oxide NP were reported by Gouda et al. [170]. The NP synthesis was carried out in situ by dipping the fabrics in successive baths of precursor salt containing AgNO3 and reducing bath containing hydrogen peroxide and sodium hydroxide at pH 9.5. The fabric was further batched and dried and showed effective reduction of colonies against S. typhimurium, S. aureus, C. albicans, and A. flavus. It has been opined by Dastjerdi et al. [171] that there is binding force playing between the textile substrate and the inorganic NP due to difference in surface energies between the two phases and hence the authors devised a functional coating based on polysiloxane modified with nano-Ag which is applied to PET fabric by the pad-dry-cure route. The polysiloxane polymeric layer on the fabric makes it resistant to heat, light, and microbial attack in addition to providing it with anti-static property, eliminating the use of spin finish step.
Since Ag NP have extreme tendency to agglomerate and form clusters of metallic Ag, thereby decreasing its antimicrobial potency manifold, considerable research has been oriented toward achieving stable NP with supporting materials targeted toward maximum achievable functional augmentation. Silica-Ag core shell NP represent a significantly important class, with silica core offering advantages of sufficient compatibility, inert
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 85
nature, and excellent heat resistance to support the peripherally located Ag NP [172]. Extremely lower sizes of Ag NP can be developed up to 1–2 nm in diameter deposited on the silica core having 270 nm diameter using one-pot chemical synthesis route as reported by Nischala et al. [172]. Cotton fabrics with silica-Ag NP immobilized by the pad-dry-cure method exhibited excellent activity against E. coli and retained its bioactivity up to acceptable standards after 10 washing cycles. Silica-Ag core shell particles have also been explored on natural fibers like wool and silk and man-made fibers like polyester and polyamide. Ag NP capped with dodecanethiol 1–5 nm in size was synthesized by the two-phase arrested micro-emulsion technique, and subsequently applied to the cotton fabric by padding it in nano-Ag sol, as reported by Tarimala et al. [173]. Cotton dressing for burn wounds with good bioactivity has been reported by Parikh et al. [174] using Ag-modified sodium carboxy methyl cellulose.
Titania doped with Ag NP by the sol–gel synthesis route using titanium isopropoxide and AgNO3 as precursor salts has been another significant research area addressing toward the stabilization issue stemming from nano-scale-sized Ag NP. Degoutin et al. [175] reported woven cotton fabric, spun-bonded PP fabric, and a cotton/non-woven PET blend fabric with durable bioactivity against E. coli and S. aureus. The fabrics except the woven cotton fabric have been surface-modified in the first step to make it hydrophilic using RF plasma and acrylic acid as a monomer. All the fabrics are subsequently impregnated with titania-doped Ag NP using pad-drycure and electrospray process. Anatase titania coated with 1% Ag NP has been used to prepare isotactic polypropylene filaments by the melt compounding route in a twin screw extruder in concentration of 0.2–0.5 wt% as reported by Dastjerdi et al. [176]. The addition of a TiO2–Ag nano-filler did not hamper processability and showed comparable mechanical activity with a neat filament. Montazer et al. [177] developed Ag-loaded titania NP through the photo-reduction route for functionalization of wool fabrics. The immobilization in wool fabrics effective against E. coli and S. aureus was carried out via padding using citric acid as a cross-linker.
The last decade witnessed tremendous growth in Ag NP-incorporated textiles fabricated through physical deposition methods to minimize toxicity associated with chemicals required for wet reduction for Ag NP. This includes techniques such as ultrasonic frequency treatment, UV irradiation, and plasma treatment. Lu et al. [178] developed an antimicrobial silk fabric with crystalline Ag NP immobilized on the surface by UV irradiation. UV irradiation was also employed by Montazer et al. [179] to produce a colloidal Ag NP solution using Tollen’s reagent as a precursor and PVP as a stabilizing agent. The SEM images of the fibres are shown in Figure 2.3.

sections.heading: 86 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
The ex situ prepared Ag NP were padded onto the polyamide fabric, and the fabric showed >99% reduction of bacterial colonies against E. coli after 20 washing cycles.
Plasma pre-treatment promoting surface activation of hydrophobic fibers to make it hydrophilic and assessable to functional groups is greatly beneficial for polyester and polyamide fibers. Deng et al. [180] developed an antimicrobial non-woven PET fabric where Ag NP were introduced by the dip-drying process between two layers of the organosilicon thin film (10–50 nm) and attached to PET by the atmospheric pressure plasma system. Radetić et al. [181] reported a series of antimicrobial textiles based on durable and uniform Ag NP nano-coating by varying the plasma sources such as low-temperature air radio frequency (RF), dielectric barrier discharge (DBD), and corona discharge. Their reports indicate that the strength of antimicrobial activity and deposition uniformity is better tunable with RF plasma, although handling the system is difficult than DBD and corona discharge. Nano-Ag coating assisted by high power impulse
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 87
magnetron sputtering on PET fabrics has been developed by Chen et al. [182]. This method is advantageous as high density plasma is capable of producing adhesion between film and PET at comparatively lower temperature of substrates. Surface activation of PET fabrics using corona air plasma following immobilization of nano-Ag has also been reported by Gorenšek et al. [183].
With increasing environmental biohazards created by harsh reductants and solvents required for NP synthesis, green nano-technology focusing on sustainability and negative externalities has emerged as the most promising field for further research in this area. In an attempt to reduce environmental toxicity which is a matter of great concern of date, natural resources such as starch, natural gums, cyclodextrin, and chitosan used as a reducing and stabilizing agent have been reported. Chitosan, a natural polysaccharide and a derivative of glucose family formed from chitin found in the exoskeleton of arthropods, is a non-toxic, biodegradable, and polycationic biocompatible antibacterial agent [184–185]. Ag cations are known to form chelate complexes with amino and hydroxyl groups of chitosan enabling chemical modification and functionalization. The emulsion containing a synergistic complex of chitosan-Ag is applied to fabrics by the conventional pad-dry-cure procedure, or the finishing technique has an excellent activity toward E. coli and S. aureus and shows resistance against alkaline laundering [186]. Such finished fabrics have the advantages of low add-on percentage preventing undesirable color generation usually associated with Ag NP-finished fabrics. Cotton fabrics bound with naturally synthesized Ag NP through the pad-dry-cure route with an excellent antibacterial activity have been demonstrated by Hebeish et al. [86]. The NP have been synthesized using hydroxypropyl starch as a reducing and stabilizing agent. The authors further showed that the presence of binder was essential to retain antimicrobial activity after laundering cycles. Mahltig et al. [187] developed Ag NP supported on dendrimers as a finishing agent for obtaining antimicrobial textiles, the thermal fixation, and the generation of which controlled the extent of the antimicrobial activity. Green synthesis of Ag NP was also attempted using Erigeron annuus (L.) pers flower extract used as a reducing and capping agent by Velmurugan et al. [188]. The Ag NP were further attached to cotton fabrics under ultrasonic treatment and were found to be effective against S. epidermis and B. linens. Ravindra et al. [189] reported Ag NP (~20 nm) formed on cotton fibers using Eucalyptus citriodora and Ficus bengalensis plant extracts. Balakumaran et al. [190] reported Ag NP synthesis using a fungal mat of Aspergillus terrus. The Ag NP, 8–20 nm in size, was further padded to cotton fabric to obtain antibacterial and antifungal

sections.heading: 88 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text: cotton fabric effective against Bacillus subtilis, S. aureus, Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), E. coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Penicillium sp., Aspergillus fumigatus, A. niger, and Rhizoctonia oryzae with excellent laundering durability. Balamurugan et al. [191] used P. pterocarpum flower extract to synthesize Ag NP to be coated on cotton fabrics.

sections.heading: 2.3.2 Application of TiO2 NP on Textiles
sections.text:
Titania NP are chiefly noteworthy because of its photo-catalytic activity for the application in self-cleaning textiles [192]. However, literatures mentioning its antimicrobial properties are also available. In situ generation of titania NP in both phases—anatase and rutile—onto cotton textile substrate has been demonstrated in a simple one-step synthesis method using ultrasonic irradiation by Perelshtein et al. [193]. Crystalline titania NP obtained by acoustic cavitation and deposited in situ without necessitating further heating of the fabric to elevated temperatures (300 °C for anatase and 600 °C for rutile) have been first reported. Through photo-catalysis invisible-light, the fabrics showed activity against E.coli, S. aureus, and C. albicans. In situ sono-chemical synthesis of anatase titania NP on cotton fabrics at low temperatures was reported by Sadr et al. [194]. In another method outlined by Daoud et al. [195], titania NP are prepared ex situ by the usual sol–gel synthesis and then applied to cellulosic fibers by the paddry-cure method followed by hydrothermal treatment at comparatively low temperature (97 °C) to obtain anatase phase in the nano-coated fibers. The cellulosic fibers demonstrated antibacterial behavior under UV and dark conditions making the process suitable for preparing antimicrobial low heat resistance materials such as wood, biomaterials, plastics, and paper. Arain et al. [196] developed cotton fabrics impregnated with commercially procured AgCl–titinia colloid and chitosan through the pad-dry-cure process with a reduction of 100% against S. aureus and 98% against E. coli. Kangwansupamonkon et al. [197] used ex situ precipitated apatite-coated titania NP for dip-coating of cotton fabrics. The porous apatite coating over NP functions as adsorbents for pollutants and contaminants and the NP showed resistance against E. coli, S. aureus, MRSA, and Micrococcus luteus in dark and visible and black light conditions. The nano-coated cotton fabrics were obtained by padding through a solution containing coated titiania NP, xanthan gum as a thickening agent, and an acrylic-based binder, and subsequently dried and cured. The fabrics showed higher antimicrobial activity in black light irradiation than in visible light or under dark conditions.
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 89

sections.heading: 2.3.3 Application of Cu NP and CuO NP on Textiles
sections.text:
The literatures on finishing of textiles where Cu and CuO NP are employed were much less compared to Ag-based finished agents. Komeily-Nia et al. [198] reported nylon/Cu NP composite fabrics impregnated with in situ reduced Cu NP (~85 nm size) by dipping in consecutive solutions containing ascorbic acid and cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB). The SEM images of the Nylon fabrics are shown in Figure 2.4. Ascorbic acid functioned as a reducing as well as ethylene-scavenging agent preventing oxidation of Cu NP to CuO NP, and CTAB controlled the size of the NP. The greenish tinged fabrics showed higher tensile strength and lower bending length and presented ZOI in the disk diffusion test against S. aureus. Teli et al. [199] reported acrylamide-grafted bamboo rayon fabric to immobilize Cu NP in situ durable up to 50 washes.
Perelshtein et al. [200] prepared a CuO-coated cotton bandage sonicated in Cu acetate in an ethanol-water medium and further UV-irradiated to develop in situ CuO NP. Crystalline CuO in nano-form

sections.heading: 90 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
is uniformly deposited on fibers and shows effectiveness against E. coli and S. aureus suitable for use in wound dressings, bed linens, and bandages. The same group advocated outstanding launderability up to 65 cycles for the sonochemical method of coating for cotton fabrics with CuO NP, suitable for minimizing hospital-acquired cross-infections [201]. Anita et al. [202] described a method to produce microencapsulated CuO NP for finishing of the cotton fabric. CuO NP of size ~50 nm were produced by the wet chemical method with CuSO4, sodium hydroxide, and starch and further encapsulated with sodium alginate by the ionic gelation process using a sprayer. The plain weave cotton fabrics finished with microcapsule-CuO NP using the exhaustion process followed by pad-dry-cure showed activity against E. coli and S. aureus and showed better laundering durability than only CuO NP-finished fabrics. Gabbay et al. [203] described a multi-soaking procedure to impregnate cotton fibers with CuO NP.
Abramova et al. [204] developed a sonochemical reactor in which NP guided by cativation jets formed by asymmetric collapse of bubbles are hurled at high velocities toward the fiber surface. The authors reported CuO NP-incorporated cotton fabrics coated uniformly having activity against E. coli, S. aureus, K. pneumonia, and MRSA. To take the NP finishing of textiles further, a pilot-scale sonochemical coating plant has been successfully developed [205]. The CuO and ZnO NP have been incorporated as a nano-coating on cotton fabrics continuously for 50 m.

sections.heading: 2.3.4 Application of ZnO NP on Textiles
sections.text:
In situ generation of ZnO NP (~30 nm) on cotton fabrics assisted by sonochemical irradiation coating was reported by Perelshtein et al. [206]. The fabrics showed activity against S. aureus and E. coli even at 0.75% of nano-coating. Uğur et al. [207] developed a multilayer nano-composite film consisting of ZnO NP by LBL self-assembly on cotton fabrics. Cationization of fabrics was previously carried out using 2,3-epoxypropyl trimethylammonium chloride (EP3MAC) and further dipping in alternate solutions of cationic and anionic ZnO nano-colloids. The fabrics with 10 and 16 layers of nano ZnO showed activity against S. aureus after 20 washing cycles.
Rajendra et al. [208] reported ZnO prepared ex situ by the wet precipitation method using ZnSO4 and NaOH as precursor salts in soluble starch for pad-dry-cure finishing of cotton fabrics. The fabrics showed better activity against S. aureus than E. coli in disk diffusion and bacterial colonies reduction test. Krishnaveni et al. [209] reported a chitosan–ZnO
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 91
complex by the hydrothermal method via in situ deposition of ZnO in chitosan. The chitosan–ZnO complex cross-linked on cotton fabric by the pad-dry-cure method is suitable for applications requiring antibacterial activity and biological fluorescence labeling applications. Polyamide 6/ ZnO NP nano-composite fibers have been prepared using a melt intercalation route using 0.5–5 wt% of ZnO NP, reported by Dural Erem et al. [210]. The nano-composite fibers showed 99% reduction in bacterial colonies of S. aureus and K. pneumoniae with increased mechanical properties.
Cotton fabrics functionalized with flower-shaped ZnO and chalcone ((E)-1-(3-hydroxyphenyl)-3-(4-methoxyphenyl) prop-2-en-1one), an aromatic ketone-based antibacterial agent have been developed using padding mangle and gum acacia as binding agents, as developed by Sivakumar et al. [211]. The fabric based on combination antimicrobial therapy which relies on synergistic effect of chalcone and ZnO NP showed >99% reduction of bacterial colonies against E.coli, S. aureus, and P. aeruginosa.

sections.heading: 2.3.5 Application of other NP on Textiles
sections.text: In situ synthesis of magnetite and hematite NP using ferric chloride has been deposited on polyester woven fabric using a sono-chemical synthesis route as reported by Harifi et al. [212]. The fabrics showed bioactivity and durable magnetic properties suitable for electromagnetic shielding and antibacterial applications. Rastgoo et al. [213] devised a one-pot deposition method of magnetite NPS on cotton/PET blend fabric through ultrasonic irradiation. The fabric was irradiated ultrasonically in a bath containing ferrous sulfate as a precursor and CTAB as a surfactant. Asymmetric bubble collapses generating cavitation-oxidized Fe2+ to Fe3+ with hydroxyl radicals produced due to water sonolysis. The blend showed 95% activity against S. aureus and 99% against C. albicans. Gouda et al. [214] reported cotton gauze fabric-finished zirconium oxide NP (2–5 nm) deposited in situ by successive immersion in a precursor salt solution and a reducing agent solution, followed by batching and drying. The cotton gauze fabrics were effective against S. aureus, S. typhimurium, and C. albicans but were ineffective against A. flavus. Crepe satin silk fabrics immobilized with Au NP developed in situ using tetrachloroauric (III) acid in aqueous media have been reported by Tang et al. [215]. The silk fabrics were colored red and brown according to Au nano-spheres and nano-disks, respectively, with good light fastness, UV protection, thermal conductivity, and excellent antibacterial activity against E. coli.

sections.heading: 92 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
2.4 Mechanism of Action of Inorganic NP
sections.text: Metal and metal oxide NP show excellent biocidal activity against different strains of bacteria, fungi, and yeast at extremely low concentrations owing to their nano-scale dimensions, unique physicochemical characteristics, and high specific surface area. Although many scientific literatures are available to support beneficial attributes, the mechanism of biocidal action of metal-based NP is poorly understood and has many schools of thought [216–217]. The intrinsic chemistry of the NP is an important parameter in determining the extent and strength of antimicrobial action and is chiefly governed by three intrinsic factors—the reduction potential of the metal, its solubility in cytoplasmic fluid, and metal donor atom selectivity. These three factors play an important role in the multi-targeted action mechanism unique of NP [56, 216–218]. The mechanism of toxicity of the nanoparticles against bacteria is schematically outlined in Figure 2.5.

sections.heading: 2.4.1 Cell Membrane Leakage and/or Impairment
sections.text: Bacterial cells possess a net negative charge due to the presence of acidic phospholipids on its outer membrane with the extent of charge varying form strain to strain. Therefore, monovalent and divalent cations are electrostatically attracted toward the outer membrane. The membrane houses transporter-specific (ABC transporters and P-type transporters) or unspecific (MIT transporters) regulating the intake or excretion of proteins and nutrients [219–220]. Cu and Zn ions are permitted to enter through ion channels as they belong to a class of essential nutrients. Cu can also cause membrane impairment through lipid peroxidation, attacking the integrity of the cell. Ag is known to cause leakage of protons through the cell by unbalancing the chemi-osmotic force across the membrane. Some cations can bind with transporters inhibiting complete assimilation of ions [220].

sections.heading: 2.4.2 Oxidative Stress Generation through ROS
sections.text:
Fe is an essential element present in living cells functioning as a co-factor to enzymes, catalyzing life-sustaining enzymatic reactions and engaged to coordination ligands; however, it also catalyzes Fenton reaction to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) according to equation (1) [221–222]:
(2.1)
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 93
Metals are characterized by their ability to contribute to redox reactions and change their oxidation states by acquiring electrons from donors. Therefore, they act as a catalyst in promoting Fenton reaction between Fe and H2O2 generating ROS. Metal cations such as Ag, which are nonFenton–active, displace Fe in coordination ligands through ionic or molecular mimicry and release Fe that catalyzes Fenton reaction producing a hydroxyl ion and a hydroxyl radical. The nascent hydroxyl radical is the most potent oxidizing reactive species, readily reacting with most biomolecules. With the rise in ROS intensifying toxic oxidative stress, antioxidants inside the cell become readily depleted [223]. Thiol groups possess high affinity for metals and can get oxidized leading to the generation of more ROS. Physiological redox reactions inside the cell are thereby severely hampered [216].

sections.heading: 94 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
2.4.3 Protein Activity Interference and Genotoxicity
sections.text: Selective interactions can bind metal ions and donor ligand atoms present in biological molecules leading to protein inactivation [217]. Fe-S dehydrase clusters in cell are prone to site-specific molecular mimicry by toxic metals which replace the Fe [216]. Free Fe further catalyzes the Fenton reaction. Bio-organic complexes with sulfur, oxygen, or nitrogen coordination ligand can be formed by cupric ions. The oxidative stress denatures the DNA double helix structure, ultimately leading to cell death [224].

sections.heading: 2.5 Nano-Toxicological Impact of NP on the Eco-System
sections.text:
With exceptional functional property enhancement obtained in NP-reinforced textile substrates, nano-additive-based research activity for textile materials is one of the fastest-growing industries of date. While every day, scientific literature points toward effortless fabrication of highly active nano-structured textile substrates leveraging its beneficial effects, there is only a modest amount of studies focused on the mechanism of action and effect on the human health and global ecosystem [66–68]. NP-finished products in the due course of time are bound to release NP incidentally, starting from the time of production, during washing and usage due to erosion, leading to severe malfunction of the environmental infrastructure [225]. In order to exert toxic effects to target organisms (bacteria, fungi, algae, and virus) for which it is primarily designed and fabricated, biocide metal NP above a threshold limit starts to attack nontarget organisms (marine species, mammalians, and human) on incidental or accidental exposure. The interfaces between the human body and the immediate surroundings, for example, small pores in the skin and respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genital tracts, function as possible entry routes toward NP absorption into the inner system [226]. It is highly likely that toxic effects associated with the exposure of NP will attack the lowest trophic level, that is, bacteria, protozoa, fungi, yeast, and molds at the initial stage [227]. However, trophic transfer may result in the transmission of toxicity to higher strata of the energy pyramid, the human. Metal and metal oxide-based NP are already proven to exhibit adverse effects to bacteria, fungi, and algae even at very low concentrations, a characteristic having roots in its high specific surface area. NP dumped onto wastewater treatment plants based on outdated hazardous discharge control technologies are incompetent in removing nano-scale-sized impurities, disrupting the aquatic ecosystem [228–229]. Scientific studies based on the effect of Ag
Antimicrobial Textiles Using Nano-particles 95
NP on marine life indicate that very low concentration of NP, especially Ag NP, can be fatal to zebra fish, clams, and Diptera species such as Drosophila melanogaster [230–232]. Crustaceans and fishes are proven be most susceptible to the NP toxicity, in some cases more than the target organism.
The levels of toxicity of different NP are different due to their inherent chemistry, reactivity, and solubility. Ag NP are the most toxic of different NP used for biocidal function apart from being the most potent one too. The LC50 values (lethal concentration; concentration in water having 50% chance of causing death to aquatic life) of Ag NP reported are very low, 0.01 mg/L for crustaceans to 38 mg/L for protozoa [67]. For other NP, the LC50 values are usually below 10 mg/L, pointing toward high risks associated with nano-Ag usage. The LC50 value of CuO NP is 2–3 mg/L for crustaceans and algae and 100 mg/L for protozoa and bacteria. ZnO NP exhibit pronounced activity against algae (<0.1 mg/L) and LC50 of 10–100 mg/L against fungi, protozoa, and yeast.
Few studies are directed toward the invivo effect of Ag NP accumulation in lower mammalian cells of species, such as rats and mice. Sung et al. [233] reported the impairment of lung functions due to inflammatory lesions in lung cells of the rat in a 90-day inhalation period. Another study conducted by Kim et al. [234] reported the accumulation of Ag in olfactory bulbs of rat and its subsequent transfer to brain tissues. In vitro studies conducted on mouse stem cells and rat liver cells indicate mitochondrial dysfunction and membrane leakage. The effects of nano-colloidal Ag of diameter 2–3 nm and 30 nm, and concentration 100 ppm on the skin condition of healthy rabbits were analyzed by Lee et al. [63]. Quite contrarily, the authors reported total skin innoxiousness for 2–3 nm NP and rare skin erythema for 30 nm NP, making 2–3 nm NP better suitable for textile applications. Gouda et al. [170] reported no clinical signs of skin erythema on adult albino rabbits patched with Ag oxide and zirconium oxide NP-impregnated cotton gauze fabrics for 4 days.
Limited study has been done to draw conclusion on the effect of human cells. Studies on topical application of Ag NP on human fibroblastic sarcoma cells (tumor cells) and carcinoma cells (cancer cells) show reduced levels of cellular glutathione indicating ROS generation and oxidative stress buildup [235]. In a study by Asharani et al. [236], the toxicity exerted by Ag NP was researched using human lung fibroblast cells and glioblastoma cells. The authors found evidences of interruption of mitochondrial respiration chain with oxidative stress generation, disruption of ATP synthesis, and DNA damage. Ag NP exerted cytotoxic effects on both types of cells in an equal manner, giving us food for thought about serious and long-term effects of Ag NP above the threshold dose. Although some literature could be found on toxicity of Ag NP, the toxicity data on CuO and ZnO NP are relatively

sections.heading: 96 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
sections.text:
rare. However, Kangwansupamonkon et al. [197] advocated non-toxicity of apatite-coated titania NP on normal human dermal fibroblast cells through MTT assay in the cytotoxicity test having cell viability over 70%.
In the present scenario, no safety organization committee has been set up for regulating synthesis and safe usage of NP. Different metal and metal oxide NP, even though possesses unique physico-chemical properties and has been classified as new class of materials according to material scientists worldwide, are chemically similar to their bulk counterparts and therefore carry commercially the same CAS number [67]. As a result, the NP are currently judged by the nano-toxicological effect on aquatic life based on the scale set for bulk materials, which is insufficient to provide substantial evidence pertaining to their non-toxic nature. While a legislative body for the regulation of NP is the need of the hour, a fundamental elucidation and understanding toward the path of activity against living cells and its effect on human health is equally important. Till then, control of usage of NP with lower dosedependent concentrations in applications directly in contact with human skin is to be considered for bringing down risk factors to a negligible level.

sections.heading: 2.6 Conclusion
sections.text:
A current glance at the literature suggests most researches are focused on antimicrobial textile materials based on Ag NP by wet processing, physical reduction, or green synthesis. However, other metal NP such as TiO2, Cu, CuO, and ZnO NP are also effective for fabricating antimicrobial textiles. The size and concentration of the NP plays an important role in demonstrating the strength of the antimicrobial effect with small NP of size 1–15 nm for Ag and Cu NP demonstrating the best activity at >50 ppm concentration (1–2 wt%) . The size of ZnO particles reported was higher, in the range of 30–40 nm but required less concentration (1 wt%) for successful inhibition. The antimicrobial activity of titania NP relying on its photo-catalytic activity provides best results in the presence of UV conditions alone, restricting its applications in the textile industry. Bacterial strains of S. aureus, E. coli, and K. pneumoniae are the most tested micro-organisms along with the fungal strain of C. albicans. However, most studies lack research on the effect of NP-reinforced textiles on cytotoxicity and allergic reactions to human subjects. A better understanding of NP release from textiles during washing or wear and tear and its subsequent action to the immediate environment is the need of the hour for a successful management of risk factors associated with the application and usage of NP.
