Shahid-ul-Islam and B.S. Butola (eds.) Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles, (163–186) © 2018 Scrivener Publishing LLC
5 Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite Materials for
Wastewater Treatment Mohammad Shahadat1,2,*, Ankita Jha1, Parveen Fatemeh Rupani3,
Asha Embrandiri4, Shaikh Ziauddin Ahammad1 and S. Wazed Ali2
1Department of Biochemical Engineering and Biotechnology, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, India 2Department of Textile Technology, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, India 3School of Environment and Safety Engineering, Jiangsu University, Zhenjiang,
China 4Department Of Environmental Studies, Kannur University, Kerala. India.
Abstract This chapter deals with the fabrication of cost-effective, eco-friendly chitosan (Ch)–graphene oxide (GO)-grafted nanocomposite (Ch–GO) for the removal of environmental pollutants (metal ions and dyes). Advanced characterization techniques such as SEM (scanning electron microscope), TEM (transmission electron microscopy), FTIR (Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy), TGA/DTA (thermogravimetric analysis/differential thermal analysis), RAMAN, XRD (X-ray diffraction), EIS (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy), and AFM (atomic-force microscopy) analyses are employed to investigate the improvement in physicochemical and mechanical properties of nanocomposite materials. Various characterization results clearly depict the existence of hydroxy, epoxy, and carboxyl groups (–OH, –OOH, and –COOH) in the matrix of Ch–GO nanocompiste as well as adsorption of metal and dye contaminates with higher metal removal efficiency. The adsorption behavior of the Ch–GO nanocomposite is elucidated in terms of the effect of pH, concentration, and temperature to achieve optimal removal capacity of pollutants. Kinetic studies establish quick adsorption followed by pseudo-first and pseudo-second and modified order kinetics. Thermodynamics
*Corresponding author: mdshahadat93@gmail.com
164 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
analysis reveals the measurement of free energy (ΔG°), enthalpy (ΔH°), and entropy (ΔS°). The excellent adsorption efficiency of Ch–GO nanocomposite materials confirms their application for the treatment of organic and inorganic contaminants in water bodies to control water pollution. In upcoming years, Ch– GO nanocomposite adsorbents are anticipated to release their possible significant applications in diverse fields.
Keywords: Chitosan, graphene oxide, fabrication, characterization, metal ions, dyes, water pollution

sections.heading: 5.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Discharging of dyes and metal ion containing effluents of various industries into water bodies has become the main cause of water pollution [1]. These effluents change the taste, odor, and property of water, which create a significantly bad impact to the life of aquatic flora and fauna [2]. Dyebased industries including printing, paper making, textile, and the paint industry are widely facing the problem of dye-contaminated wastewater [3]. Among the contaminated pollutants in industrial effluents, dyes are the most harmful substances which hinder penetration of sunlight into water and prohibit the photosynthesis of aquatic animals. In addition, these dye molecules affect the quality of water and result in carcinogenic influence [4]. Industrialization and urbanization have increased the discharging of metal ions, which include aluminum (Al), arsenic (As), cadmium (Cd), chromium (Cr), manganese (Mn), nickel (Ni), iron (Fe), zinc (Zn), lead (Pb), copper (Cu), and mercury (Hg) in soil, air, and water, which severely harm the environment [5–7]. These metal ions are consumed by the human through food or water, adsorbed in the body, and play a key role during cellular activity up to a certain limit [8–12]. The metal ions can be beneficial only up to a certain concentration. However, a higher concentration causes a number of physiological effects. Various metal ions together with their permissible limits according to the World Health Organization (WHO) are shown in Table 5.1.
Besides dyes and metal ions, other organic entities including insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, wood preservatives, and the use of antibiotics are also highly toxic, and affect body’s soft tissues and cause a number of diseases (e.g., gastrointestinal, carcinogenicity, etc.) [22–26]. Therefore, it is important to treat industrial effluents and solid wastes before discharging into water resources. In this regard, a number of chemical and biological treatment methods (e.g., flotation, chemical precipitation, electro-coagulation-flocculation, membrane filtration, ion exchange, modified bentonite clay, natural adsorbent, etc.) are used [6, 27–38]. These methods
Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite Materials 165
are associated with high-cost, time-consuming, pre-treatment procedures as well as are inconvenient for onsite analyses. As compared to conventional methods, adsorption by hybrid ion-exchange materials has gained popularity and is being effectively used for the removal of dyes and metal ions [11, 39–41]. However, there are certain drawbacks [42]. The limitations of composite materials have been overcome by the synthesis of chitosan–graphene-grafted nanocomposite adsorbents for the treatment of wastewaters.

sections.heading: 5.2 Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite
sections.text:
Recently, various methods and techniques have been developed to fabricate cost-effective polysaccharide adsorbents namely starch, cellulose, alginate, and chitosan [43]. Chitosan (Ch) is a low-cost, non-toxic, highly reactive multifunctional biomaterial which is obtained by the deacetylation of chitin [44] and shows higher adsorption efficiency owing to the existence of a large number of amino groups [45]. It has been successfully applied in
166 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
a number of fields such as the food industry, cosmetic, medicine, water treatment, etc. The presence of amine and hydroxyl groups makes the Ch as a potential biosorbent for the removal of metal ions in wastewaters due to the formation of stable metal chelates [46]. Chitosan is also associated with some limitations as it is soluble in the acidic medium except water and alkaline solutions. To improve mechanical strength and adsorption efficiency of Ch for the treatment of metal ions in aqueous media, efforts have been made to modify Ch with a suitable adsorbent [47]. In this regard, a new member of the carbon family, graphene (Gr), was selected for the modification of Ch owing to its unique structure (two-dimensional, oneatom-thick structure) together with high mechanical properties and high surface area [48]. One of the particular derivatives of graphene is known as graphene oxide (GO), which has attracted much attention for the adsorption of metal ions, dyes and other uses [49]. The GO consisting of various functional groups (–OH, –OOH, –COOH), which provide interfacial interaction with other adsorbent to synthesize thermally and chemically stable products as well as to improve other properties (hydrophilicity). In addition, these functional groups show strong binding affinity with metal ions and dyes molecules [49, 50]. The GO has been successfully applied in the form of effective adsorbent for the removal of metal ions (Cd(II), Co(II), and Cu(II)) from water [50, 51]. The GO-based membrane was developed using green-induced directional method [52]. The membrane was employed for the adsorption of Cu(II), Ni(II), and Cd(II) ions. The adsorption of metal ions on GO membranes was interrupted by weak ionic strength. Maximum adsorption of Cu(II), Ni(II), and Cd(II) on membrane was found to be 72.6, 83.8, and 62.3 mg g 1, respectively. Adsorption isotherm followed the Langmuir isotherm model and adsorption kinetics followed the pseudo-second-order model for the adsorption of metal ions. It has been noticed that the adsorption process reached equilibrium in a shorter period of time due to larger interlayer spacing of GO membranes. Based on recycling and regeneration study, the prepared GO membranes can be used more than six times without decline in adsorption capacity.
Yang et al. in 2010 demonstrated the interaction between positively charged ions on Cu(II) and negatively charged GO. It was able to remove Cu(II) ions [53–55]. The results have proved that GO can also be used for the adsorption of Pb(II), Cd(II), Co(II), and U(VI). However, it is noteworthy to mention that pH is an important factor in the adsorption of heavy metals using GO because the pH-dependent functional groups on the GO surface are the potential sites for metal adsorption. Zhang et al. reported the treatment of arsenate with 95% removal efficiency within 4–7 pH range using a cross-linked ferric hydroxide–GO composite [56]. The fabrication
Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite Materials 167
of composite was done by in situ oxidation of ferrous sulfate using hydrogen peroxide.
A recent study carried out by Zhu et al. indicated efficient adsorption of As(III) from contaminated water via Fe–Fe2O3 core shell coated with graphene [57]. Fe2O3 helps to increase adsorption sites whereas Fe core maintains the magnetic separation. This finding was explored by Luo et al. who observed that pH plays an important role for the adsorption of metal ions. The increase in the pH range improves the adsorption rate of MnO2 nanoparticles into Fe3O4–rGO materials. Therefore, MnO2 functions as a good oxidant for the effective adsorption of As(III) and As(V). There is a great application potential foreseen. The removal of Cr(VI) from polluted waters by catalytic reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) using iron-decorated grapheme sheets was reported by Humera et al. [58].
In another study, Zhu et al. [59] synthesized graphene-coated core double-shell nanoparticles for the removal of Cr(VI) from wastewater. This core was made up of crystalline iron while the outer shell was made up of iron oxide. The external shell covered an amorphous Si–S–O. Results indicated total removal of Cr(VI) in 5 min which could be separated from the solution using an external magnetic field. Metal ion induced self-assembly of a FeOOH–rGO hydrogel by the NH4OH reduction of FeSO4 and GO was fabricated by Cong et al. [60]. This composite proved to be effective in the removal of gasoline, Cr(VI), and Pb(II) from polluted water. Similarly, Sreeprasad et al. synthesized rGO–metal/metal oxide composites using a redox-like reaction between GO and the metal precursors, which resulted in the effective removal of Hg(II) from polluted water [61]. In the same vain, GO coated with TiO2 can be used in the removal of the heavy metal ions; Zn(II), Cd(II), and Pb(II) [61]. In order to increase the adsorption capacity of graphene, Polypyrrole–rGO hybrid was synthesized via a noncovalent functionalization of graphene sheets with polypyrrole [62]. The outcome indicated the growth of polypyrrole on the graphene sheets resulting in high surface area of mesoporous nature. The adsorption capacity is also affected by the ionic strength as it determines the concentration of heavy metal ions available for adsorption. 3D materials have also been applied in the adsorption of metal contaminants from polluted water [73]. This work was further extended by Li et al. [63] who revealed that polypyrrole–rGO nanosheets could be used in the removal of Cr(VI) from aqueous solutions. Sacrificial MnO2 nanoslices served as the composite material, with the polypyrrole retaining the morphology of the MnO2 nanostructure. As with 3D graphene materials, these polypyrrole materials show an increased adsorption capacity due to a change in the structure of composite material. Vasudevan and Lakshmi [64] proved that graphene
168 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
can be applied for the effective removal of phosphate ions from aqueous solutions. In this study, graphene was prepared by liquid phase exfoliation of graphite. This process establishes functional groups onto the graphene surfaces, which are vital for the phosphate adsorption. The authors concluded that this adsorption is spontaneous and chemically irreversible, with a maximum adsorption capacity of 89.4 mg g 1. Correspondingly, Li et al. [65] have shown that exfoliated graphene can be used to adsorb fluoride ions (monolayer adsorption capacity 35.6 mg g 1 at pH 7 and 298 K) from the solution. The results reveal that it cannot be effectively employed in industrial settings even though it has proven to be an effective adsorbent due to its irreversibility.
Thus, GO membranes have been effectively employed for the removal of heavy and toxic metal ions. However, self-association and van der wall interaction between GO layers inhibit their use in potential application [66]. To overcome all the drawbacks associated with native Ch and GO, chitosan–graphene-supported nanocomposite materials were synthesized using different chemical routes. The present chapter deals with the synthesis of chitosan–graphene-grafted nanocomposite materials and their application for the removal of metal ions and dyes from wastewaters.

sections.heading: 5.3 Removal and Recovery of Environmental Pollutants
5.3.1 Removal of Heavy Metals
sections.text:
Graphene oxide/chitosan (GO-Ch)-supported nanocomposite was fabricated for the removal of Cr(VI) ions [66]. The composite material was synthesized by the reaction of GO and Ch modified with disodium ethylene-diaminetetraacetate (EDTA-2Na) (GCE). In terms of adsorption capacity, GO-Ch-modified showed much more adsorption efficiency: 86.17 mg/g for Cr(VI) at pH 2 compared to unmodified Ch and established equilibrium in a short time (90 min). Interestingly, adsorption kinetics study covered a pseudo-second-order model together with intraparticle diffusion and film diffusion models. In between the Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms, the adsorption process was found to be best fitted for the Freundlich isotherm and demonstrated high value for the Freundlich constant (KF) which increased with increasing temperature leading to higher adsorption. Thermodynamics studies were spontaneous and highly endothermic nature at high temperature for the adsorption of Cr(VI) on GEC. The re-generation study confirmed the reusability of
Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite Materials 169
the GEC nanocomposite, which showed only 5% reduction in the adsorption efficiency after seven cycles. Thus, a higher adsorption capacity along with good re-generability of GEC makes the GEC a potential material for the removal of Cr(VI) ions in contaminated water. A comparative study regarding the adsorption behavior of GEC for the removal of Cr(VI) with other reported adsorbent is shown in Table 5.2.
A novel nanocomposite was synthesized by the implementation of amino-functionalized magnetic composite, CoFe2O4/chitosan/graphene [75]. Various characterization techniques including FTIR, XRD, and BET were employed to investigate morphology and chemical makeup of the composite. In addition, the effect of adsorption dose, pH, and contact time was determined to examine adsorption behavior of the composite. The optimal adsorption capacity of Ch-GO was found to be 361.0 mg/g at 323 K at neutral pH (7.0). Adsorption kinetics was established by the pseudo-first-order equation with a higher value of R2 (0.9976) as compared to pseudo-second-order kinetics. Adsorption isotherms were also studied at different temperatures, which confirmed the Langmuir isotherm model. The thermodynamic study revealed a spontaneous and endothermic nature of the adsorption process [76]. The synthesized nanocomposite of CoFe2O4/chitosan/graphene successfully reduced Hg(II) ions from the wastewater sample.
170 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
To improve the quality of wastewater, a hybrid of reduced graphene oxide (RGO)/chitosan/lysine (Ch) with PLL was developed using electropolymerization and cyclic voltammetry [77]. The pH of the solution plays an important role for the adsorption of metal ions in optimum yield; therefore, the optimal pH-4.5 was chosen due to protonation of hydrophilic groups that result in reduction in the metal ion adsorption. The synthesized electrode was effectively applied for the removal and recovery of Cd(II): 96.0–103.33%, Pb(II): 93.33–97.6%, and Cu(II): 96.66–101.33% in a tap water sample.
Triehtylenetetramine-based graphene oxide and chitosan (TGO-Ch) composites were developed by microwave irradiation and conventional heating method [78]. The adsorption of Cr(VI) was compared using both the above-mentioned methods. However, microwave irradiation resulted in higher yield. Optimal capacity of Cr(VI) was achieved (219.5 mg g 1) at pH 2 with 20 mg RGO-Ch (303 K). The adsorption kinetics followed pseudosecond-order kinetics and quick equilibrium adsorption (85%) was achieved in 20 min. A thermodynamic study established an endothermic and spontaneous process. The recycling study was performed to reuse the exhausted material after the adsorption process. The solvents, HCl and NaOH, were employed to desorb adsorbed Cr(VI) on TGO-Ch. The material showed 92.25% and 82.82% removal efficiency by using NaOH (1  mol  L−1) after three cycles; however, 80% removal capacity was archived after five cycles which confirmed the effective removal of Cr(VI) in waste water.
Another chitosan coating attapulgite (Ch-ATP) has been fabricated by self-assembly methodology and applied for the treatment of U(VI) in waste solutions [79]. In comparison to ATP and pure chitosan, modified Ch-ATP showed improved adsorption capacity of U(VI). Batch adsorption study and spectroscopic analyses confirmed the formation of inner-sphere complexes of U(VI) on the surface of Ch-ATP owing to the bonding of newly generated functional groups (i.e., -OH and -COOH). Under acidic conditions, the composite material revealed improvement in the adsorption of U(VI) in the presence of humic substances (HS); however, the alkaline medium restricted its adsorption capacity (desorption). The coordination of U(VI) with O2−  and –OH groups of Ch-ATP was confirmed by XPS analysis. It was observed that after sorption of uranium, the existence of specific band at ~382 eV verified high sorption capacity of Ch-ATP. Based on good adsorption capacity, eco-friendly and cost-efficient Ch-ATP can be effectively applied for the pre-concentration of U(VI) in contaminated water and nuclear reactor discharges.
Chandra et al. have synthesized magnetite-reduced graphene (MRGO) nanocomposites for the removal of arsenic in wastewater [80].
Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite Materials 171
Morphological investigation of the composite was done by FTIR and XRD techniques. The magnetic MRGO demonstrated superior paramagnetic behavior at room temperature and might be separated by an external magnetic flux. These composites show high binding capability toward As(III) and As(V) due to the formation of active or sorption sites in the matrix of reduced graphene. The composite material showed 99.9% arsenic removal efficiency in water.
Mercapto-grafted graphene oxide–magnetic chitosan (MC-GOCh) bio absorbent has been formulated for the pre-concentration and extraction of Hg(II) using a facile eco-friendly method [81]. Cold vapor atomic absorption spectroscopy was used for the detection of Hg(II). Maximum adsorption of mercury was achieved under optimal conditions of sorbent dose of 60 mg at pH 6.5 and surface assimilation time of 10 min by using 3 mL HCl (0.1M) and thiourea (2% w/v) for a breakthrough curve. An exceptional linear curve was obtained in 0.12–80  ng  mL−1  range (R2  =  0.999) together with a pre-concentration factor (80). The limit of detection (LOD) and limit of quantification (LOQ) were found to be 6.0 × 10 2 ng mL 1 and 12.0 × 10 2 ng mL 1, respectively. The value of relative standard deviation (4.7%) demonstrated good repeatability together with good recoveries (95 to 100%) of metal ions Hg(II) in real water.
A porous hybrid chitosan–gelatin/graphene oxide (ChG-GO) nanocomposite has been used for the removal of metal ions with significant recoveries (97%) [82]. The material was prepared by unidirectional freezedrying method and characterized using advanced techniques. Highly porous nature of ChG-GO was found owing to the development of new cavity in the matrix of a composite and the material showed selectivity for the detection of Cu(II) and Pb(II) ions. Physico-chemical parameters such as wet ability, absorption capacity, compressive strength, the effect of pH, concentration of GO, and metal ion along with the effect of EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) were determined for the optimal absorption of metal ions on the composite material. The improvement in absorption efficiency of ChG-GO was achieved (1700% to 2700%) by the enhancement in the content of GO (1% by wt.) in the matrix of monolith which increased porosity and surface area and resulted in higher adsorption capacity. The compressive strength composite monoliths increases with enhancing the content of GO in both states (dry and wet), which proved a strong interaction between the polymer matrix of chitosan and GO sheets. The composite material containing 5% GO showed higher (2.5 times) compressive strength as compared to 1% GO by weight. The adsorption efficiency of water increases due to the improvement in functional groups ( OH,
COOH) on the surface of ChG-GO composite and results in higher
172 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
adsorption of metal ions. The adsorption efficiency (Qs) of Pb(II) increases (68.5 to 99 mg/g) with the increasing content of GO (5 wt. %) in the ChG matrix. Moreover, 20% to 88% increment in the adsorption capacity of Pb(II) was found by the addition of EDTA. The ChG-GO nanocomposite showed 80% adsorption capacity after five desorption cycles which confirmed its ability for the treatment of metal ions.
Li et al. fabricated graphene-supported cyclodextrin-chitosan/graphene oxide nanocomposite (cycledex-Ch-GO) using a facile chemical route. The synthesized grafted nanocomposite has been used for the adsorption of Cr(VI) in an aqueous solution [83]. The magnetic property of cyclodexCh-GO was found due to the reaction of Fe3O4 with cyclodex-Ch-GO. Based on a high surface area, existence of –OH and –NH2 groups, the material has high potential to extract Cr(VI) from water under the influence of a magnetic field. The adsorption of Cr (VI) ions was followed by the Langmuir isotherm together with a maximum removal capacity of Cr(VI) at low pH (6.8) while chemical kinetics was followed by pseudo-secondorder kinetics. High performance of cyclodex-Ch-GO was due to its high surface area which caused optimal removal of Cr(VI) in wastewater.
An interesting work related to the removal of Cd(II), methylene blue (MB), and orange G (OG) using magnetic graphene oxide (MGO) nanocomposite has been reported by Deng et al. [84]. The pseudo-second-order model and the Langmuir isotherm model were found to be best fitted for maximum adsorption of Cd(II) (91.2 mg g 1), MB (64.23 mg g 1), and OG (20.85 mg g 1), respectively. The synthesized nanocomposites were also utilized for the removal of dyes from real water samples. It has been observed that in tap water samples, the natural process capability of Cd(II) was 65.39% from ultrapure water. However, the water samples had very little interference with the performance of MGO toward MB and OG, indicating that MGO was appropriated for the removal of ionic dyes as well as Cd (II) from real water. On increasing the concentration of MB, the adsorption capacity of Cd(II) was found to decrease. The GO showed a reversible trend (improvement in adsorption efficiency) in the binary systems of Cd(II)– MB and Cd(II)–OG, respectively. Therefore, there might be chances of interference of MB and OG with an MGO composite which demonstrated improved removal potential of dye molecules in water samples.
A hybrid of Fe3O4 SiO2-chitosan/GO (MS-Ch-GO) nanocomposite has been synthesized for the treatment of tetracycline (TC) in aquatic solutions [85]. Various parameters such as the effect of zeta potential, concentration of containment, and pH effect were examined. A pH range, 6.0–7.0, demonstrated the highest adsorption efficiency due to the lower electrostatics repulsion. The effect of concentration of TC and different metal ions
Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite Materials 173
(Na+, K+, Ca2+, and Mg2) revealed a maximum adsorption of 47.5 at pH 3.0 50.2 mmol kg 1 and 69.2 mmol kg 1 at pH 6.0 for TC, while in the absence of cations, the adsorption of TC onto MS-Ch-GO was found to be 50.2 mmol kg 1 at pH 3.0 to 67.6 mmol kg 1 at pH 6.0, respectively. The effect of Cu(II) concentration (0.1, 0.2 mM) was also examined to observe the change in the adsorption efficiency of TC on MS-Ch-GO. The improvement in the adsorption capacity of TC was found in the presence of Cu(II) on increasing the pH of the solution from 3.0 to 7.0. Moreover, at pH 7.0, the MS-ChGO composite showed the highest adsorption capacity for 0.1 mM and 0.2 mM Cu(II) as 173.60 mmol kg 1 and 183.47 mmol kg 1, respectively.  Improvement in the adsorption of TC in the presence of Cu(II) might be due to the formation of a complex among Cu (II) between TC and MSCG (where Cu(II) acts as bridge). Pseudo-second-order kinetics and Freundlich isotherm models were best fitted for the optimal adsorption of TC and metal ions.
Graphene-based GO-Ch-FeOOH nanocomposite has been fabricated by the reaction of graphene oxide, chitosan, and  FeS using the sol–gel chemical route [86]. The prepared material was investigated under various conditions of physico-chemical parameters, namely, sorbent mass, pH, temperature, shaking speed, and contact time. The synthesized material achieved better adsorption capacity toward the removal of Pb(II) which may be owing to the existence of new functional groups in the matrix of GO-Ch-FeOOH. The pH of solution also plays an important role for optimal adsorption of metal ions. The adsorption capacity of Pb(II) increased with increasing solution’s pH (from 3 to 5.5). After a pH of 5.5, a decline in the adsorption efficiency was found which may be due to the protonation of amine group (–NH2 to –NH3) as a result of electrostatic repulsion between NH3 and Pb(II). On the other hand, at higher pH, sufficient –OH
- adsorbed on the surface of composite led to the decline in the adsorption capacity of Pb(II). A thermodynamic study established the applicability of the Langmuir adsorption isotherm (on the basis of higher R2 value) compared to the Freundlich model. Thus, chitosan–graphene-based nanocomposites have a potential to treat wastewater for the removal of heavy metal ions. Chitosan-gelatin/GO (Ch-gel-GO) was used by Zhang et al. for the adsorption of heavy metals from aqueous solutions. In addition to this, Fan et al. [87] disclosed that a magnetic chitosan–rGO composite material can be exploited for the efficient removal of Cr(VI) from polluted waters.

sections.heading: 5.3.2 Treatment of Organic Pollutant
sections.text:
The removal of fuchsine dye from contaminated waters using magnetic graphene nanocomposites was investigated by Wang et al. [88]. Results
174 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
indicated high removal efficiency with fast adsorption time, rendering the composite a suitable material for purification of water. In recent studies, Fan et al. demonstrated that the adsorption capacity of methylene blue (MB) in polluted water can be enhanced by using a magnetic chitosan–rGO composite material [4]. Nguyen-Phan et al. reported that a 3D wormhole like mesoporous titanosilicate–rGO was used for the removal of methylene blue from waste water [89]. The effect of Ti dopant in an Si matrix was investigated which established that a high concentration of Ti (i.e., 20 mol%) enhanced the adsorption capacity of the composite. On the other hand, improvement in the concentration of Ti resulted in a negative effect on the photocatalytic dye degradation activity. Similar work was reported by Li et al. to fabricate a Mg(OH)2–rGO composite by the simultaneous reduction of MgCl2 and GO using NaOH [90]. Mg(OH)2 helped rGO to maintain a mesoporous structure and high surface area which proved to be beneficial for the removal of MB from water. Magnetic Ni-rGO nanocomposites were fabricated by the simultaneous hydrazine reduction of GO and NiCl2 [91]. A complete adsorption of organic dyes (RhB and MB) was achieved in 4 h. This work was repeated by Li et al., showing that a Ni–rGO nanocomposite material can be successfully used in the removal of aromatic compounds (benzene, toluene, and dimethylbenzene) from aqueous and non-aqueous solutions.
Graphene-coated biochar has been employed for the removal of Poly aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) [92]. As compared to native biochar, the adsorption capacity of biochar with graphene coating increased by 20 times. The P25–rGO composite material showed the potential to adsorb methylene blue from an aqueous solution by using a self-assembly process of P25 on the graphene sheets. An improvement in the adsorption capacity was achieved by using nanoribbons or nanotubes because of high surface area in nanosheets as compared to other nanostructures. Tifeng Jiao et al. evaluated the degradation capacity of methylene blue (MB) and Rhodamine B (RhB) from textile wastewater via GO-based composite hydrogels by selfassembly of Ch and GO in an in situ reduction approach [93]. The outcome of experiments indicated that prepared 3D GO-based hydrogels efficiently removed dyes and exhibited good photocatalytic performance for RhB and MB in accordance with the pseudo-second-order model. Authors concluded that chitosan molecule was incorporated to facilitate the gelation process of the GO sheets. For the removal of a pharmaceutical compound (dorzolamide) from biomedical synthetic wastewaters, a novel graphite oxide/poly(acrylic acid)-grafted chitosan nanocomposite (GO/Ch) was fabricated and used as a biosorbent [94]. GO-Ch showed a higher adsorption capacity in comparison with the parent materials (graphite oxide and
Chitosan–Graphene-Grafted Nanocomposite Materials 175
poly(acrylic acid)-grafted chitosan). It implied that the reactive groups of GO and Ch interact with amino groups of dorzolamide and the abundance of carboxyl groups of GO-CSA composite was the main reason for enhancing its adsorption capacity.
A novel magnetic bioadsorbent composite made up of magnetic chitosan and graphene oxide (MChGO) was prepared by Fan et al. [4]. Optimization of dye was achieved at pH 3, whereas pH 12 was preferable for desorption. Kinetic experiments presented relatively “fast” adsorption together with the best fitting of modified pseudo-second-order equation. The equilibrium data were fitted to the Langmuir, Freundlich, and Langmuir−Freundlich models, with maximum adsorption capacities (391, 401, and 425 mg g 1, respectively) at 25 °C, 45 °C, and 65 °C. In accordance with the thermodynamic theory, the positive values of ΔHº suggested endothermic nature of the adsorption while the negative values of ΔG° indicated high adsorption affinity for dye molecules. Synthesis of graphite oxide (GO) with magnetic chitosan (Ch) to form (GO-Ch) was also carried out to serve as an adsorbent for an industrial dye (Reactive Black 5) [95]. An effective synthesis method for the preparation of the MGCh nanocomposite material was conducted by Sheshmani et al. to treat Acid Orange 7 (AO7) [96]. Dye removal efficiency was highly dependent on medium pH, contact time, and adsorbent concentration. Data indicated that MGCh adsorbent has a good potential for the removal of dye in wastewater. Some important chitosan–graphenegrafted nanocomposites for water treatment are listed in Table 5.3.

sections.heading: 5.4 Conclusion
sections.text:
This chapter reports facile synthesis of chitosan–graphene (Ch-GO)supported nanocomposite materials using sol–gel chemical route and hydrothermal methods. These nanocomposites have been successfully employed for the removal of organic and inorganic pollutants. The Ch-GOgrafted material was selected on the basis of existence of different functional groups (–NH2, –H, –OOH) in the matrix of a composite which provides a porous nanostructure via hydrogen bonding and other interactions. Morphological characterization confirmed the formation of a porous nanocomposite of Ch-GO. The data of metal ion adsorption and dyes removal efficiency established that Ch-GO-based nano-materials have showed good pollution-removal potential. Based on the significant finding of chitosan– graphene, it is expected that the Ch-GO-based nanocomposite has momentous prospective to open new ways for their synthesis and applications in wastewater treatment. The achievement of environmentally stable Ch-GO

Shahid-ul-Islam and B.S. Butola (eds.) Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles, (187–218) © 2018 Scrivener Publishing LLC
6 Decolorization of Textile Wastewater
Using Composite Materials Sharf Ilahi Siddiqui1, Rangnath Ravi1, Geetanjali Rathi1, Nusrat Tara1,
Shahid-ul-Islam2 and Saif Ali Chaudhry1,* 1Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi, India
2Department of Textile Technology, IIT Delhi, New Delhi, India
Abstract Over the past few decades, large discharge of dyes from textiles industries in water bodies has been posing serious threat to environmental safety and society. Textile industries are the largest and fastest growing industries, therefore consuming a large amount of water and active ingredients such as dyes and coloration for the finishing of different fibers. These active ingredients enhance the chemical oxygen demand (COD), biological oxygen demand (BOD), and total organic compounds (TOC) of water and show toxic effects toward the human body. Therefore, reprocessing the polluted water is the only way to minimize the hazardous effects of these textile effluents. In this chapter, the issue of various dye discharges in water, their effect on human health, and advanced water treatment process using composite materials has been covered.
Keywords: Color water, dyes, remediation, adsorption, composites

sections.heading: 6.1 Introduction
sections.text:
The major environmental problem currently is the generation of effluents (pollutants) from the textile industry, leather industry, food industry, pulp and paper industry, and paint industry. These industries use large quantities of water for their processing and produce wastewaters with different chemical compositions [1]. Color water may be the most problematic.
*Corresponding author: saifchaudhary09@gmail.com
188 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
In general, textile industries largely discharge the color-containing water during the dyeing process. Asian countries, particularly India, have large textile industries that play a major role in their economics. More than 100,000 commercial dyes with over 7 105 tons of color stuff are produced and consumed every year. China is the largest exporter of color stuffs, whereas India is the second one. Worldwide, textile industries alone discharge more than approximately 10% of total discharged dyes [2, 3].
Color stuffs discharged in water enhance chemical oxygen demands (COD), biological oxygen demand (BOD), and total organic compounds (TOC) of water. These enhancements in BOD, COD, and TOC affect the aesthetic properties of water and are environmentally unacceptable. Moreover, these dyes may cover up the water surface, and reduce the amount of dissolved oxygen, and also reduce the penetration of light, which affect the photosynthetic activities of living creatures present in the water, thereby severely affecting the food source of aquatic organisms [3]. Dyes are non-biodegradable organic pollutants, and therefore, their degradation has become a major concern, which is not easy. Despite this, the removal
Textile Wastewater Treatment 189
of color stuffs from water or effluents is of great concern. To achieve the momentum in dye removal, it is necessary to develop more suitable treatment technologies with respect to cost, feasibility, practicability, reliability, stability, environmental impact, sludge production, operational difficulty, pre-treatment requirements, the extent of the removal, and the potential toxic by-products. Complete removal of color stuffs from water is sometime associated with the degradation of dye molecules, but it may not be applicable to all types of color stuffs [4–6]. It is a challenge for researchers to develop the economically and environmentally effective treatment technology.

sections.heading: 6.2 Classification of Dyes and Their Toxicity
sections.text:
Color stuffs, referred to as dyes, can absorb light in the visible range of the spectrum at a certain wavelength and has high affinity towards substrates on which applied. A large number of natural and synthetic dyes are being used in various industries [7, 8]. The food industry frequently uses natural dyes, while the textile industries use synthetic dyes. The chromophore groups such as –N=N–, =C=O, =C=C=, –C=NH, –CH=N–, NO, N–OH, –NO2 or –NO– OH, and –C=S are responsible for the color of dyes [9, 10] (Table 6.1).
Dyes are classified as acidic, basic, direct, disperse, mordant, pigment, reactive, solvent, sulfur, and vat dyes (Figure 6.1). Acidic, direct, mordant, and reactive dyes are anionic; basic dyes are cationic; whereas pigments, disperse, and solvent dyes are non-ionic [11, 12] (Table 6.2).
Anionic dyes, having amine (NH2), carboxy (COO ), hydroxy (OH -), and sulfonate (SO3 ) groups, acquire net negative charge, while cationic dyes has net positive charge due to protonation of amine or sulfur-containing groups. These dyes are highly visible, even at very low concentration, and absorb and reflect the sunlight entering water, thus hindering photosynthesis [13].
Moreover, they show acute and chronic effects toward living organisms depending on their concentration and length of exposure. Anionic and cationic dyes are used for the coloring of natural and synthetics fibers. Dyes containing –N=N– groups are called azo dyes which have a wide application in textile, leather tanning, paper production, food, color photography, pharmaceuticals and medicine, cosmetic, hair coloring, wood staining, agricultural, biological, and chemical research, light-harvesting arrays, and photo electrochemical cells [14].
Consequently, a large number of synthetic dyes having azo groups are being released into the environment. Various synthetic azo dyes having low toxicity are being applied to various substances. These dyes usually
190 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
produce aromatic amines on anaerobic reduction of –N=N– groups which can be toxic and harmful [15].
Large exposure of dyes shows allergic, mutagenic, teratogenic, and carcinogenic effects toward the human body; moreover, it causes bladder cancer, splenic sarcomas, and hepato carcinomas [16–18]. Generally, complex
Textile Wastewater Treatment 191
dyes and basic dyes are carcinogenic due to the presence of metals and aromatic rings.
These dyes have a high intensity of color which decrease the sunlight penetration in water and affect the photosynthetic activity of aquatic life. Azo dyes have toxic amines groups; anthraquinone-based dyes do not degrade in water; and reactive dyes are highly soluble in water, which produce serious troubles in the environment. These colorants can also produce numerous dysfunctions in the kidneys, reproductive system, liver, brain, and central nervous system in the human body. Moreover, the release of dyes also alter the pH values to either extreme acidic or alkaline, and high temperatures, high BOD, COD, solid, oil, and possibly toxic organics that include phenols into water which may change the water quality and cause large physiological and biochemical changes in water. These changes in water quality show hazards toward aquatic plant and fishes [19, 20]. Therefore, focus on specific methods and technologies to remove dyes from different kinds of wastewater streams is desired.

sections.heading: 6.3 Decolorization of Colored Water
sections.text:
The treatment of colored water, before discharge in water bodies, and reuse of dye-contaminated water after the treatment process have become an emerging issue for cleaning the environment. The removal of color from dye-contained wastewater is a subject of prime concern
192 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
for scientist. Government agencies from various countries have become very stringent regarding the discharge of dyes as effluents from industrial units. Environmental agencies in both developed and developing countries are making efforts to ensure that the industries treat their color effluents to follow given standards. Moreover, maximum concentration limits of color stuffs in water have also been set. However, most of the industries do not follow these guidelines and discharge large a concentration of color stuffs in water and cause hazardous effects. Thus, treatment of these colorants in water before discharge and consumption is necessary.
Color water treatment (decolorization) is based on either photocatalytic degradation of color substance through the bond breakages or complete removal of color substance. Decolorization of water is the result of shifts of absorption of light from the visible to the ultraviolet or infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum.
Various technologies such as nano-filtration, reverse osmosis, electrodialysis, coagulation, flocculation, electro-flotation, electro-kinetic coagulation, oxidation, irradiation, or electrochemical processes, and aerobic and anaerobic microbial degradation have been utilized for the decolorization of water [21–25] (Table 6.3). However, various disadvantages, such as high cost, low efficiency, limited versatility, need for specialized equipment, interference by other wastewater constituents, large production of sludge, and poor handling of the generated waste, are associated with these methods. Various technologies used in decolorization of colored water have been discussed in several reports [26]. The development of efficient, economic, and eco-friendly technologies for decolorization of the colored water is very important. Being a surface phenomenon, adsorption is being utilized as an eco-friendly and economical treatment process to reduce dye contents in the water system.
Textile Wastewater Treatment 193

sections.heading: 6.4 Sorption Technology
sections.text:
The adsorption process is a surface phenomenon, and involves the interaction between the adsorbate (solute) and the adsorbent (solid surface). Small-sized particle, high surface area, large number of active sites, and magnetic character of adsorbent respond to the higher removal capacity of dyes [27].
This phenomenon is known to be simple, inexpensive, and efficient for the dye removal from water or wastewater. Moreover, it does not require the pre-treatment step before its application. Besides, sorption needs less working area, has lower sensitivity to diurnal variation, does not produce toxic chemicals, and is flexible in design and operation.
Adsorbent and dye interact either physically or chemically during the sorption process. Physical interactions involve weak bonding such as van der Waals, hydrogen, and dipole–dipole, while chemical interactions are characterized by strong inter-particle bonds, such as covalent, and ionic bonds, due to an exchange of electrons. Adsorption mechanism and their kinetics can be devised from the application of both linear and nonlinear isotherms to equilibrium data, and various kinetic relationships, respectively [28, 29]. Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms are most commonly used to quantify the amount of adsorbate adsorbed by an adsorbent.
The enhanced remediation of dye contents has been observed by using various solid supports. As already stated, various factors such as dye/sorbent interaction, sorbent surface area, particle size, temperature, pH, and contact time largely affect the sorption capacity of the solid surface [30].
The molecular size of dye and the number of groups attached to the dye are also responsible for adsorption fluctuation. Adsorbents having a large surface area, large active sites, and porous in nature may significantly remove dye molecules; however, the smaller size of dye particles may effectively be adsorbed than bigger molecules. This is due to diffusion limitations [31].

sections.heading: 6.5 Recent Development in Adsorption Technology
sections.text:
Numerous adsorbents, such as activated carbon [32], biomasses [33], clay minerals [34], zeolites [35], waste materials [36], and metal-based adsorbents [37], have been used for the adsorptive removal of dyes. Metal-based adsorbents, particularly metal oxides, have expertise in effective removal of dyes [38].
194 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
The repeating cycle of the used adsorbent enhances its adsorption efficiency. Attempts have been made for the regeneration of exhausted adsorbents via desorption of dyes using an acid or a base [39, 40]. However, this step requires the separation of exhausted adsorbents from water. Filtration and centrifugation are adopted for the separation of exhausted adsorbents but now is avoided due to high cost processing. Surprisingly, newly developed magnetic adsorbents are having an advantage over filtration and centrifugation due to low cost, easy handling, and response to a low magnetic field.
In addition, it has been estimated that functionalized and stable magnetic nano-sized adsorbents can be most attractive and an advanced technique for water purification [41–43]. Functionalized adsorbents, having large hydroxyl or other function groups on their surface, can strongly trap the dye contents at various pH [44] (Figures 6.2 and 6.3). Therefore, a large number of eco-friendly, functionalized nano adsorbents have been developed with remarkable potential for dye remediation from water, waste water, and aqueous solution. Stabilized and functionalized adsorbents could be achieved by functionalization of nanoparticles through organic materials such as polymer and higher acids.
However, the drawback associated with functionalized adsorbents is the detachment of NPs from organic parts during the treatment process. This may cause toxicity on long-term accumulation of NPs in water. Therefore, various environmentally sound and stable adsorbents were developed and preferred for the dye remediation [45].
Recent development in advance water treatment technology is the production of flexible, thermally, and mechanically stable and magnetic multi-functional units, having a large number of special features for
Textile Wastewater Treatment 195
decolorization of colored water. These developed multifunctional units are referred to as composites, which could be achieved by certain size scale mixing of various materials such as inorganic particles and biopolymer, polymer, oxidizing, or reducing agents, and other carbonaceous materials through methods such as co-precipitation, sol–gel, etc. [46].
Recently, the mixing of inorganic and organic components at the nanometric scale provided the advancement in water purification techniques. These types of materials are referred to as organic–inorganic hybrid nanocomposite. Therefore, application of this sorption technique would be the nourishing step, under above-mentioned factors, to meet discharge color standards. For easing the way of young scientists for the search and development of more adsorbents, herein, we have listed (Table 6.4) the most latest available literature on recently used composites for dyes removal. This chapter will help the scientific community to improve the quality of the water treatment process.

sections.heading: 6.6 Removal of Dyes Using Composites
sections.text:
Recently, Zn-Al double-layered hydroxides (ZnAl–LDHs-3) have been developed via hydrothermal method for the removal of three different types of dyes such as Congo red, Methyl orange, and Active red (X-3B) [47]. The maximum absorption capacity of ZnAl–LDO–3 was observed as 1540, 1153, and 390 mg/g for Congo red, Methyl Orange, and Active Red (X-3B), respectively. These adsorbents have been proved the most potential adsorbent for dye containing wastewater treatment. Long et al. [48] developed the magnetic composite, Fe3O4@catechol/PEI, by the co-polymerization of catechol and branched polyethylenimine (PEI) onto Fe3O4 nanoparticles under the alkaline condition. The prepared hybrid material was used for

Textile Wastewater Treatment 203
the removal of three different kinds of anionic dyes, Methyl Blue, Orange G, and Amaranth, from aqueous solutions. Adsorption data well fitted to the pseudo-second-order kinetic model and Langmuir isotherm, and the maximum monolayer adsorption capacities for Methylene Blue, Orange G, and Amaranth were 344.8, 192.3, and 146.2 mg/g, respectively. An advance feature of adsorbents is their separation on application of a low magnetic field at equilibrium.
Similarly, magnetic Fe@graphite nanocomposite (Fe@G-N) was also developed for the adsorptive removal of anionic dyes from aqueous solutions [49]. Two anionic dyes, Acid Red 88 (AR88) and Direct Orange 26 (DO26), were removed from aqueous solutions at different parameters, such as initial dye concentration (5–40 mg/L), pH of solution (4–10), and temperature (20–60 °C). The adsorption results obtained from batch experiments suggested that the kinetic of the reaction well fitted to the pseudosecond-order model, and the isotherm well followed both Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption models. Magnetic hydrogel beads, a modified gum tragacanth/graphene oxide, were used for the adsorptive removal crystal violet (CV) and Congo red (CR) from their solutions [50]. The observed result showed that adsorption kinetics was well addressed by the pseudosecond-order kinetic model and isotherm by the Langmuir isotherm model where the maximum monolayer adsorption capacity for CV and CR was 94.0, and 101.74 mg/g, respectively. In addition, the prepared adsorbent could be reutilized for three adsorption–desorption cycles without any significant loss of adsorption capacity.
Another magnetic composite, MCM-41, has been utilized for decolorization of colored water [51]. Composite materials were developed by the surfaceinitiated atom transfer radical polymerization (SI-ATRP) of (3-aminopropyl) triethoxysilane (APTES) and poly (glycidyl methacrylate) p(GMA), followed by the functionalization with tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TAEA). The modified material was utilized as an adsorbent for cleaning of Direct Blue 6 (DB-6) and Direct Black-38 (DB-38) dyes from an aqueous medium. The magnetic character of the composite material was investigated by the VSM technique which showed the saturation magnetization at 19.6 emu/g. The adsorbent was found to be highly effective for the removal of both dyes at a wide pH range of 4.0–7.0, and the experimental data well fitted to the Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetic model. The magnetic composite was very stable, and could easily be separated and regenerated.
A cross-linked polyhedral oligosilsesquioxane (POSS)-based hybrid inorganic–organic nanohybrid having a specific surface area of 42.8 m2/g was also fabricated for adsorptive removal of acidic dyes, Methyl orange (MO) [52]. The cross-linked adsorbent was fabricated through the Schiff
204 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
base chemistry using octa-amino POSS as building blocks and glutaraldehyde as a dual functional reagent. The hybrid inorganic–organic nanohybrid was confirmed by FTIR spectroscopy. MO could effectively be removed from the aqueous solution with a maximum monolayer adsorption capacity of 237.5 mg/g. The reaction rate was well explained by the pseudo-second-order kinetic model and the reaction was spontaneous and exothermal. The specialty of the adsorbent was that it could effectively be regenerated using the methanol/NaOH (9:1) mixture.
Another cross-linked composite, cross-linked activated organo-bentonite (AO Bent)/sodium alginate (SA), has been developed for cationic and anionic dyes cleanup from aqueous solutions [53]. The AO Bent/sodium alginate (SA) composite was prepared by the intercalation of sodium alginate in activated organo-bentonite, and the cross-linking between sodium alginate and chlorohydric acid was confirmed from the X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA), and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). Furthermore, batch experiments were performed to remove cationic dye, Methylene blue, and anionic dye, Methyl orange, from their aqueous solutions. Adsorption data obtained from the batch experiment were well fitted to the pseudo-second-order kinetic model and Langmuir model. The prepared adsorbent was considered as cost effective and ecofriendly.
Similarly, a magnetically recoverable porous cross-linked polyethylenimine (MPEI) composite was developed for enhanced adsorptive removal of six anionic dyes [54]. Sorption mechanism and rates were well explained by the Langmuir monolayer adsorption and the pseudo-second-order kinetic model. The reaction was endothermic and spontaneous. Anionic dyes having the –SO3
− group were electrostatically adsorbed on to the positively charged MPEI, which was confirmed by the FT-IR and EDX spectra of dye-loaded MPEI. In addition, composite materials could easily be regenerated in an alkaline medium and utilized for a number of cycles. Salama et al. [55] fabricated carboxymethyl cellulose-grafted polymethacrylic acid (CMC-g-PMAA) having extraordinary adsorption behavior for Methylene blue, which exhibited extremely high removal capacity. The maximum monolayer adsorption capacity of the hybrid material for Methylene blue was found to be 671 mg/g. Reaction kinetics followed the pseudo-second-order model.
In the same year, Sun et al. [56] synthesized magnetic MnFe2O4/diatomite composite via the precipitation/hydrothermal method for cationic dyes such as methylene blue and basic fuchsine (rosaniline hydrochloride) dyes remediation. The adsorption process was fast and the maximal
Textile Wastewater Treatment 205
adsorption capacity for methylene blue and basic fuchsine obtained was 104.06 and 284.09 mg/g, respectively. The sorption process was recorded as an endothermic and spontaneous reaction.
Similarly, magnetic chitosan/SiO2/CNTs (MNCSC) nano-composite was utilized for direct blue 71 (DB71), and Reactive blue 19 (RB19) cleaning from aqueous solutions under various parameters such as initial dye concentration, contact time, adsorbent dosage, initial pH, etc. [57]. The monolayer maximum adsorption capacity of MNCSC was achieved at 61.35 and 97.08 mg/g for DB71 and RB19, respectively. Three different kinds of kinetic models were applied but the pseudo-second-order equation well fitted the adsorption data. The sorptions of anionic dyes have also been investigated on two prepared adsorbents, isoreticular nanoporous Zn(II)-MOFs (TMU-16) and TMU-16-NH2 [58]. Results demonstrated that TMU-16-NH2 showed a higher removal capacity than TMU-16 due to hydrogen bonding between dyes and amine groups.
Low-cost and ecofriendly zinc oxide-loaded activated carbon (ZnO-AC) was also applied for the treatment of organic dyes such as Orange G (OG) and Rhodamine B (Rh-B) [59]. The optimized adsorption capacity of ZnO-AC for OG and Rh-B was 153.8 and 128.2 mg/g, respectively. The sorption reaction was endothermic up to a temperature of 40 °C; however, the removal of OG decreased with increased temperature. Similarly, Dil et al. [60] utilized zinc (II) oxide nanorod-loaded activated carbon (ZnONRs-AC) for the removal of azo dye from the aqueous solution and optimized their removal capacity under different parameters including initial concentration, adsorbent dosage, pH, temperature, ultrasonic time, etc. At an initial concentration of 18 and 14 mg/L of Methylene blue and Crystal violets, respectively, the maximum adsorption capacity was recorded as 83.9 and 81.6 mg/g for MB and CV dyes, respectively.
Recently, nano-magnetite Fe3O4 nanoparticles were impregnated onto the walnut shell (Fe3O4-WNS), and used for the removal of methyl violet and rRhodamine 6G dyes from their aqueous solutions [61]. Various models such as multiple linear regression, random forest, and artificial neural network were applied to predict the removal efficiency of magnetic adsorbent against these dyes. Han et al. [62] synthesized the hydrophobic surface-modified silica aerogel (MSA) and hydrophilic (hydroxyl-group) silica aerogel (HSA) which could remove Rhodamine B (RhB) and Methylene blue (MB) from aqueous solutions. The surface area of prepared MSA and HSA was 880.47 and 628.52 m2/g, respectively, which was much higher than silica aerogel. Due to a large surface area, MSA and HSA removed 65.74 and 47.21 mg/g of Methylene blue, and 134.25 and 185.61 mg/g of
206 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
RhB, respectively. The reaction mechanism of monolayer and kinetics followed the pseudo-second order.
Recently, Fe3+ ions (FeCl3.6H2O) were introduced into bagasse biomass to achieve a novel magnetic porous adsorbent, g-Fe2O3/C, for the catalytic degradation and removal of methylene blue (MB) from the aqueous solution (Figure 6.4) [94]. The g-Fe2O3/C exhibited handsome adsorption and catalytic degradation abilities for MB. Similarly, quince seed mucilage (QSM)-based magnetic nanocomposite adsorbent (MNCA) has been developed by the in situ formation of magnetic iron oxide nanoparticles into the QSM solution for biosorption of MB from the aqueous solution (Figure 6.5a–c) [95]. Batch experiments were performed to optimize the adsorption capacity of MNCA for MB under the influence of various parameters. The process was spontaneous and exothermic following the pseudo-second-order kinetics. A Langmuir adsorption isotherm model was well fitted to the experimental data tested for MB, and the maximum monolayer adsorption capacity was 179 mg/g. These results indicate that the hybrid composite can be employed as efficient low-cost adsorbents with excellent dye adsorption performance in the wastewater treatment process. These were some recent advancements in the dye cleanup technology which made the process significant for dye remediation from water.
Textile Wastewater Treatment 207

sections.heading: 6.7 Adsorption Mechanism
sections.text:
The structure and functional behavior of the dye molecule, surface characteristics of the adsorbents, mass transport process, and so on decide the adsorption capacity of adsorbents. Dyes are planar as well as complex molecules, which can be easily adsorbed on to the hybrid composite having a large number of oxygenous functional groups by electrostatic attraction
208 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
and hydrogen-bonding interactions. The bonding between the adsorbent surface and dye molecules can be simply characterized by the FTIR spectrum. The possible interaction mechanisms between the adsorbents and dye molecules have been discussed in various literatures [96–100]. They compared the FTIR spectrum of unloaded adsorbents to dye-loaded adsorbents and revealed that the characteristic peaks for the dye-loaded adsorbents were broadened and shifted slightly. For example, Liu et al. [96] investigated the mechanism of anionic dye acid blue 93 (AB93) and cationic dye methylene blue (MB) adsorption by a cellulose-based bio adsorbent. Both AB93 and MB were planar molecules that could be easily adsorbed on the cellulose-based bioadsorbents by van der Waals force and hydrogen-bonding interactions. To confirm the mechanism, they compared the FTIR spectrum (Figure 6.6) of cellulose-based bioadsorbents and dye-loaded cellulose-based bioadsorbents, and revealed that the OH/NH stretching vibration broadened and shifted from 3434 to 3429 and 3424 cm−1, CO-NH stretching vibration shifted from 1667 to 1672 and 1655 cm−1, COO− asymmetric stretching vibration shifted from 1564 to 1582 and 1559 cm−1, COO− symmetric stretching vibration from 1411 to 1402 and 1402 cm−1, and the C–OH plane shifted from 1330 to 1347 and 1325 cm−1 for AB93 and MB adsorbed cellulose-based bioadsorbents, respectively. No significant change was found for the peak corresponding to CH stretching vibration at 2942 cm−1.
Textile Wastewater Treatment 209
These shiftings in the characteristics peaks for cellulose-based bioadsorbents suggested the specific electrostatic and hydrogen bonding interactions between the functional groups of dye molecules and the adsorbent (Figure 6.7). A number of literature on the basis of FTIR spectrum studies are now available to understand the dye adsorption mechanism for composites which generally suggested that electrostatic and hydrogen-bonding interactions are responsible for dye adsorption on to the composite surface [97–100]. Besides the electrostatic attraction and hydrogen-bonding interactions, complexation between the metallic sites of the adsorbent and electron-donating sites of dyes or π–π interactions between the π electrons in a carbonaceous adsorbent such as graphene oxide and the π electron in the aromatic ring of a dyes are also responsible for the adsorption of dyes onto the adsorbent surfaces.
To understand the π–π interactions between π electrons in a carbonaceous adsorbent such as graphene oxide and the π electron in the aromatic
210 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
ring of a dye, Tran et al. [97] investigated the mechanisms of sorption of methylene green 5 (MG5) on to the commercial activated charcoal, synthesized activated carbons, and prepared biochar (Figure 6.8). They suggested that π–π interactions majorly contributed to the adsorption of MG5 on to the adsorbent surface. The π–π interactions between the MG5 and the adsorbent surface could be confirmed by the FTIR analysis which showed that a peak corresponding to the skeletal vibration of aromatic C-C bonds decreased in intensity and upshifted after MG5 adsorption. Similarly, Chen et al. [101] also suggested that the π–π interactions played a major role in the dye adsorption mechanism.

sections.heading: 6.8 Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, we incorporated the study and features of various recently used, novel, inexpensive, magnetic, and some nonmagnetic adsorbents, which efficiently removed and degraded several dyes from aqueous
Textile Wastewater Treatment 211
solutions. Adsorbents having large adsorption capacities for several dyes are added herein. The obtained concluding remark is that the porous, high surface sites containing adsorbents such as organic–inorganic nanocomposites show excellent magnetism, superior adsorption capacity, and have excellent catalytic degradation ability for dyes. Thus, on including the list of adsorbents, and the study of inexpensive adsorbents, a more suitable and conventional method can be obtained at a certain interval of time that has great potential for the clean-up of environmental pollutants.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The Financial support from the University Grant Commission, UGC, India, and Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia, New Delhi, India, is gratefully acknowledged.

sections.heading: 7.1 Introduction
sections.text:
The level of environmental pollution has increased alarmingly due to rapid growth of industrialization and urbanization [1–3]. Hexavalent chromium [Cr (VI)] and dyes contribute to a significant extent toward environmental pollution. Wastewater containing approximately 170,000 tons of chromium is being discharged into different water bodies every year all over the world [4]. Similarly, about one million kilograms of dyes released from textile industries are being discharged into rivers and streams each year worldwide [5–7].
Cr (VI) is carcinogenic, mutagenic, and teratogenic. It causes a wide range of clinical/health problems such as damage to the liver and kidneys, lung carcinoma, nausea, dermatitis, nasal membrane inflammation, ulceration, irritation of the gastrointestinal tract, and renal damage as shown in Figure 7.1, when consumed above the permissible limit of 50 μg L-1 in potable water as fixed by the US EPA [8–10]. The compounds of Cr (VI) are mostly used in different industrial processes such as metal plating, leather tanning, and pigment manufacturing. Effluents containing high Cr (VI) concentration from these industries are discharged into the aquatic environments [11–13]. Being highly mobile in an aqueous environment, it contaminates the natural water ecosystems easily.
Dyes are also considered to be toxic or carcinogenic. Due to the complex aromatic structure and synthetic origin of dyes, these possess high chemical stability and low biodegradability in water. It causes a major problem in the discharge of large quantities of organic compounds in wastewater and becomes potentially harmful to the environment. Thus, treatment of industrial wastewater containing Cr (VI) and dyes has become an important and urgent environmental issue. Therefore, various physical, chemical,
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 221
and biological techniques such as precipitation [14], ion exchange [15], membrane filtration [16], electrochemical approaches [17], reverse osmosis [18], and adsorption [19] have been proposed for the treatment of waste water rich in Cr (VI) and toxic dyes. However, most of these techniques find a number of drawbacks such as high operational cost, low feasibility of scale-up for industrial applications, and ineffectiveness at high concentrations. On the other hand, adsorption has been recognized as one of the most promising techniques for the treatment of Cr (VI) from wastewater due to its several advantages which include high removal efficiency, low energy consumption, less chemical investment, and reusability [20–22]. Hence, different kinds of adsorbents such as activated carbon [23], biomass [24], clay minerals [25], zeolites [26], industrial and agricultural wastes [27, 28] have been used for the removal of Cr (VI) and dyes from the wastewater. Practical applications of these adsorbents are restricted because of low adsorption capacities and selectivities, which is due to less porosity, low surface area, lack of functional groups, and small dye-binding constants [29]. Thus, there was an urgent need for the development of adsorbents having high porosity, large surface area, and high functionalities.
In recent years, nanomaterials have attracted great attention worldwide for various applications. Besides these, they are also being used as potential adsorbents in wastewater treatment due to their large surface area, enough active surface sites, and high adsorption capacity [30].
222 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
Silica-based nanomaterials [31], graphene-based nanomaterials [32], titanate nanotubes [33], ferrites [34], layer double hydroxides [35], etc. have recently been successfully applied for the adsorption of Cr (VI) and various noxious dyes. In this chapter, we have discussed the adsorption behavior of silica-based nanomaterials, titanate nanotubes, and layer double hydroxides (Figure 7.2) in terms of adsorption capacities, isotherm models, kinetics, and thermodynamics of adsorption. Maximum adsorption capacities obtained under optimum adsorption conditions such as adsorbent dose, concentration of Cr (VI) solution and dyes solution, pH, and temperature were presented in the tables. Detailed illustrations of mechanisms of adsorption were given in the form of figures. A roadmap describing the scope of the chapter is given in Figure 7.3.
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 223

sections.heading: 7.2 Mesoporous Silica (m-SiO2)
sections.text: Silica exhibits good physical and chemical properties such as water stability (nonswelling), thermal stability (up to 1500 °C), and good mechanical strength. Different kinds of silica materials such as amorphous silica, mesoporous silica, fumed silica, and silica gels have been synthesized. Among these, mesoporous silica is extensively used in various applications due to its high surface area and large number of of silanol (Si−OH) groups. Particularly, these are considered as high-capacity adsorbents as they exhibit enhanced accessibility to active centers [36] and fast mass transfer rates in the regular porous environment [37, 38]. Various ordered mesoporous silica materials such as SBA-15, USG-41, MCM-41, and their modified forms are used as adsorbents for the removal of Cr (VI) and dyes in recent years.

sections.heading: 7.2.1 Adsorption of Cr (VI) on to Mesoporous Silica
sections.text:
Barium titanate mesoporous silica (BaTiO3/SBA-15) prepared by an aerosol-assisted solid-state reaction using SBA-15 as a hard template exhibited high adsorption capacity as compared to bulk BaTiO3 and pure SBA-15. It might be attributed to its high porosity and large surface area, which enhanced the oxy-anionic species of chromium to get adsorbed at the internal surface of the pores. Moreover, the development of a positive surface charge on the nanomaterial due to oxygen vacancy adsorbed negatively charged Cr (VI) species effectively by electrostatic interactions [39]. SBA15 nanoparticles modified with 3-aminopropyltrimethoxy-silane exhibited an improved adsorption capacity of 48.31 mg g-1. These nanoparticles with a large pore size distribution facilitated surface functionalization due to which there was coordination of Cr (VI) species on their surfaces leading to higher adsorption. 3-aminopropyltrimethoxy-silane-functionalized USG-41 nanoparticles with a broad pore size distribution exhibited still higher adsorption capacity of 111.1 mg g-1. MCM-41 nanoparticles moldified with 3-aminopropyltrimethoxy-silane with a narrow pore size distribution exhibited low adsorption capacity of 39.68 mg g-1 [40]. Immobilization of TiO2 onto MCM-41 provides adequate number of active sites on the surface of TiO2-MCM-41. As a result, the adsorbent showed an enhanced adsorption capacity.
The sample with 20 weight percentage (4.0 mmol g-1) TiO2 exhibited a maximum adsorption capacity of 120.64 mg g-1. Less uptake of the sample with 25 weight percentage (5.02 mmol g-1) TiO2 might be attributed to the loss of ordered hexagonal structure of MCM-41that led to irregularity in
224 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
the surface sites. The mechanism of adsorption was shown in Scheme 7.1, which indicated that positive charges were developed on the surface of the adsorbent below the pHZPC (i.e., 6.2) due to which negatively charged univalent Cr (VI) species (HCrO4
-) were adsorbed through electrostatic attraction below this pH (i.e., 5.5). At very low and high pH, adsorption is decreased because bivalent Cr (VI) species namely Cr2O7
2- at lower pH and CrO4
2- at higher pH were the dominant ones which would neutralize twice the number of active sites available on the surface of adsorbents as compared to univalent species [31]. This led to a decrease in adsorption at both lower and higher pH values [41]. Moreover, a decrease in adsorption at higher pH might be attributed to the fact that the typical siliceous hexagonal structure of MCM-41 was destroyed above pH 8.0 [42]. However, maximum adsorption capacity of 904 mg g-1 was obtained for MCM-41 samples with a large surface area and uniform diameter [43]. This indicated not only active sites but also large surface area and uniform particle size are responsible for enhanced adsorption capacity. Maximum adsorption capacity and optimum adsorption conditions such as pH, temperature, initial Cr (VI) concentration, adsorbent dose, fitted isotherm, kinetic model, thermodynamic parameters, and mechanism of adsorption for Cr (VI) onto mesoporous silica are given in Table 7.1.

adsorbent (film diffusion). (ii) Transport of the dye within the pores of the adsorbent, with only a small amount of dye being adsorbed on the external surface (particle diffusion). (iii) Adsorption of the dye on an inner surface of the adsorbent.
Huang et al. have synthesized ordered SBA-15 using nonionic surfactant as a template in acidic conditions and studied the adsorption behaviors of cationic dyes such as methylene blue (MB) and Janus Green B (JGB), an anionic dye [reactive black 5 (RB 5)], and a neutral dye named dimethyl phthalate (DMP) [7]. The structural formula of (a) MB, (b) JGB (c) RB 5 and (d) DMP are given in Figure 7.4. SBA-15 has shown enhanced adsorption capability toward cationic dyes due to the electrostatic attraction between cationic dyes and the anionic nature of SBA-15 whereas it does not absorb any anionic and neutral dyes. The adsorption capacities for MB and JGB were found to be 49.25 and 66.43 mg g-1, respectively, and adsorption isotherms were well fitted with Langmuir and Freundlich models.
A facile non-polar solvent-assisted Stöber method has been developed by Wang et al. to synthesize ordered mesoporous silica materials with tunable pore size, diverse morphologies, and mesostructures by using cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) as the template and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as a silica precursor in a simple aqueous-phase synthesis system [44]. By simply changing the amount of n-hexane and aqueous ammonia in the system, ordered mesoporous silica with a pore size of 2.7–10.5 nm, various morphology (nanocubes, truncated nanocubes, coreshell microspheres, and twisted nanorods), high surface area up to 888 m2 g-1, and large pore volume of 1.55 cm3 g-1 are synthesized (Figure 7.5). Owing to their highly hydrophilic surface, large and accessible pores, and high surface area, the mesoporous silica materials exhibit an excellent performance in the adsorption of dye molecules of a large dimension (1.6 nm) with a maximum adsorption capacity of 106 mg g-1 in 10 min at 200 mg L-1 initial Rhodamine B (RhB) concentration.
Extremely ordered mesoporous SBA-15 have been prosperously synthesized by Mirzae et al. through a plain sol−gel technique and then functionalized with polyamidoamine (PAMAM) dendrimer for acid blue 62 (AB62) dye adsorption.
The structural formula of (a) RhB and (b) AB 62 are given in Figure 7.6. Appropriate parameters for removing AB62 were at pH 2, adsorbent dosage of 0.03 g L–1, and contact time of 60 min at 25 °C. The experimental results suitably fit the Langmuir model and the adsorption was found to be physisorptive and exothermic [45].
Tsai et al. have demonstrated a high density of –COOH groups loading into SBA-16 via a one-pot synthesis route, which involves co-condensation
230 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
of carboxyethylsilanetriol sodium salt (CES) and tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS) templated by Pluronic F127 and P123 in an acidic medium. These functionalized materials are used to effectively remove two cationic dyes methylene blue (MB) and phenosafranine (PF) with the maximum adsorption capacities of -561 and 519 mg g-1, respectively, at pH 9 [46]. The adsorption behavior of MCM-41 on two basic dyes [basic green 5 (BG5) and basic violet 10 (BV10)] was studied by Juang et al. They investigated
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 231
that MCM-41 might be a good adsorbent for the removal of basic dye pollutants from effluents, only when the effect of interactions between MCM41 and large dyes (BV10) on the pore structure stability of MCM-41 is insignificant [47]. Chemical structure of phenosafranine (PF), basic green
232 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
5 (BG5), basic violet 10 (BV10), acid red 1 (AR1), and acid blue 9 (AB9) are given in Figure 7.7.
Wu et al. have studied the adsorption of anionic dyes like Acid Fuchsine (AF) and Acid Orange II (AO) using MCM-41 functionalized with amine groups in the mesoporous silica framework (NH2-MCM-41) as the adsorbent [48]. Chemical structure of (a) Acid Fuchsine (AF) and (b) Acid
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 233
Orange II (AO) are given in Figure 7.8. The maximum adsorption capacity for AF was approximately 140.60 mg g-1 at pH 2.0 and 25 °C with NH2MCM-41 dosage 2.0 g L-1, and 278.38 mg g-1 for AO at pH 3.0, respectively. In single-component systems, equilibrium data fitted well the Langmuir and D-R models, suggesting the adsorption to be monolayer and physical in nature. Kinetic studies showed that the adsorption process could be better described by both the Lagergren pseudo-second-order and the Spahn and Schlunder models. Moreover, it was found that the adsorption was governed by film diffusion followed by intraparticle diffusion. Thermodynamic constant values ( Go<0, Ho<0 and So<0) demonstrated that the adsorption reactions of AF and AO onto NH2-MCM-41 were feasible, spontaneous, and exothermic under examined conditions. For binary component systems, AF and AO exhibited competitive adsorption onto NH2-MCM-41, and adsorption capacity values of AF and AO were reduced compared to those of the corresponding single-component systems. Furthermore, both in single and binary component systems, the experimental data could be better described by the Langmuir isotherm and the pseudo-second-order kinetic models.
The adsorption behavior of the polyamine functionalized mesoporous silica (MS-PEI) and 3-aminopropyltriethoxy silane (APTES) functionalized mesoporous silica was (MS-APTES) studied by Nayab et al. toward anionic dyes [49]. The kinetic data support a pseudo-second-order adsorption behavior for both monolayer and polymer functionalized MS. The associated thermodynamic parameters (ΔG°, ΔH°, and ΔS°) reveal that the process of adsorption with MS-PEI is more spontaneous and energetically
234 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
favored as compared to the adsorption with MS-APTES. Taken together, the novel adsorbent system derived from a combination of MS and branched polymer (MS-PEI) shows a higher adsorption efficiency and capacity toward the anionic dyes than the monolayer-based adsorbent (MS-APTES).
Nanda et al. have synthesized in situ preparation of meso-MnO2MCM-41 and studied both dye adsorption and photodegradation. The intra-particle mesoporosity and high textural properties have a vital role for an efficient adsorption of dyes such as Rd 6G, MB, MG, and RhB [50]. Chemical structure of (a) Malachite Green (MG) and (b) Rhodamine 6G (Rd 6G) are given in Figure 7.9. Maximum adsorption capacity, optimum adsorption conditions such as pH, temperature, initial dye concentration, adsorbent dose, fitted isotherm, kinetic model, thermodynamic parameters, and mechanism of adsorption for dyes onto mesoporous silica are given in Table 7.2.

sections.heading: 7.3 Titanate Nanotubes
sections.text:
After the discovery of carbon nanotubes, tatanium oxide nanotubes gained huge attention owing to its one-dimensional nanostructure and unique physical and chemical properties. In recent years, TNT themselves have attracted much attention due to their potential application in areas of photocatalysis [51, 52], wastewater treatment [53], ion exchange [54], lithium ion storage [55], solar energy conversion [56], and so on. Lower fabrication cost, nanotubular structure, good sedimentation properties, large surface area, and pore volume made titanate nanotubes as promising adsorbents for the removal of organics and heavy metals from aqueous solutions [54, 57, 58].
