Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 239
for the removal of Cr (VI) and organic dyes was reviewed in this section [33, 59, 60].

sections.heading: 7.3.1 Adsorption of Cr (VI) on to Titanate Nanotubes
sections.text:
The mechanism for adsorption of coexisting Cr (III) and Cr (VI) onto titanate (TiO6) nanotubes was explained with the help of Scheme 7.2 [59]. According to it, a double-layer adsorption occurred when Cr (III) and Cr (VI) were coexisted. An ionic cluster of Cr (III) and Cr (VI) was formed first and these were bridged with Cr (III), which was adsorbed onto titanate nanotubes mainly by the ion exchange mechanism with the formation of Cr (III)–O–Cr (VI) linkage. The maximum adsorption capacity for Cr (III) and Cr (VI) was found to be 82.1 and 9.8 mg g-1, respectively. It was also observed that the rearrangement of Cr (III) from the second layer to the surface of titanate nanotubes takes place during unsaturation of adsorption sites resulting in the breakage of Cr(III)–O–Cr(VI) linkage which causes decrease in the adsorption of Cr(VI). Adsorption of Cr (VI) from aqueous solution onto amino-functionalized titanate nanotubes was investigated by Wang et al. [33]. The adsorbent was prepared by covalently grafting [1-(2-amino-ethyl)-3-aminopropyl] trimethoxysilane onto protonated titanate nanotubes and exhibited much higher adsorption capacity for the removal of Cr (VI) as compared to protonated titanate nanotubes. It is because of high porosity, surface area, and presence of a large number of protonated amino groups which possess good selectivity toward Cr (VI) species due to electrostatic attraction. The authors have suggested that protonated amino groups adsorb negatively charged Cr (VI) species via
Scheme 7.2 Schematic diagram of the synergetic adsorption of Cr (III) and Cr (VI) in the binary system [Reproduced from reference 59].
240 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
electrostatic attraction by exchanging NO3 - ions present earlier on them according to equations (7.1)–(7.3):
–NH3 +NO3 – + HCrO4 – –NH3 +HCrO4 – + NO3 – (7.1)
2 (–NH3 +NO3 –) + CrO4 2– (–NH3 +)2 CrO4 2– + 2NO3 – (7.2)
2 (–NH3 +NO3 –) + Cr2O7 2– (–NH3 +)2 Cr2O7 2– + 2NO3 – (7.3)
The adsorbed Cr (VI) species were reduced partially to Cr (III) with the participation of H+ ions and electrons from amino groups as per the following chemical equations:
Cr2O7 2– + 14H+ + 6e– 2Cr3+ + 7H2O (7.4)
CrO4 2– + 8H+ + 3e– 2Cr3+ + 4H2O (7.5)
HCrO4 – + 7H+ + 3e– 2Cr3+ + 4H2O (7.6)
Cr (III) species so formed were chelated with amino groups and hence were not entered into the solution. The mechanism of adsorption was shown in Scheme 7.3. Experimental results followed the Langmuir isotherm model which suggested the presence of homogeneous active sites and monolayer adsorption of Cr (VI) onto the surface of both the adsorbents. Maximum adsorption capacity computed by the Langmuir isotherm model was found to be 153.85 mg g-1 for amino-functionalized titanate nanotubes whereas that for protonated titanate nanotubes was 26.60 mg g-1 at initial pH 5.0 and temperature 30 °C. Titanate nanotubes modified with 2-bromo-ethylamine hydrobromide exhibited higher adsorption capacity for the removal of Cr (VI) as compared to titanate nanotubes [60]. It was because the existence of a positive charge on its surface in a wide pH range (pH < 8) as its pHzpc was 8.2 and the presence of –NH2 groups in appropriate pH ranges, which caused electrostatic attraction toward negatively charged Cr (VI) species, leading to a large adsorption capacity. The maximum adsorption capacity of modified titanate nanotubes calculated from the Langmuir isotherm model was found to be 69.1 mg g-1, which was almost five times greater than that of titanate nanotubes. Maximum adsorption capacity, optimum adsorption conditions such as pH, temperature, initial Cr (VI) concentration, adsorbent dose, fitted isotherm, kinetic model, thermodynamic parameters, and mechanism of adsorption for Cr (VI) onto titanate nanotubes are listed in Table 7.1.
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 241
Scheme 7.3 Schematic illustration of Cr (VI) adsorption–reduction mechanism onto amino-functionalized titanate nanotubes (reproduced from reference 33).

sections.heading: 7.3.2 Adsorption of Dyes on to Titanate Nanotubes
sections.text:
Calcined titanate nanotubes (TNT) were synthesized by Xiong et al. with a hydrothermal treatment of the commercial TiO2 (Degussa P25) followed by calcination. The adsorption MB onto calcined TNT was studied. The pseudo-second-order model was the best to describe the adsorption kinetics and the intraparticle diffusion was not the rate-limiting step. The equilibrium adsorption data were in good agreement with the Langmuir isotherm model having a correlation coefficient of 0.993 indicating monolayer adsorption. The maximum adsorption capacity of 133.33 mg g-1 was obtained.
The mechanism of adsorption can be explained through chemical sorption which involves the formation of methylene blue-calcined titanate nanotube nanocomposite. Electrostatic attraction might be predominant in the initial bulk diffusion [61]. The morphological studies TEM (transmission electron microscopy) and HRTEM (high resolution TEM) of TNTs are shown in Figure 7.10.
242 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
Hsieh and his coworkers prepared TNTs by the hydrothermal method and investigated the liquid-phase adsorption behavior of MB onto TNTs. Highly porous titania nanotubes with the maximum surface were formed by hydrothermal treatment. The nanotubes are mainly mesoporous and their pore sizes were found to increase with calcination temperature. Adsorption mainly occurs through physisorption process and the maximum adsorption capacity was found to be 290 mg g-1 [62]. Hierarchical 3D titanate nanotubes with pompon-like microspheres were synthesized by a simple hydrothermal method in the presence of CH3COOH and H2O2. It indicates that the obtained material is rich in hydroxyl groups. The 3D-TNT microspheres exhibited excellent selective adsorption performance toward cationic dyes such as MB, NR, MG, and CV with very high rate of decolorization process. The saturated adsorption capacities for NR, MB, MG, and CV are found to be 401.8, 382.07, 361.95, and 322.5 mg g-1 at 25 °C respectively [63]. Lee et al. studied the adsorption behavior of
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 243
basic dyes [basic green 5 (BG 5) and basic violet 10(BV 10)] on to titanate nanotubes and that of acid dyes (acid red 1 and acid blue 9) onto cetyltrimethylammonium (CTAC) chloride-modified TNTs. The low amount of Na+ favors good adsorption of TNTs and their CTAC-modified version for the removal of basic and acid dyes from aqueous solution through the cation and anion exchange mechanism [64]. The effect of hydrothermal synthesis temperature of TNTs on adsorption of BG5 and BV10 was investigated by Lee and his coworkers [65]. The sample prepared at 160 °C exhibited a maximum adsorption capacity of 216 mg g-1 for BG5, which is comparable to that exhibited by activated carbon. It may be due to the retention of a nanotubular structure with the retention of adequate titanate interlayer spacing, surface area, and pore volume suitable for adsorption at this temperature. Furthermore, the adsorption capacity of TNT for BG5 is greater than that for BV10. It might be attributed to the smaller size of BG5, which can efficiently be packed in TNT [66]. Maximum adsorption capacity, optimum adsorption conditions such as pH, temperature, initial dye concentration, adsorbent dose, fitted isotherm, kinetic model, thermodynamic parameters, and the mechanism of adsorption for dyes onto titanate nanotubes are given in Table 7.2.

sections.heading: 7.4 Layered Double Hydroxides
sections.text:
Layered double hydroxides are referred to as hydrotalcite-like materials with a general formula [M(II)1-xM(III)x(OH)2]
x+[Ax-].nH2O, where M(II) is the divalent metal ion, M(III) is the trivalent metal ion, and Ax- is the exchangeable interlayer anion [67]. These are a class of layered materials that possess a flat two-dimensional morphology composed of different elementary layers constituted by a hydroxy framework of different metal ions such as Mg2+, Zn2+, Al3+, Fe3+, etc. Isomorphous substitution of bivalent metal ions in the brucite-like hydroxy framework by trivalent metal ions such as Al3+, Cr3+, Fe3+, etc. gives rise to the generation of additional charge over the layers, which is counterbalanced by exchangeable anions such as Cl-, CO3 2-, SO4 2-, etc. In recent years, these are used extensively for water remediation through the removal of noxious anions (and interestingly sometimes cation) from waste waters [68, 69] because of their large surface area for the adsorption of anion, ability for facile exchange of interlayer anion, and tailorable hydrophobic/hydrophilic nature [70]. HTlcs can remove anions from the solution by three different mechanisms: (a) adsorption on external surfaces, (b) intercalation by anion exchange, and (c) intercalation by reconstruction of the calcined material. The third
244 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
mechanism follows the calcination of LDH to produce intermediate nonstoichiometric oxides, which undergo rehydration in an aqueous medium and give back the hydroxide structure with different anions in the interlayers (memory effect) [71].

sections.heading: 7.4.1 Adsorption of Cr (VI) on to Layered Double Hydroxides
sections.text:
Layered double hydroxides containing nitrates or chlorides in the interlayer, after modification and calcined forms, are generally explored for the removal of Cr (VI) [72, 73]. Houri et al. studied the removal of Cr (VI) Mg Al –Cl, Zn Al – Cl and Zn Cr - Cl with chloride as an interlayer anion. The authors reported 55 mg g-1 uptake capacity [72]. Bulbulian and co-workers studied the chromate uptake efficiency of MgAl LDHs and reported that the calcined ones are better adsorbents than as-synthesized forms. The authors studied the materials for real systems such as tannery waste and concluded that calcined samples were the best [74]. Goswamee et al. carried out the adsorption of Cr (VI) onto MgAl, NiAl, and ZnCr LDHs and found that MgAl was effective than the other ones. Among MgAl samples, those with higher Al content on calcination gave good uptake capacity. The rehydration efficiency of the MgAl sample made it a good adsorbent for Cr (VI) than NiAl and ZnCr [75]. Ternary HTs were used to increase the adsorption capacity. Zr4+ was incorporated over ZnAl and MgAl in different amounts and achieved a maximum chromate uptake capacity of 31 mg g-1 for calcined MgAlZr-HT (at 450 °C). With the incorporation of Zr4+, the surface charge increased that helped in the removal of anionic species of Cr (VI) [76]. Later in 2007, Carriazo et al. explored the anion exchange ability of chloride for chromate uptake and they compared the uptake capacity of chloride-LDHs with its carbonate counterpart. The results reported show that MgAl chloride samples are better adsorbents than even calcined MgAl sample [77]. Calcined MgAl-CO3 was also explored by Alvarez-Ayuso and Nugteren for the removal of Cr (VI) through reconstruction and reported 128 mg g-1 uptake [78]. Similar results were earlier reported by Rhee et al. through reconstruction over calcined MgAl-CO3 [79]. Lazaridis and coworkers investigated the sorption of Cr (VI) over MgAl-CO3 LDHs. The calcined material gave an uptake capacity of 120 mg g-1. The authors reported that with agitation speed, at low pH, and at high chromate concentration, the uptake capacity enhanced. Detailed kinetic and equilibrium studies were done over as-synthesized MgAl-CO3 and reported 17 mg g
-1 uptake capacity [80, 81]. The mechanism of adsorption and factors affecting adsorption of Cr (VI) in an aqueous solution onto aluminum magnesium mixed hydroxide nanoparticles were studied by Li et al. [82]. According to the
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 245
study, adsorption of Cr (VI) species onto the adsorbent is the combination of anion exchange and surface complexation processes. A former mechanism suggested that Cl- ions associated with the surface or interlayer of the adsorbent exchange with the anionic Cr (VI) species as per Equation (7):
Sur-OH2 +/Cl- + HCrO4 - → Sur-OH2 +/ HCrO4 - + Cl- (7)
The later mechanism involved the electrostatic interaction between the protonated surface of the adsorbent and negatively charged Cr (VI) species as mentioned in equation (8).
Sur-OH2 + + HCrO4 - → Sur-OH2 +/HCrO4 - (8)
The maximum adsorption capacity was found to be 112 mg g-1 at pH 4.0 and 40 °C. The nano-sized adsorbents with Mg/Al molar ratio 3 exhibited largest adsorption efficiency due to smallest average particle diameter and highest zeta potential. Ramirez et al. studied sol–gel MgAl hydrotalcite for the removal of chromate. MgAl sol–gel sample heated at 350 °C showed high adsorption capacity than 150 °C heated and unheated ones. The authors observed that with surface area the adsorption capacity increased, 350 oC calcined sample exhibits higher surface area and capacity [83]. Recently, Goh et al. reported the adsorption of Cr (VI) along with other oxyhalides and anions over MgAl LDHs prepared through fast precipitation. The nitrate and chloride-containing MgAl samples were studied. Among the anions studied, chromate was removed to a greater extent (1.2 meq g-1). The mechanism for uptake of Cr (VI) was also studied by the authors and stated that the occurrence of anion exchange or ligand exchange results in outer-sphere and inner-sphere complexes [84]. The influence of competitive anions such as nitrate, sulfate, carbonate, phosphate over adsorption of chromate, and other oxyanions were also reported by them. The influence of other co-existing anions on the adsorption of chromate had great dependence on the pH of the solution as at a different pH, the coexisting anions as well as chromate moieties will change [85]. Xu et al. carried out a column study for chromate uptake over calcined MgAl-CO3. The results showed that calcined MgAl exhibited around 44 mg g-1 uptake capacities over a range of 50–200 mg L-1. The authors claimed that the material could be regenerated and reused effectively [86]. Cocheci et al. analyzed the adsorptive capacity of ZnAl-CO3 and found that as-synthesized samples were effective for chromate removal than its calcined forms. They also stated that in the case of as-synthesized ZnAl-CO3, the chromate was not exchanged with carbonate in the interlayer, but exchanged
246 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
at the edges of brucite-like layers [87]. Cocheci and coworkers reported uptake of Cr (VI) onto MgZnAl hydrotalcites with a varying Mg/Zn/Al ratio. The studies over calcined MgZnAl HTs showed that MgAl gave maximum chromate uptake. The results confirmed that incorporation of Zn shows no effect on chromate uptake capacity [88]. The impact of ferric iron in calcined nano-Mg/Al hydrotalcite on the adsorption of Cr (VI) from the aqueous solution was studied with respect to structure characteristics, adsorption properties, and the removal mechanism [89]. Mg/Al and Mg/Al/Fe precursors are nanosized particles and lamellar structure but the latter possessed smaller interlayer space. The mechanism of Cr (VI) removal by both the adsorbents takes place not only through intercalation but also by strong interaction between negative ions and positive external surface and inter layer ion exchange mechanism. After the reconstruction process, calcined Mg/Al/Fe showed a high adsorption rate though its adsorption capacity was less than that of calcined Mg/Al. It was because the replacement of Al3+ by Fe3+ in layered double hydroxide increased the positive surface charge by strengthening the bonds between double hydroxide layers and the carbonates in the interlayer due to which negatively charged Cr (VI) species were attracted toward it with a faster rate. On the other hand, the anions present in the interlayer were strongly attracted toward Fe3+ due to its high polarizing power than Al3+ making the ion exchange process more difficult, which decreased the adsorption capacity. Maximum theoretical saturated adsorption capacities calculated from the Langmuir isotherm model for calcined Mg/Al and Mg/Al/Fe were 85.9 and 75.4 mg g-1, respectively, at pH 3.0 and at 48 °C. Though thermodynamic parameter values revealed that the adsorption process was spontaneous and endothermic, yet changes in these values indicated that the addition of Fe3+ in calcined Mg/Al will not be favorable for the adsorption process due to the nature of ferric iron, which makes the interlayer anion exchange more difficult, after the reconstruction of the structure. Therefore, the presence of Fe3+ in calcined Mg/Al hydrotalcite was unfavorable for the removal of Cr (VI) from the aqueous solution. The efficiency of Mg/Fe hydrotalcite-like compounds for the removal of Cr (VI) from an aqueous medium was studied by Das et al. [35]. Adsorption of Cr (VI) increased with the decrease in pH and it is independent of Cr (VI) speciation. Higher adsorption was observed at lower pH due to strong attraction of Cr (VI) species with the positively charged adsorbent surface. However, adsorption decreased significantly at pH ≤ 4.0 because of partial dissolution of the adsorbent at this pH. Less diffusion of ions into the pores of the adsorbent, reversible process between the adsorbed species and that in the bulk solution, and increased competition between
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 247
Cr (VI) species and OH- ions are the facts which caused a decrease in the removal of Cr (VI) at higher pH. Kinetic studies revealed that adsorption occurred on the outer surface as well as within the pores of the adsorbent through diffusion. Hydrotalcite-like compounds containing cations such as Mg2+, Zn2+, and Al3+ with different proportions in brucite-like sheets and carbonate or benzoate anions in the inter layers were prepared by the coprecipitation method to evaluate their adsorption capacity for the removal of Cr(VI [90]. The most efficient adsorbent was obtained from the calcined Mg-Zn-Al hydrotalcite-like precursor containing interlayer CO3
2- anions. This material exhibited greater performance for the removal of Cr (VI) from the aqueous solution in the presence of competitive anions such as Cl- and SO4
2-. The adsorption capacity also depended on the metal content. Thus, composition of metal ions and the structural and textural properties influenced the adsorption capacity of these adsorbents. Maximum adsorption occurred at an optimal pH of 6.0. Pseudofirst-order models described well the adsorption kinetics. Mg-Al oxides adsorbed the Cr (VI) species by the reconstruction of a layered structure while Zn-containing materials adsorbed them on their surface. The difference in behavior of Zn-containing materials was due to the separation of oxide phases. Layered double hydroxides with Co/Bi = 3 were synthesized by urea hdrolysis and subjected for adsorption of Cr (VI). The asprepared Co-Bi LDH samples exhibited a maximum adsorption capacity of 277.7 mg g-1 at pH 7.0 [91]. Maximum adsorption capacity, optimum adsorption conditions such as pH, temperature, initial Cr (VI) concentration, adsorbent dose, fitted isotherm, kinetic model, thermodynamic parameters, and mechanism of adsorption for Cr (VI) onto layer double hydroxides are listed in Table 7.1.

sections.heading: 7.4.2 Adsorption of Dyes on to Layered Double Hydroxides
sections.text:
Santos et al. have studied the thermal decomposition of carbonate-intercalated layered double hydroxide (ZnAl-CO3-LDH) followed by acid blue 113 adsorption [92]. The kinetics of dye adsorption on calcined-LDH shows a two-step behavior consistent with the dye adsorption on the external and internal surfaces of ongoing recovered LDH lamellar aggregates. The intercalation of anionic dye in the interlayer LDH galleries is only verified after 180 min of contact with the dye solution, contributing to merely 13% of the adsorption capacity. The adsorption isotherms follow the Langmuir model, confirming that the adsorption takes place mainly on the reconstructed LDH external surface. The LDH memory effect allows the efficient recyclability of the used LDH adsorbent.
248 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
Magnesium aluminum layered double hydroxides were synthesized by Abdellaoui et al. through the co-precipitation method with nitrate and carbonate as an interlayer anion (MgAlNO3 and MgAlCO3) followed by the calcination of a carbonate-containing LDH sample to obtain the mixed oxide MgAl500 [93]. The resulting materials were characterized by several physicochemical techniques. Calcined and uncalcined LDHs were used as adsorbents to remove the amaranth azo dye in an aqueous solution. Adsorption results indicated that MgAl500 had a greater adsorption capacity (1.6 mmol·g−1) than non-calcined LDHs (0.8 and 0.2 mmol·g−1 for MgAlNO3 and MgAlCO3, respectively). Isotherms showed that the adsorption of the dye was consistent with the Langmuir model. The kinetic experiments of dye adsorption showed that the system reached the adsorption equilibrium in 3 h for the three adsorbents. The kinetic data fitted well with the pseudo-second-order model. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the adsorption products suggest that adsorbed amaranth anion was intercalated in the MgAlNO3 interlayers by anion exchange and in the MgAl500 by the rehydration and reconstruction process, according to the value of the basal space d003 = 17.7 Å. Whereas in the case of MgAlCO3, it was probably adsorbed on the external particle surface.
The influence of common inorganic anions present in the solution was also studied and a decrease in the dye removal was observed in the following order HPO4 2− > CO3 2– > SO4
2− > Cl–. The dye desorption was tested with a carbonate and phosphate solution and it was partial in all cases. The recyclability of the used adsorbents was performed by calcinations, and the percentage of removal decreases after the first cycle for MgAlNO3 and MgAl500. The dye removal improved after the first cycle, and then decreased after the second cycle for MgAlCO3.
A novel strategy for the preparation of poly(levodopa) functionalized MgAl-layered double hydroxide (PDOPA-f-LDH) was developed by Zhao et al. based on the modified mussel-inspired chemistry [94]. The utilization of PDOPA-f-LDH for the removal of methylene blue (MB) from an aqueous solution was also examined. Taken advantage of the self-polymerization of levodopa (DOPA) in an alkaline solution and the strong affinity of catechol groups to the substrate surface, the LDH was covered homogeneously by a layer of polymer coating of DOPA, leading to the functionalization toward LDH. The structure, surface morphology, thermos-stability, and elemental composition of as-prepared PDOPA-f-LDH were investigated by the transmission electron microscope, scanning electron microscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Besides, the surface charge of the PDOPAf-LDH was also investigated using zeta potential. The effects of various
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 249
parameters, including contact time, initial MB concentration, solution pH, and temperature, on the adsorption of MB onto PDOPA-f-LDH were systematically investigated. Results show that the adsorption capacity of functionalized LDH at 25 °C could reach up to 102 mg g-1, which is much higher than that of pure LDH under the same experimental conditions. The adsorption kinetics and isotherm of MB adsorption were studied in batch experiments. The pseudo-second-order model is found to be the best to describe the adsorption kinetics. The isotherm result shows that the Freundlich isotherm is the better-fit-isotherm model to represent the equilibrium data. The values of thermodynamic parameters, including enthalpy change ΔH0, entropy change ΔS0, and Gibbs free energy change ΔG0, were also determined. All the ΔG0 values are negative; the ΔH0 and ΔS0 values of PDOPA-f-LDH were −7.824 kJ mol−1 and −0.01562 kJ mol−1 K−1, respectively. The activation energy of system (Ea) is calculated as 24.69 kJ mol−1. The fact suggests that the MB adsorption on PDOPA-f-LDH is a spontaneous and exothermic process. These obtained results indicate that the prepared PDOPA-f-LDH could be used as an interesting adsorbent with great potential to adsorb the cationic dyeing pollutants from aqueous media.
The NiFe layered double hydroxides with a different mole ratio of Ni/ Fe (4:1, 3:1, 7:3, and 1:1) were prepared through a simple co-precipitation method by Lu et al. [95]. The adsorption performance was evaluated by the removal of methyl orange (MO) dye and hexavalent chromium (VI) heavy metal ion as shown in Figure 7.12. It is found that Ni4Fe1-LDH can remove
250 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
more than 92% of MO in 10 min at the 10 mg L–1 MO initial concentration, and 97% of Cr (VI) in 1 h at 4 mg L–1 Cr2O7
2− initial concentration. The saturated adsorption capacity of Ni4Fe1-LDH is found to be as large as 205.76 mg g–1 for MO and 26.78 mg g–1 for Cr (VI). The adsorption behavior of this new adsorbent is fitted well with the Langmuir isotherm and the pseudo-second-order kinetic model, indicative of a monolayer and chemical adsorption that synergistically originates from the exchangeable anion mechanism and layer charge density. Due to the excellent removal capacity of MO and Cr (VI), the NiFe-LDHs could be a promising adsorbent for wastewater treatment.
Ahmed et al. adopted a new approach for the removal of indigo carmine blue (IC) dye which is extensively used in jeans manufacture and was successfully performed on novel mesoporous (LDH) nanoparticles prepared by the sol–gel route using CTAB as a shape and pore directing agent [96]. A successful adsorption of IC on LDH nanoparticles of surface area = 85.6 m2 g-1 at various pH with a maximum adsorption capacity of 62.8 mg g-1 at pH = 9.5. The Langmuir model is more favorable to describe the adsorption of IC rather than the Freundlich model, which reflects the preferential formation of monolayer on the surface of LDH. Both film diffusion and the intraparticle diffusion affect the dye adsorption. The values of enthalpy change for (ΔH) and (ΔS) are +28.18 and +0.118 kJ mol-1, respectively, indicating that the removal process is endothermic. The results indicated that LDH nanoparticles conserved a good activity even after five consecutive cycles of reuse. The results suggest that mesoporous LDH nanoparticles are considered a potential novel adsorbent for the remediation of wastewater containing IC.
A series of hydroxyl ammonium ionic liquids/layered double hydroxide intercalation composites (ILs/LDHs) were synthesized and adopted to study the adsorption process of anionic dye reactive orange 5 from aqueous solutions by Zhou et al. [97]. The experimental results showed that the maximum adsorption capability of ILs/LDHs reached up to 300.9 mg g-1, which was obviously higher than that of LDHs. The adsorption isotherms were well described by the Freundlich model in the presence of the LDHs and ILs/LDHs. The adsorption kinetics followed the pseudosecond-order kinetic model. The negative value of ΔG° and the positive value of ΔH° indicated a spontaneous and endothermic nature of reactive orange 5 adsorption. For ILs/LDHs (b), desorption percentages were 57.91%, 46.67%, and 37.34% in each cycle, respectively.
Li et al. have reported a novel magnetic polydopamine (PDA)–LDH (MPL) bifunctional material, which is fabricated by an easy and green approach for the simultaneous removal of potentially toxic metals and
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 251
anionic dyes [98]. In a mono-component system, the removal behaviors showed heterogeneous removal capacities of 75.01, 624.89, and 584.56 mg g−1 for Cu (II), methyl orange (MO), and Congo red (CR), respectively. Interestingly, the presence of CR and MO enhanced the removal of Cu (II) significantly in the Cu (II)–dye binary system. However, the presence of Cu (II) had no significant effect on dyes. Such a green and facile synthesis method, efficient removal performance, and superior reusability suggest that the MPL assemblies have a practical application potential for integrative and efficient treatment of coexisting toxic pollutants.
The “batch” method for evaluating the adsorption of Sunset Yellow FCF food dye into a CaAl-LDH-NO3-layered double hydroxide (LDH) system was investigated by Pereira de Sa et al. [99]. The CaAl-LDH-NO3 was coprecipitated at variable pH and characterized by X-ray diffraction, infrared spectroscopy, and scan electron microscopy. Adsorption experiments were carried out as a function of pH, contact time, and dye concentration. The results showed that the pH affects the adsorbent surface charge and the degree of anionic dye dissociation. The effective pH range for dye removal was between 4.0 and 10.0. A lower pH potentially causes dissolution of CaAl-LDH-NO3. The Langmuir equation adequately describes the equilibrium data. The best-fits showed a maximum adsorption of 398.41 mg g-1.
The Mg/Fe LDH with carbonate interaction and its calcined product (CLDH) were synthesized by Guo et al. [100] and used as adsorbents for the removal of acid brown 14 (AB 14) from aqueous solutions. The synthesized CLDH was efficient and had a much higher adsorption capability of 370.0 mg g-1 for AB 14 compared with that of the LDH, 41.7 mg g-1. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the CLDH before and after the adsorption demonstrated that the adsorption was significantly enhanced by reconstruction of its original layered structure in the presence of AB 14 with the memory effect. It was found that the adsorption isotherms were well described by the Langmuir model for both the LDH and the CLDH with a correlation coefficient (R2) > 0.99, and the adsorption kinetics of AB 14 on these two adsorbents followed the pseudo-second-order kinetic model. The results indicated that the calcined Mg/Fe-layered double hydroxide is an efficient adsorbent for the treatment of waste water with a high concentration of anionic dyes.
Ni-Al-layered double hydroxide (Ni-Al LDH) was synthesized by the co-precipitation method from their nitrate salts and utilized as an adsorbent for the removal of methyl orange (MO) dye from its aqueous solution by Monash et al. [101]. The synthesized Ni-Al LDH was characterized using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and
252 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
N2 adsorption–desorption analysis. Batch adsorption isotherm experiments were conducted with methyl orange dye at three different temperatures (30 °C, 40 °C, and 50 °C). Adsorption isotherm data were fitted with Langmuir, Freundlich, and Redlich–Peterson models. It was found that the Langmuir and Redlich–Peterson isotherm models best described the adsorption of MO on calcined Ni-Al LDH. The experimental results revealed that the increase in temperature increases the adsorption capacity of MO on the calcined Ni-Al LDH adsorbent. The maximum adsorption capacity was found to be 5.7 × 10−4 mol g−1 at 50 °C. The influence of pH on the adsorption of MO dye indicated that the adsorbent has good structural stability in the studied pH range. Thermodynamic studies authenticated that the adsorption of MO dye on calcined Ni-Al LDH was spontaneous, endothermic, and an entropy-driven process.
The Mg-Al-CO3-LDH with a Mg 2+/Al3+ molar ratio of 2 was prepared via the co-precipitation method at a constant pH of 9–10 and used to remove three red dyes by the batch adsorption method [102]. The results showed Mg-Al-LDH were well crystallized and can adsorb the red dyes effectively. The optimal adsorbent dosage and contact time were 1.0 g and 60 min, respectively. Adsorbed amount hardly changed when pH < 10. The adsorption kinetics fit the pseudo-second-order kinetic models well and isotherms correspond to the Langmuir model strictly. All the relevant mechanisms were studied and manifested as anion exchange and also electrostatic attraction for CR. Maximum adsorption capacity, optimum adsorption condition such as pH, temperature, initial dye concentration, adsorbent dose, fitted isotherm, kinetic model, thermodynamic parameters, and mechanism of adsorption for dyes onto layer double hydroxides are listed in Table 7.2.

sections.heading: 7.5 Conclusion
sections.text:
Nanomaterials emerged as good adsorbents for remediation of Cr (VI) due to their high surface area as well as highly active surface sites and exhibited relatively higher adsorption capacity. Modification of their surfaces was carried out to enhance the surface area and number of active surface sites and, hence uptake capacity. Protonated surfaces or protonated modified surfaces of nanomaterials adsorbed Cr (VI) species through electrostatic attraction. In addition to this, surface functional groups such as -OH, -CO-, etc. reduced Cr (VI) to Cr (III). Methods of preparation were responsible for the formation of nanostructutres with a high surface area and uniform particle size which enhanced the uptake capacity.
Adsorption of Cr (VI) and Textile Dyes 253
Introduction of nanoporous architecture, increasing the surface area, and developing layered functional nanomaterials show promising dye adsorption capacities. Mesoporous silica materials having long range ordered porosity, intraparticle mesoporosity, and high effective surface area favor enhanced adsorption (mostly fitted with the Langmuir model) with second-order kinetics. Titanate nanotubes with their unique arryed nanostructures provide higher surface area and large pore volumes for better adsorption of noxious dyes. Moreover, the layered fuctional structures of LDH favors enhanced adsorption in its interlayer spacings.

sections.text: The authors are thankful to the management of SOA University, Bhubaneswar, for their constant support.

sections.heading: 8.1 Introduction
sections.text:
Dyes are major organic compounds of effluents discharged from industries such as textile, pulp and paper, cosmetic and pharmaceuticals, food and packaging, etc. [1, 2]. Methylene blue (MB), that is, methylthioninium chloride (Figure 8.1), is a member of the thiazine class of dyes with many applications [3–5] which was first prepared by  Heinrich Caro in 1876 [6]. The toxic effects from thiazine dyes have been previously investigated and documented [7]. Severe toxic effects (1%) on Iris epithelium and corneal endothelium [11], and toxic effects on human luteal cells [12], on fetus [13], and on erythroleukemic cells [14] are only few examples of the harmful impacts on living organisms when exposed to MB. Hence, the toxicity and carcinogenic effects of this type of dyes raise major concerns about human health and also about the safety of aquatic environments where dye-contaminated effluents might end up [8–10].
The removal of MB from industrial effluents is an important environmental issue because most of the conventional biological, physical, and chemical treatment methods are not able to efficiently degrade this compound [15]. In this context, exploring efficient methods and optimizing its operating conditions for MB removal are goals of high significance. The application of engineered nanomaterials (NMs) has proved to be a successful route for the removal of MB dye from contaminated environments when appropriate conditions are met. Recent studies have shown that the performance of NMs is highly conditioned by the experimental conditions, that is, contact time, pH, and temperature among others, the removal efficiency being very dependent on the combination of used conditions. In addition, the application of additional measures such as UV irradiation has shown the ability to improve the final removal efficiency when assisted by NMs. Table 8.1 summarizes literature data supporting these findings. Despite this pool of knowledge, there is still a need to find out the optimum conditions under which maximum removal efficiency can be achieved under reasonable investments of time, materials, and input energy.

Ultrasonic Synthesis of Zero Valent Iron Nanoparticles 265
As an emerging technology, the application of iron-based NMs for the treatment of polluted waters and wastewaters underwent fast development in recent years. Within this context, iron oxides such as magnetite (Fe3O4) [16, 17], hematite (Fe2O3) [18–20], maghemite (γ-Fe2O3) [21, 22], and iron hydroxides such as lepidocrocite (α-FeOOH) [23] are of particular interest to degrade and remove various types of environmental contaminants. Zero valent iron (ZVI) is another type of iron-based material with a potential to be widely adopted in real-scale applications as an effective, non-toxic, and low-cost alternative for conventional clean-up technologies [24, 25]. The application of micro-sized ZVI particles in permeable reactive barriers [26, 27] is a good example of the utilization of this material as a well-known strategy for the treatment of highly polluted ground waters. However, ZVI particles, if used as nanosized particles (nZVI), may provide a significantly larger surface area-to-volume ratio, and also a higher surface energy which result in significant improvement of their reactivity toward contaminants [28–36]. In addition, various attempts have been made to enhance the properties of these NMs in terms of specific surface area (SSA), crystallinity, etc. [29–31]. However, there is still field for improvements. For instance, the simultaneous enhancement of nanomaterial properties such as crystallinity and surface area and the optimization of nZVI synthesis conditions still remain to be explored.
For optimizing the MB removal efficiency, nZVI synthesized with enhanced surface area and crystalline structure via a combined liquid phase reduction–ultrasonic irradiation technique is proposed here. Also, the MB removal can be maximized by correlating the conditions allowing optimum degradation of MB with the properties of the used NMs. The reactivity of the synthesized nZVI toward MB can be traced with a photometric analysis which allows us to identify the mechanisms involved as well.

sections.heading: 8.2.1 Materials
sections.text:
Chemical reagents including iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3.6H2O from Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) (99%) and sodium borohydride (NaBH4 from Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) (≥98.0%) without further purification are used as precursors and reductants for the synthesis of nZVI. Ethanol from Fisher scientific (99.0%), and deionized water supplied by an ultrapure water purification system (EASYpure RF-Barnstead/Thermolyne)
266 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
are also used for experiments. MB (99%) is from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO). pH adjustments are performed with H2So4 (>95%, Fisher Scientific, UK) and NaOH (JMGC co., Portugal).

sections.heading: 8.2.2 Synthesis and Characterization of NMs
sections.text:
The synthesis of nZVI is performed in a 500 mL three-open-neck flask reactor installed inside an ultrasonic cleaning bath (Branson, 1510E-MT) with a theoretical dissipation rate of 70 W and operating at 42 KHZ ± 6%. Mechanical overhead stirring (at 250 rpm) with IKA Eurostar 40 stirrer is utilized to continuously stir the reaction medium. Certain amounts of a sodium borohydride solution (0.91 g of sodium borohydride dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water) are injected in 30 mL of an ethanol/deionized water solution (24 mL of ethanol + 6 mL of deionized water) containing the precursor (0.81 g of FeCl3.6H2O) at room temperature. A Watson Marlow 120U/R peristaltic pump is utilized to control the injection rate of the reductant. After completing the injection of the reductant solution, the final mixture is stirred for more 10 minutes in the reactor. The black precipitates are then collected, washed, and dried before characterization.
Crystallographic characterization of the synthesized particles is carried out by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Rigaku, Geigerflex, Japan) in the 2θ range from 30° to 100° with a goniometer speed of 2°/minute. The Scherrer equation (equation (2)) is used to determine the crystallite size of the particles:
d K / cos (1)
where d is the average crystallite size, K is a dimensionless shape factor, λ is the wavelength of the X-ray used, β is the full-width at half maximum intensity (FWHM) of the sample, and θ is the Bragg angle. Transmission electron microscopy by Hitachi H9000na (Japan) operated at 300 kV acceleration voltage is utilized to study the morphology of the synthesized particles. Particle size distribution of the particles is obtained by counting more than 500 individual particles selected randomly using photoshop and Image J software programs. Particles’ specific surface area (SSA) is assessed by gas adsorption with a Micromeritics Gemini V2 (USA) equipment. The SSA is calculated based on the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) isotherm. Zeta potential measurements are carried out using a zetasizer (Zetasizer Nano ZS, Malvern, UK) for assessing the electrical charge characteristics of the particles surface. For that, dilute aqueous suspensions of the NMs (10 mL) are prepared under ultrasonic irradiation in an ultrasonic cleaning
Ultrasonic Synthesis of Zero Valent Iron Nanoparticles 267
bath (Model Sonoswiss 6lt, Switzerland). The pH of the nanoparticle suspensions is adjusted in the acidic and alkaline ranges using HCl or NaOH, respectively. The magnetic hysteresis measurements are performed using a vibrating sample magnetometer-VSM (CryogenicCryofree). The hysteresis curve is recorded at 5K under a magnetic field up to 10 T.

sections.heading: 8.2.3 Discoloration of MB
sections.text: Reactivity of the ZVI NMs prepared under ultrasonic irradiation (nZVIUI) is determined using MB, as a model contaminant [40, 41]. The reactions are performed under visible light at 720 lux assisted by a multi-function environment meter (ST-8820, REED, USA) under ambient temperature. Based on a set of preliminary experiments (data not shown), the optimum dosage of the NMs for the removal of MB was identified as 1 g/L. nZVIUI particles are suspended in a 100 mL aqueous solution containing 25 mg/L of MB. The absorbance behavior of the MB solution under various pHs ranging from 4 to 10 at room temperature is monitored for 30 min with a UV-Vis spectrometer (T80+, PG Instruments, UK) from 200 to 750 nm. When the MB (green color) is dissolved in water, a blue color solution is yielded. The intensity of the blue color measured at wave lengths of maximum absorption, i.e., 665 and 605 nm (related to monomeric (0-0 band) and dimeric (0-1 band) forms of MB, respectively [42]) is used to follow the removal process and its efficiency.

sections.heading: 8.3.1 Materials’ Characterization
sections.text:
The XRD pattern of the particles prepared under ultrasonic irradiation is presented in Figure 8.2. The sample is composed of ZVI (JCPDS No. 07-71-3763), without any evidence of secondary phases. Based on Sherrer equation (equation (1)), the crystallite size of the powders was determined as 23.9 nm.
A TEM micrograph of the nZVIUI samples prepared under ultrasonic irradiation is presented in Figure 8.3. The sample consists of aggregates of enchained spherical particles. The particles clearly present a core-shell structure consisting of a dark core (nZVI) covered with a thin bright layer. Figure 8.4 shows the particle size distribution of the prepared particles. As observed, the average particle size is around 27 nm. The BET-specific surface area of this sample was determined as 50.6 m2/g; this large value is
268 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
Ultrasonic Synthesis of Zero Valent Iron Nanoparticles 269
in line with the relatively low average particle size calculated for the sample (Figure 8.4). Also, the SAED image obtained from TEM denotes a relatively high intensity for spots indicating a well-developed crystalline structure.
The pH dependence of nZVIUI zeta potential is shown in Figure 8.5. The results indicate that the zero charge point (zpc) is ~8 and that the surface of the particles is negatively and positively charged at pH above and below 8, respectively.
270 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
Vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) analysis was performed in order to study the magnetic properties of the prepared nZVIUI nanomaterial [35]. In Figure 8.6, the magnetic hysteresis (M-H) loop of the sample is presented. According to this figure, saturation magnetization (Ms) of the sample was found very high (~100 emu/g). This characteristic of the NMs can offer an economic advantage of using this type of NMs for the treatment of polluted aquatic environments because they can be recovered and recycled readily after being used in treatment operations [43–48]. The materials can be easily separated from the treated effluents by applying an external magnetic field, for example, using a permanent magnet.

sections.heading: 8.3.2.1 MB Discoloration under Acidic Conditions
sections.text:
A photometric assay is employed for assessing the concentration of MB in synthetic solutions. Adsorption spectra of MB solutions with different concentrations are detailed in Figure 8.7. As observed, two absorption maxima of MB are detected at 610 and 664 nm [49–52], their intensity difference being attenuated as MB concentration increases. In this study, the conversion of MB to any colorless products such as MLB is termed as discoloration whereas the irreversible conversion of MB to products such as CO2 or H2O is referred as MB degradation [53].
In order to study the extent of MB discoloration using nZVI particles prepared under ultrasonic irradiation and also the mechanisms involved
Ultrasonic Synthesis of Zero Valent Iron Nanoparticles 271
in the process, assays at various pHs of the reaction medium, ranging from 4 to 10, are important in order to cover the effects of pH variation.
The assay at pH = 4 is used to assess the effects of acidic conditions on the process of MB discoloration. Under this condition, the percentage of color removal (here identified as the percentage of reduction of the adsorption intensity measured at 664 nm) from the solution reached only 29% after 30 min of reaction and the pH slightly increased to 4.1. Moreover, after re-collecting the nanoparticles from the reaction medium, the solution becomes rapidly re-colored suggesting that there should be a reversible reaction for the removal of MB under acidic conditions where the MB molecules are not attached to the surface of the NMs considering the zeta potential of the synthesized nZVIUI .
MB is widely applied for optical oxygen sensing especially in the food industry [54, 55]. It is well known that MB is reduced to leuco methylene blue (LMB) which is a colorless compound in the absence of oxygen. This compound is readily re-oxidized (to MB) by introducing oxygen to the system [56]. When MB is subjected to the treatment with nZVI particles, it is proposed here that the surface layer of ZVI particles undergoes oxidation according to equation (2) [57–60]:
Fe Fe e0 2 2 (2)
The released electrons are subsequently used to reduce the MB to LMB, under acidic conditions. A schematic of the involved mechanism is presented in Figure 8.8.
272 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
According to Figure 8.5, the point of zero charge (PZC) of the prepared nZVI particles is reached approximately at pH 8. Below this pH, the surface of nZVIUI particles is positively charged, while above this pH it is negatively charged. Hence, under acidic conditions, repulsive electrostatic interactions between ZVI particles and the positive ions of MB do not favor the adsorption of MB on the surface of ZVI particles. Therefore, the hypothetic contribution of MB adsorption on ZVI particles for the chemical pathway of MB discoloration is considered negligible within the considered acidic pH window.
As referred, rapid re-coloration of the solution takes place suggesting that under acidic condition LMB does not degrade to simpler intermediate compounds or to final products (CO2+H2O) [61]. This suggestion is supported by the photometric results obtained after 30 min of reaction presented in Figure 8.9. The results show that the difference between the two maximum absorbances at 290 and 664nm becomes enhanced with the reaction time, being this considered as an evidence for the decrease of MB in the reaction medium. Also the intensity of the adsorption peak at 243 nm which is attributed to LMB [62] becomes enhanced with the reaction time, in line with the reasoning here proposed.
Ultrasonic Synthesis of Zero Valent Iron Nanoparticles 273

sections.heading: 8.3.2.2 MB Discoloration under Quasi-neutral Conditions
sections.text: In order to study the effects of increasing the pH till the vicinity of the PZC of the nZVI particles, the pH of the MB solution is adjusted to 7.5 immediately after the addition of the NMs to the suspending medium (water) (1 g/L). The photometric results obtained in a 30 min time interval are presented in Figure 8.10. As observed in Figure 8.9 (a), an apparent effective removal of MB is observed after 5 min of reaction time (blue line), in line with the loss of blue color observed after 5 min. During this short period, the pH of the medium increased slightly to ~8.5. A shoulder at 664 nm (Figure 8.10) indicates that the discoloration of MB was almost achieved but not complete. The shoulder does disappear after 30 min of reaction (Figure 8.10 (b)) (green line), thus indicating that a 100% discoloration of MB was achieved (Figure 8.11). However, a narrow peak observed at

sections.heading: 250 nm indicates that part of the organic dye (MB) is converted into LMB.
sections.text:
Figure 8.10 (c) presents the UV-Vis adsorption of the solution with regard to 24 h, after collecting the NMs. At this time (red line), a small peak is found at 664 nm, corresponding to a concentration of 3.9 mg/L, which is 15% of the initial amount of the MB. We also observed a decrease in the LMB peak at 250 nm denoting the transformation of the existing LMB to MB in the presence of oxygen in the medium.
When the pH of the medium gets close to the PZC of nZVI particles, MB gets more easily adsorbed on the surface of nZVI particles as the repulsive forces between the surface of the nanoparticles and MB molecules are now much weaker or inexistent. Under these conditions, it is assumed that MB
274 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
complexes are formed on nZVI particle surface [61] being very susceptible to chemical attack by species originated at the surface layers of the nZVI particles. According to equations (3) to (7) which describe the reaction possibilities of the nZVI particle surface layers, namely, with the surrounding H2O molecules, H radicals are generated which may induce the cleavage of the MB molecules [63–66]. This can be suggested as a main reason for the higher efficiency of the MB degradation and cleavage at pH = 7.5
Ultrasonic Synthesis of Zero Valent Iron Nanoparticles 275
compared to acidic conditions. A schematic of the involved mechanism under quasi-neutral conditions is presented in Figure 8.12:
Fe Fe e0 2 2 (3)
Fe H O Fe H OH0 2 2 (4)
Fe H Fe H e0 2 2 (5)
Fe H Fe H0 2 22 (6)
Fe Fe e2 3 (7)
Attachment of MB to the surface of the NMs facilitates the degradation of MB molecules.

sections.heading: 8.3.2.3 MB Discoloration under Basic Conditions
sections.text:
Figure 8.13 presents the results of the discoloration of MB carried on at an initial pH of 10. As observed, the extent of the discoloration reached only 26% after 5 min (blue line) which is much lower than that recorded at initial pH = 7.5. After 15 min of reaction (red line), the discoloration of MB reached 61% and it increased further to 100% after 30 min of reaction (green line).
Under high pH values, an extensive adsorption of MB on the surface of the used NMs, helped by electrostatic attractive forces, can be expected.
276 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
Such adsorption provides a favorable condition for the degradation of MB. A lower removal of MB under basic conditions as compared to quasineutral conditions can be attributed to the mechanisms involved in the discoloration of MB in an alkaline medium. According to equation (4), the production of H+ is a key step for the generation of hydrogen radicals which can subsequently degrade and remove MB from the solution. Nonetheless, the presence of abundant OH- under basic conditions may play a scavenging role leading to the readily consumption of the produced H+ near the surface of the nZVI particles. Hence, the reactions for the cleavage of MB are restricted.
It has been well documented in the literature that the performance of NMs for the removal of persistent phenolic compounds increases under acidic conditions [67–70]. Most of the phenolic compounds such as chlorophenols are negatively charged which facilitates their attachment to the surface of NMs positively charged as frequently observed in acidic media. Therefore, it can be suggested that the better efficiency of NMs under acidic pH for the removal of such contaminants is probably associated with the formation of pollutants-NMs surface complexes which might be more effective players in the process of pollutants degradation than the release of electrons to the reaction medium by the reduction of Fe nanoparticles with subsequent chemical attack to pollutants.

278 Nanomaterials in the Wet Processing of Textiles
The results of this study show that the attachment of MB molecules to the surface of nZVI particles under neutral or basic conditions facilitates the degradation of the dye due to the positive charge of MB species. So, it can be anticipated that the available surface area of the NMs is a key factor, because it can critically determine their efficiency when dealing with complex organic pollutants. The results of this study also indicate that the efficiency of the reactions that occurred in the bulk solution (not on the surface of the NMs) is negligible. So, limiting the release of electrons from the nZVI materials to the reaction medium for the purpose of increasing the lifetime of nZVI particles will probably not affect their efficiency.
Table 8.2 provides the results of some recent studies for the removal of MB using ZVI NMs comparing the efficiency of Fe nanoparticles toward the discoloration of MB, under different operating conditions. In most of the cases, the characteristics of the used NMs have not been fully provided in the respective reports. In the present study, a very high efficiency of the NMs for the degradation of MB can be attributed to the enhanced properties (high crystallinity and large specific surface area) of the used nanoparticles which provide a good condition for the rapid degradation of MB in a short period of time (100% discoloration in 5 min) under appropriate pH conditions.

sections.heading: 8.4 Conclusions
sections.text: nZVI particles with enhanced properties may be successfully synthesized by utilization of ultrasonic irradiation. Such NMs present an efficient performance regarding the degradation of MB and discoloration of MB solutions. The pH of the solution medium is a critical parameter for determining the MB removal efficiency of the synthesized NMs. While acidic pH allows achieving 30% discoloration of MB, quasi-neutral conditions of pH = 7.5 permit the complete removal of the dye color. The properties of the NMs including zeta potential, size, specific surface area, and crystallinity are the main factors determining the efficiency of the NMs for environmental clean-up purposes.

metadata.abstractText: The unique properties of nanomaterials have real commercial potential for the textile industry. In recent years, fine materials that are produced using nanotechnology have been used in the textile production process. Production of functional textiles is the main purpose of using nanomaterials or nanocomponents on natural fibers such as cotton, wool, silk and synthetic fibers such as polyester, nylon, and acrylic, as they possess various properties such as light resistance, antimicrobial, self-cleaning, fire retardant, etc. Different kinds of nanostructures are used in textiles. For example, carbon and copper nanoparticles or polymeric nanostructures such as polypyrrol and polyaniline as electro conductive agents; aluminum, zinc oxides, and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) for increasing durability of fibers; antimicrobial agents such as silver, zinc oxide, and titanium dioxide (TiO2); moisture absorbent agents such as TiO2; selfcleaning nanostructures such as CNT, TiO2, and fluoroacrylates; UV protection agents as TiO2 and ZnO; nano porous structures such as silicon dioxide or carbon black in order to improve dye ability of fibers; and many advanced properties such as heat conducting or insulating or electromagnetic shielding via introducing CNT or vanadium dioxide and indium tin oxide to fibers, respectively. In this chapter, the development of using nanostructures to improve the properties of textiles is discussed. For this reason, nanostructures used in finishing processes are presented, separately.
